text: Tap at Haus Wertheym, Frankfurt Altstadt. Pours chestnut brown with a lasting off-white to beige head. Aroma of light toasting, dark fruit, toffee, malt, molasses. prune, and raisin. Quite heavy sugary sweetness, low bitterness. Medium to full body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Decent example of one of my favourite styles.

Dark brown/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, & dark fruit; Flavor of toasted sweet malt, caramel, molasses, dark fruit (notably plums & cherries), raisons, and spice; Alcohol is well hidden; Nicely balanced and complex; Excellent brew.
Dark amber-brown with a light tan head. Dark fruit nose. Opens with medium carbonation and a medium body, and ending with brown sugar, overripe dark fruit, and some alcohol warming.
Powerful and very rich. Warming as it is consumed and lots of aroma and flavor of dried fruits and raisins. Extremely sweet. Tasty and great for dessert.
Butelka 0,33l. Aromat melanoidynowy, s≈Çodowy, karmelowy. Delikatny alkohol. W smaku do≈õƒá g≈Çadkie, chlebowe, karmelowe i alkoholowe.

the aroma is fruity and caramel with hints of vanilla, toffee, raisin, bisquit, dried plum, berries and red wine... the taste is caramel and fruity with notes of toffee, candy, raisin, dried plum, port, figs and dark fruits... sweet, dry and bitter aftertaste...
11.2 oz. bottle. Pour was black, lasting tan head. Aroma was sweet malts, fig, raisin, light chocolate. Taste was sweet, creamy, cocoa, plum.

Deep dark nutty brown hue with a thin ivory foamy top. Lovely dark nutty and sweet roasted toast malt tones on the nose. Earthy toast and dry nutty alcohol phenols on the flavor with a touch of woody metallic nuances. Full, boozy, dark bready and slightly metallic, but in a good German way. A little dry and bready and boozy but alright.
Bottle - Dark brown color with small off-white head. Taste is white sugar and dark malts. alcohol well hidden. round and nice eisbock which lacks some real character.

Bottle, 33cL. @Naintr√© with my dad and mom. A very dark beer with a small off-white head ; poor retention. Prune, dried and candied fruits, roast, caramel. Medium round sweet warming, light dry bitter. Good body, light to meidum oily texture, average carbonation, sweet roasty warming lasting finish. Overall, good !

Yay. My first rate if an eisbock. Bottle pour cola brown with ruby hue and rapidly dissipating tan head. Nose caramel, candied apple, molasses, raisins. Taste sweet up front, candied fruit, fig, prune. Then some stone fruit and caramel. Minimal to no bitterness. Mild hint of alcohol in the end.

Clear, deep amber, cola color, tall, explosive head with fine bubbles. 
Medium body, very flavorful, lean texture, very hot but refreshing mouthfeel, average length. 
Sweet, well balanced by bitterness and acidity. 
Malty, citrusy, barley candy, alcohol flavors. 
Very enjoyable for the style. I prefer tripels and quads. 
Good match with Gruyere, Garrotxa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

nice condensed bock rife with malt and dark fruit wine that is also a little red. sweetish and of course boozy the alcohol helps to thin it out in the finish while creating a warming sensation. some moderate chewiness at first. bit of raisin and a hint of spice. a bit of wood with an ivy.

Aroma is sweet, caramel, floral, maple, nutmeg, brown sugar, booze. Appearance is dark brown, light brown head, clear if it wasn¬ít dark. Taste is caramel, dark fruit, boozy as hell, light maple, nutmeg, toffee, malty, woody, lots of stuff happening here. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, woody caramel booze aftertaste. Overall, it actually tastes pretty good, although it¬ís a touch hot.
Pours a dark brown or black with thin off white head. Aroma sweet dark fruity aroma. Taste of dark fruit and a little boozeness without the bit.

Manchmal ein typisches Bock voll stolzer Malzs√º√üe, dann gerne auch mal sanfter Querschl√§ger in phenole Regionen. Hier gibt es dann Lakritz und rauchige Dunkelobsthinweise zu entdecken. Alles sehr dezent und nicht aufdringlich. Rund, aber auch irgendwie zu schlapp und einen Tick too sweet. Luft nach oben vorhanden üòÅ. 0,33/ca.2¬Ä. BEYOND BEER HH. FLASCHE.

0,33 l bottle from Bierland Hamburg for small 1,60 ¬Ä. Not easy to get in north west Germany. Pours out in a darkest brown, one finger short living beige head. Fresh malt candy on the nose. Dark choco and malt nose, some licorice. Taste starts smooth, malty, little bit choco, cough drops, but not medical, low but present sweetness.Not really alcoholic. Dangerous and nice. One extra point for the low price.

Shared bottle at Addy¬ís. First time trying this style- didn¬ít even know Eisbock was a thing until bartender suggested it. Tons of dark fruit and underlying maltiness but doesn¬ít drink overly sweet. ABV is well done and not overwhelming. Balanced. I¬ím intrigued.
Dark fruit malt smell, taste is same with some caramelized flavor...strong boldness...wouldnt want stronger...At John¬ís for Clemson bowl game and new years

Apparence : Brune bien fonc√©e, limpide, rouge au travers de la lumi√®re, l√©ger col beige, r√©tention faible malgr√© une carbonatation moyenne. Annonce d¬íun corps mince? 
Nez : Malt grill√©, accents toast√©s, fruits rouges m√ªrs, notes bois√©es, cr√®me. 
Go√ªt : Entr√©e assez timide de malts grill√©s et de fruits, l√©ger c√¥t√© sucr√©e. Moyennement sucr√©e. Finale plut√¥t sucr√©e accompagn√©e d¬íune l√©g√®re amertume. 
Sensation : Corps d¬íune l√©g√®ret√© pr√©dite au nez, effervescence moyenne √† faible, longueur moyenne et chaleur d¬íalcool notable en gorge. 
Bref : Bi√®re somme toute facile √† boire dans laquelle le sucre r√©siduel ne devient jamais envahissant √† travers les ar√¥mes grill√©es et fruit√©es de la bi√®re. C¬íest bien, mais il manque de profondeur pour une bi√®re de 9,2% qui se veut √™tre un concentr√©. Comment dire, tous les √©l√©ments y sont (le malt, la levure fruit√©e et la l√©g√®re amertume), quand m√™me de fa√ßon √©quilibr√©e, mais sa l√©g√®ret√© et candeur d¬íapproche laisse un peu sur notre app√©tit.

Beautiful dark body and little head aroma of beet and licorice just like your drunken Georgian uncle likes. Hey, I kid, its like a candy store run by that drunken uncle. Like Mom says you can¬ít go in there anymore because you¬íll get drunk from the fumes off his back. Flavour is muddy candy, cloying with sugary barley. Not my kinda Bock. Or Bork. But that¬ís another story.
Bottle. Dark brown. Aroma: malt, jam with caramel and malt, port wine. Taste: sweet, caramel, wine, syrup, a little fruit, candy.

Although not my favorite beer genre, this is an excellent Eisbock (ice bock) specimen. Definitely a "distilled", stronger brew that concentrates dark fruit, almost prune-like flavor but isn¬ít sweet either. Gives a good kick in the pants.

330ml bottle. No deciperable code date. Appearance: Deep dark brown, with dark ruby hints under light. Clear, with a moderate khaki colored head. 
Aroma: Very malty, with some caramel and dark fruit, mostly cherry. 
Taste: Rich, deep malt sweetness with a well balanced blend of caramel, toast, and bread crust. Lighter dark fruit character than in the aroma, that turns to a bit of spicy cherry from the alcohol. Bitterness just enough to prevent the malt sweetness from being cloying. 
Mouthfeel: Medium to heavy body with a moderate carbonation. Alcohol warmth is present, but not abrasive
Finish: Toasted bread strong on the finish, with a touch of dark fruit. 
Overall: Extremely well balanced beer given it¬ís strength. Drinks like a strong Doppelbock, with strong bready, toasty, and dark fruit character, all while balance against the high ABV.
On tap beer. Nice dark color. Raisin and prune notes, but not strong flavors. This sample was different than ones I¬íve had in bottles which had strong flavors.

Tumma, punertavanruskea olut kohtalaisella, mutta hyvin nopeasti kokonaan h√§vi√§v√§ll√§ vaahdolla. Tuoksu varsin mieto, makean maltainen ja limppuinen sek√§ luumuinen. Maku makean maltainen, luumuinen ja aavistuksen paahteinen sek√§ metallinen. Lopussa alkoholi tuntuu hieman. Suutuntuma varsin laimea prosentteihin n√§hden. Ei kovinkaan erikoinen kokonaisuus.

Ruby close to dark black. visible carbonation. White foam that quickly is reduced to a thin layer which lasts until practically drink the cup leaving some lace. Aromatic and complex. On the nose aromas of malt, candy, bread and some alcohol, with fruity notes of dark fruits like plums, figs, raisins and berries such as blackberries and raspberries. certain nuances are also appreciated wood, even very subtly smoked a trace. Just hop intuits. malty character on the palate, dominated by toasted, caramel and fruit, mainly dark fruits with vanilla nuances. The flavors are well blended, not resulting in water or excess alcohol, although alcohol appears suddenly and is present but without bothering with a moderate burning at the end Swallow, helping to provide a dry and slightly bitter aftertaste. Very drinkable despite its intense flavor, alcoholic volume and body.

Bottle. Dark ruby almost black color with small head. Aroma has lots of malt, caramel, toffee, raisins and dark bread. Taste is malty with long sweet aftertaste. Flavors of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, ripe fruits, raisins and a hint of alcohol.

L:
-pours a dark ruby with a medium,quickly dissipating,foamy,offwhite head
-low carbonation visible
S:
-syrup,black bread,raisins,caramel,spicy,figs,dates,cinnamon,to the nose plus banana,slight coffee
-finishes dry
F:
-low to medium carbonation
-medium body
-slight alcohol noticeable
O:
Fantastic, if you like em sweet & complex
On draught. Pours mahogany, with a moderate beige head that fades. Nose is caramel and malt. Taste follows. On the sweet side. Nice.
Pours dark brown with low light tan head. Aroma of hazelnut, caramel, butterscotch. Taste is sweet, slightly burnt, roasty finish. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Dark red-brown, small tan head. Brown sugary malty aroma. Medium full body, a little alcohol. oily texture. Rich sweet malty flavor with caramel, toffee, a little red fruit. Excellent.

345 ml bottle served in a lager glass. 
This is a good looking beer with a deep, dark, reddish brown body topped by a tan head than quickly reduces to a thin top coat and ring. Spotty lacing. 
Sweet malts dominate the aroma. The flavor brings in some boozy elements, as expected, but no higher than usual for style or 9.2% ABV. Lots of toffee and some dark dried fruit notes. Light-moderate sweetness seems just right for style.

Tap at Biermuseum Cologne. Old notes.
Brown. A lot of sweet dry friuts and caramel aroma. Medium sweetness. Thin. A little aclogol. Nice staff.

33cl bottle. Dark brown with a two finger thick creamy tan head which quickly dissipates. Aroma is malty, sweet dark fruits like plum, caramel, boozy. Rich flavour and quite sweet, malt, dark fruit, alcohol, sugary, toffee. A rich, warming and interesting beer.

Bottle 33cl. Poured into a teku glass. Almost opaque dark brown, good two finger dense creamy tan head, mostly diminishing, light lacing; aroma sweet malty, cocoa, caramel, licorice, brown sugar; rich taste, heavy sweet, slightly bitter, malty, chocolate, dates, alcohol; toffee sticky sweet and sugary middle part, toffee, finish sweet and light roasty bitter, slighly boozy; full-bodied, oily to sticky texture, soft carbonation; quite nice, easy to drink and less heavy as expected.

Aroma of chocolate chip cookies. Appearance dark and stouty, half finger head that leaves quickly with no lacing. Alcohol hidden. Palate very sweet. Tastes not too dissimilar to a Russian Imperial Stout but maybe sweeter. Chocolatey. Easier to drink that Aventius Eisbock but completely different taste profile.

Karamella, kaka√≥, aszalt gy√ºm√∂lcs√∂k kombin√°ci√≥ja adja √≠zvil√°g√°t, enyhe √©dess√©gel √©s k√∂zepes sz√©nsavass√°ggal kieg√©sz√ºlve. R√∂gt√∂n √©rezni a magas alkoholtartalmat, de nincs lik≈ër√∂s hat√°s, sz√©pen belesimul a t√∂bbi √≠zkomponensbe. Ut√≥√≠ze r√∂vid, kaka√≥s, √©des-alkoholos. Finom desszerts√∂r.

Aromas of plum dried fruits and malt.

A dark brown beer.

Heavy on the sweetness, along with a generalized bitterness. A fairly long finish with sweet plum and dried fruits and the generalized bitterness. High alcohol is apparent. 

Overall a good and interesting beer, comes across as a Belgian style stout. I like the plum and dried fruit flavors in particular.
Meget st√¶rk og god! har den gode bock smag, der synes bare at v√¶re mere at det hele i den.

People tend to think of Kulmbacher as the quintessential German Eisbock. It¬ís hard to argue with them. It¬ís boozy, malty, rich, fruity, syrupy, and will warm you right the hell up. The body has a beautiful balance between carbonation and full-bodied malt.
pours dark cola brown with a thick tan head. aroma is rich caramel malt. The taste is rich and malty sweet. leaves a malty bittersweet on the palate through the finish. A really enjoyable brew!

From a 12 oz poured in a glass. Aroma is sweet vanilla. Flavor is rich and very sweet chocolate. No alcohol burn. Tasty. No offputing flavors, but nothing really great either. Honestly just bought to get the tick for an Eisbock.

Bubbily blackish brown with head that disappears pretty quickly. Boozy medicinal aroma. Really sweet caramel, raisins, hides the booze pretty impeccably. Thick body but goes down really smooth. Some warming with sticky heavy maltiness that hangs on the roof of your mouth. A nice dessert style nightcap but in all honesty not the best thing I¬íve ever had. Love the story behind the style though. Personally I enjoyed the Aventinus eisbock more.

Aroma - alcohol, rich dark malt that has notes of fig, molasses, and caramelized sugars.
Appearance - black body, with a 1/2" off-white head that hangs out for a while.
Taste - sweet and rich malt. Elements of molasses, caramelized sugar, and fig.
Palate - body is medium, the texture thick, the carbonation bordering on lively, the finish slightly astringent with alcohol.
Blue rather than silver label. Sweet bock aroma and taste. Dark brown color. Alcohol rather than hops in after taste.

Shared 11.2 oz. bottle. Pours dark amber with a rather light beige head. Aroma of caramel, alcohol and lots and lots of malt. Tastes of molasses, caramel, sweet malts, maybe a hint of prune, some alcohol. Not much bitterness to speak of. Warms the belly.

Aroma: sweet with caramel maltiness; Appearance: dark, red amber with off white head; Taste: malty with caramel but not very pleasant; Palate: strange aftertaste; Overall: definitely not my favorite; would not buy again.
Dark amber color with tan head. Aroma is sweet raisins, toffee, some spices. Taste is not even as sweet as one expects. Rather low carbonation, good chewiness. Low carbonation. Very good!

Bouteille 0,33 l from Abou. Dark reddish dress with a fleeting head. Aromas malted and caramel, roasted-chocolate dry fruits. The taste is syrupy, locor-like, with candied cereals and residual sugar. Fruity esters and notes of dry fruits, dates, molasses and earthy hops. Rich and warm.

Dark, chestnut color. Medium-sized head. Roasted malt , nuts , dark fruits and cookies in aroma. Sweet , malty taste with gentle bitterness at the end . Well hidden alcohol. Smooth and warming finish . Great, winter sipper.

Has a roasted caramel nut aroma. Rich dark cinnamon body with a two finger faint tanned head to start. Rich roasted caramel taste with a thick wet feel. Warming to the palate. This one is meant to be enjoyed slowly.

Bottle, big almond colored head faded to a skiff, deep almost black beer. Aroma sweet raisin, malt. Taste is raisin, malt, faint clove and cinnamon, coffee and toasted barley at the finish. Palate is rich, carbonation subdued. Nice and warm!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2016 A really ¬íold¬í favorite. In the 1960¬ís, I got drafted and was fortunate enough to spend a year and a half stationed in Bamberg, Franconia, Bavaria, Deutschland. And to learn what real beer was like and enjoy the numerous small Franconian breweries while my friends and brothers were being killed in yet another senseless imperialist war. But anywho, toward the end of the month and the next payday, we GI¬ís were always broke and in need of some mind numbing forgetfulness for pocket change, and I hit on a few bottles of this Eisbock, at one mark a bottle (at that time 25 cents) plus a couple of shots of cognac (similarly priced) as a quick trip to la-la land. Good non-memories of several wasted years serving Uncle Sam. Anyway,
my local astonishingly good pub, The Foundry, invited me to a free holiday event this evening, featuring several brewed for the occasion small casks, and when those ran out, a selection of their bottled stuff, resulting in the appearance of several sixers of the aforementioned Eisbock. What can I say. Same old shitkicker! Here I copy a BA review, as most reviewers of this brew appear to be as inebriated as myself... "Aroma of sweet, rich malt, dark dried fruit, hints of brown bread. Flavor follows aroma, with rich sweet malt, dark dried fruit, hints of molasses and brown bread. Classic bock flavors, but a little more intense. Medium bodied with light creaminess. A nice, classic eisbock, providing great bock flavors intensified by the ice process, well balanced between fruit and malt flavors. Alcohol is well covered and this can be a sneaky beer since is it slightly sweet and full of flavor, it is hard to sip slowly. Nicely done." Yeah, down the hatch. Lots of lovelies at the drinkathon free event...
Pours a copper color with a malt aroma. Taste is dark malt mixed with a European hops flavor. Minor sweetness of caramel and a slight bitter aftertaste.

The follow-up to Reichelbr√§u Eisbock and in that sense the ¬íprototype¬í of the Eisbock style in more than one way. I¬íve been pondering about this German classic for years and finally found a bottle to rate it. Thick, dense, creamy, pale beige head over a very dark purple brown beer, still translucent though. Very purely malty aroma of dry cookies, caramel candy, damp cloth, brownies, hint of tea, toasted brown bread, dried banana, chestnuts, butterscotch, leather, quite a lot of iron but coming across as quite natural still. Condensed sweet onset, candied dates, dried banana and hints of candied cherry, ¬ídeep¬í and subtle sourishness balancing this sweetness, soft carbo, very caramelly middle with nutty and chocolatey accents, smooth and lightly oily, fairly thick mouthfeel, fruit sweetness carrying on over this thick caramel sweetness, light bittering in the end, a little bit toasted with soft, ¬ístructural¬í herbal and earthy hop touch; somewhat liqueurish and gin-like alcohol warmth is there from the middle and heats the throat a bit without becoming astringent - or even without decreasing the surprisingly high ¬ídrinkability¬í of this beer seen its ABV. Not very complicated but very well crafted, an old European classic which inspired many others and a must for maltheads. I did like Schneider¬ís take on this style a bit more for being richer, but this one sure demands respect.

Tap at Station House, Forest Hills, Queens. Pours dark amber, almost black. thin off-white head. Aroma is cherry, dark fruit, malt, fig, plum. Flavor is plums, cherries, dark fruits. Not too boozy for how big it is. Solid. Good beer on a chilly day.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Priv√©es Bi√®ropholie au co√ªt de 6,95$. Ar√¥me: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe de petits fruits. Apparence: La couleur est brune-noire avec une faible densit√© de bulle. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col beige mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de caramel avec une pointe de c√©r√©ales et de fruit√©e. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. L√©g√®re pr√©sence de caramel en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #6567)
Pours dark Crimson with a light brown lacing. Smell is roasted fruit. Very smooth easy drinking beer. Taste some banana and fig. Finish shows a bit of alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2015 0,33 l Longneck-Flasche aus einem lokalen Getr√§nkemarkt. Sehr dunkles, tr√ºbes, √∂liges Bier mit einer kleinen, br√§unlichen, feinporigen Schaumkrone. Riecht nach Pflaumen, Schwarzen Beeren. Im Geschmack eine leichte Trockenpflaumen-S√º√üe, dann Anfl√ºge von Karamell, Kaffee und R√∂staromen. Die 9,2 Prozent schmeckt man nicht, f√ºhlt sie aber nach dem zweiten Schluck. Wow, das knallt!

Aroma is sweet hints of banana. Black beer small head. Taste is light bitterness medium sweetness. Moderate alcohol. Finish is smooth ligh/medium finish. Body is medium. Low carbs. Would be goodnbut the pushing alcohol lowers points in all areas.
Bottle from saveur biere, france. Almost black color, tanned head. Aroma has sweet sugar notes, malty, hint of alcohol. Quite smooth palate, sweet malty notes, some licorice.

Bottle from Wine Warehouse. My first eisbock! Let¬ís see how this goes.

Pours brown with a frothy tan head. Aromas of caramel, plum and other dark fruit, possibly rum or something that reminds me of a most Christmas rum fruitcake.

Taste is a bittersweet combination of plum, caramel, fruitcake, nuts, metal, sugar. Finishes more sweet than bitter.

Very interesting. Nice first impression.

Good fruity aromas of ripe plums. Sparse foam, but it is also a strong Eisbock with its 9.2% as high foam. The taste is malty and sweet, mellow and warming. Only slightly hop bitterness at the end keeps the whole in place for a long time. It is a really nice and really tasty bock.

Des reflets rouge√¢tres se distinguent √† contre jour au travers un liquide tr√®s fonc√©. Un mince voile inerte le recouvre. Un nez d¬íalcool, de raisins secs et de pruneaux s√©ch√©s. Une amertume et un aspect acidul√©, m√™l√©s √† des saveurs de fruits secs dans une texture des plus soyeuses qui offre de belles caresses au palais. (Date 21.10.15 ) (1533-010815)

Courtesy of Jaghana
Couleur brune sombre, aucune mousse. Nez fruits noir, orge, caramel, note quetsches un peu vertes. Gout caramel sucr√©, note fruits noirs, alcool, chocolat. Corps assez moyen pour une eisbock. Fin caramel cuit.

Bottle 33cl, a brown beer with huge head. Nose is on toasted barley and toasted caramel. Aroma is on blond caramel, toffee, plum, metallic hints, vinous, chocolate hints, alcohol and cooked barley, toasted caramel. Good body, not bad but less pleasant than expected.

Bottle. Aroma of biscuit caramel malts and dark fruit. Pours dark brown. Very sweet taste, metallic. Heavy body, high carbonation, alcohol very present in finish that is somewhat sticky. Pretty good eisbock.
Bread, dough, raisin, raisin, roasty, cereal, caramel, dried fruits, leaves, earthy, woody

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2015 Rossa molto scura, praticamente nera, con riflessi color rubino, schiuma beige poco persistente.
Aroma tostato abbastanza volatile (crosta di pane), successivamente molto presenti esteri fruttati di frutti scuri (prevalentemente prugna e uva passa) e caramello.
Al palato d√† il meglio di s√©: parte fruttata (sempre prugna) e vinosa, successivamente si presentano note di cacao che virano verso caff√® tostato e zucchero caramellato, coda amaricante erbacea molto elegante.
L'alcol accompagna tutta la bevuta ma non √® mai troppo "presente".
Retrolfatto fruttato.
Corpo pieno, mediamente carbonata ma risulta comunque armoniosa.
Decisamente buona, da provare.

My first eisbock. This was not bad at all. Reminded me a little of a lesser St. Bernardus 12 with a grape gum and slight metallic flavor. It got better as it warmed up losing the metallic tinge. This was easy enough to drink but nothing blew my mind. I would not bother buying this when I can get an Aventius Dopplebock instead.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a white head that dissipates to a thin ring. Aromas of sweet malt, raisin and bread. Flavors are raisin, brown sugar, dark fruit and bready notes. Surprisingly light on the palate. Substantial alcohol warmth with an herbal hop finish. This is really a very nice beer. Hats off to Germany.

11.2 oz single bottle from Molly¬ís Spirits. Deep, dark brown appearance with a big light brown head. Aroma of dark malts, fruity esters, candy sugar, caramel, chocolate, toffee and alcohol. Similar flavor, malty, fruity and pretty sweet. Full body with soft carbonation and a syrupy feel. OK. Only my second ever Eisbock rating. Pairing: Phish - It¬ís Ice, from April 8, 1994
Dark, almost black with an off-white head. A slightly boozy, sweet aroma. Sweet flavor, a little fruit, hint of chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. Pretty nice.

Pours darkest black and very dense. Almost no head.
Aroma is intense: candy, liquorice, strawberry and violet.
Taste is sweetish, silky and thick. Very powerful, good sourness and restrained bitterness. Long finish.

Bottle from the Malt Shoppe in Tosa. Pours a tannish brown with almost no head. Aroma has sweet malts, some peat, some fruits. Later in the glass, some grainy-ness and some lemon show through. Taste is of sweet caramel - overlayered - with tangy wheat and stone fruits, berries, and a touch of lemon. Medium bodied but complex. With alcohol. Finishes thickly sweet and tangy, with some length. Not the best bock had, and the complexity was not a plus. 13.6

0,33l bottle from drinks-of-the-world.de, best before 21/10/2015. Clear, dark ruby with a thin, soapy, slowly collapsing, tan head. Pleasant, sweetish-malty aroma of prunes, raisins, treacle and cane sugar. Sweetish-malty taste of prunes, raisins, treacle and cane sugar, followed by notes of nuts and dark chocolate. Short, a little alcoholic and warming finish. Full body, oily mouthfeel, very soft carbonation. This one is a little disappointing considering its high score. Of course, it is relatively aromatic and tasty, but it is far off from Schneider¬ís Aventinus Eisbock. A bit like a concentrated doppelbock but that does not garantuee excitement.

Bottle.

A: Near black, opaque body, light creme color head, lacing.

N: Raisin, prune, toffee, some black licorice, biscuit, touch of honey, vanilla. Plenty of sweet fig, and some marshmallow.

T: Very sweet but not cloying.

M: Medium body, prickly carbonation, alcohol is hidden.

O: Tasty Eisbock. Lots of dark fruit flavors.
Sugar cane and dark berries with hints of alcohol. Small traces of coffee beans. Excellent
Bread, caramel, and a bit of that distinct German beer flavor that I don¬ít know how else to describe. Taste isn¬ít boozy, but the alcohol warming sensation comes after every sip. Good beer.

12 oz bottle, poured into a snifter at ~45 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours a deep hickory brown, shaded vaguely with red tones, and forms a thick very pale off-white head with good retention. Lacing is decent.

Smell: Deliciously malty, dark yeasty bread and lightly roasted grains.

Taste: Thick, warm, yeasty dark bread of several different types - rye, pumpernickel, pretzel, pandoro - fills the mouth, suffused with swirls in the loaf of a mixture of caramel and toffee. Towards the finish, a syrupy sweetness comes through beneath the bread, as if there were a toffee tree that could give forth toffee syrup.

Mouthfeel: Full and creamy, though not quite as much as other eisbocks I have had.

Overall: As with most eisbocks I try, this is a joy to partake in. It has less dark fruit aspects than some of the others, but more bready malt aspects. I¬ím a fan.

Always an interesting beer, which in its day was a powerful beer. Now it seems to fall in the middle of the pack. Strong malty and alcohol aroma. Dark brown molasses color. Medium body. Burnt sugar and alcohol flavor.

Clear cola brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma is dry fruits, caramel, sweet malt, prunes stand out more than anything. Taste is medium sweet and bitter. Quite balanced. Bitter finish, oily texture. Nice.

Cerveza de color marr√≥n rojizo con una peque√±a cabeza de color marr√≥n.
Aroma a malta tostada, caramelo y alcohol.
Sabor dulce a malta caramelo, con notas de ciruelas y alcohol, final seco. cerveza buena y agradable.

Appearance: pours with a medium to large tan head that dissipates quickly, the beer is very dark maroon color that looks black when not held up to a bright light 
Aroma: maple syrup, light alcohol, faint dark roasted malt
Taste: caramel, maple syrup, pretty sweet, small hop bitterness on the finish, alcohol warmth
Palate: very thick mouthfeel, average carbonation, alcohol aftertaste 
Overall: a very malt forward beer with lots of alcohol, sweet and warm, like a Scottish beer


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.

A- Raisins, dark fruits, caramel, alcohol.

A- Deep ruby color, clear dark liquid liquid, light brown head.

T- Raisins, dark fruits, caramel, spices, boozy.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, strong finish.

O- Wow, this was a lot stronger than I expected. My first Eisbock as well. Tons and tons of raisins on the nose and palate. Not sure I liked it extremely well, but it was a solid beer. Very concentrated taste too. I almost want to dilute this with water.

On tap @Buskers Pub (Rome). Brown with ruby reflections, little beige foam. Aroma of malt, caramel, brown sugar, candy, alcohol, powerful. Flavour is very sweet, caramel, toffee, bron sugar again, alcohol. Full body, medium carbonation. Not my cup of tea, but nice.

Pours dark burnt copper from bottle with thin persistent off white head. Malty aroma with hints of raisin and alcohol. Deep malty complex flavor with notes of burnt raisins, toast, plum, and chocolate. Alcohol is present but not overwhelming, and serves to balance malt in the relative absence of hoppy bitterness Full body with light carbonation. Overall amazing beer, a rare entity that tastes like dessert in a bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A good Eisbock with rich aromas of malt and chocolate. One of the better bock beers however not something I can drink on a regular basis.

12oz bottle, shared with friend, poured into tulip glass

Aroma: big malty aroma, much like dobblebock, sugar, caramel, syrup

Appearance: Dark, very dark, near black

Taste: Lots of malty goodness, heavy sweet

Palate: full body, sticky texture

Overall: A very good Bock. You can really feel the 9.2% ABV, but it works very well here. Found a few bottles covered in dust under the bottom shelf of local bottle shop. Was unsure exactly how old, but this bottle tasted great.
Brandy-like aroma when poured into a snifter. Nice eisbock flavor. A little watery but it doesnt burn. Nice.

Had on tap at farmhouse tap and grill Burlington, by. My after dinner dessert, pours deep Amber, frothy off white head. Big plum, caramel, generally sweet. Slight booze burn. Full body. Glad I got a half pour. I am ready for bed.

25.12.2013. Tuoksussa mallasta, hedelmi√§. Maku maltainen, makea, mausteinen, yrttinen, loppu my√∂s l√§mmitt√§√§. My√∂s karamellia ja tietynlaista pehmeytt√§. Maukas ja aika tasapainoinen, mutta my√∂s melko makea.
Clear dark beer with beige head. Sweet, malty and hoppy. Couldn¬ít session it but it¬ís very good.

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark brown, reddish beer with a small off white head on top. Aroma is very, very malty, loads of sugary stuff, molasses, caramel, boozy characters and even some woody notes in there. Flavor is very sweet, loads of sugar and booze, as to be expected. A very syrupy mouthfeel, sligtly sticky, silky and almost no carbonation going on. The sweetness is mostly boozy, sugar and dark fruits, but all very well balanced and nice. The alcohol is there, but certainly not disturbing at all. Very nice stuff indeed!
0.33l bottle. Black body, thin white head. Aroma of caramel, plums and toast. Taste of chocolate, caramel, plums and reisis. Medium body, warming alcohol. Very nice.

2/7/15 notes: bottle, age unknown. Initial pour is woodsy brown with a surprisingly thick and creamy head. Aroma is sherry, charred oak, nougat, and a bit of quality Stollen. Flavor is malty and caramelized, but not overly so. Lots of Medjool and dried dark cherry, and the subdued earthy dark malts to prevent heavy sweetness. All in all, a surprisingly well balanced brew that reminds me of Celebrator with its rounded maltiness.

Pretty ruby red color when held up to the light with a thin, whispy head. Sweet dark caramel nose. Lots of dark sweetness, like prunes, dried fruit, and rum raisens. Almost nutmeg spice to it. Alcohol is a stong undercurrent, but not the dominent sensation
Clear dark ruby, thick lacing light brown foam head. Heavy caramel aroma with barley and nutty tones. Strong alcohol presence, light caramel taste, a good bock. (Houston 201501)
Chocolate and vanilla. Long taste, with a warming finish. Great beer, very special.
Dark brown pour. Aroma of strong sweet dates and chocolate. Rich malts with bubbles. Finished with candied taste that lingers
bottle. very deep brown with minimal head. very malty with dark fruit and molasses. moderate booze. interesting, but unexceptional.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 Draft at Monks and then again in a bottle at Bierstube. Clear dark brown pour. Minimal head. Refined Eisbock. Dark caramel malts. Complex aroma of marzipan and dark fruit. Taste brings in some chocolate liquorice flavors as well. Chestnuts. Bing cherries. Prunes and dates. The 9.2% ABV is well hidden. Delicate finish. Body ultimately feels a bit thin, but still quite extraordinary. UPDATE: December 2014. Trying the bottle and draft next to each other. Both are great. Most remarkable difference is that while the draft brings in more common rich fig, date and raisin flavors - the bottle clearly has more unique notes of dried blackberries and blueberries. Bottle is better. This has easily become my favorite Eisbock.

Pours dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma has notes of roasty malts, raisins, figs, and brown sugar. Flavor follows suit...sweet and fruity and adds some mild earthy bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is sweet and malty and warming.

Draft from Hay Merchant in Houston. Pours a dark brown hue
with a full tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, caramel and molasses. Taste of sweet, malty and nicely rounded with dark fruit, caramel, raisins, brown sugar, molasses and light toffee. Medium to full body with light carbonation, and a sweet heated finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottle from saveur-biere.com
Dark brown body, with a small, creamy, dark beige head.
Aroma of dried fruits, cherries, marzipan, nuts, caramel, alcohol.
Taste follows this pretty much, but less intense and not very complex.
Mouthfeel is full, creamy, with a medium carbonation and it finishes with a long-lasting alcohol warmth, astringent, but only with slight, sweet aromas.

Slightly one-dimensional, but with pleasant, intense dark fruits and sweet malts, although I didn¬ít enjoy the taste and finish as much as the nose. Overall good, but I was expecting a bit more, not on par with the Schneider Weisse Eisbock in my opinion.

Bottle, 01/11/14. Pours black with an auburn tinge, medium beige head. Aroma is chocolatey, liquorice - a lot of it. Dark malts. Sweetish salty liquorice. Taste is liquorice, some roast, dark malty bread. Full with medium carbonation.
Draft->snifter. Dark red-brown with moderate tan head. Sweet dark fruit, molasses, toffee. Dark and tasty. A real standout.

what it lacks in complexity, it makes up for in sweetness and alcohol content. not a particularly well balanced beer, but the style doesn¬ít call for that. glad i tried it a couple times, but i probably won¬ít be back for more."

Poured from bottle to glass. Reddish dark brown hue with tan head that dissipated to a ring. Aroma is plum, fig, caramel, ethanol. Mouthfeel is nice with medium body and zesty carbonation. Taste is sweet throughout with an ethanol finish. Overall this is a decent brew.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish brown with a tan head. Taste dark fruit, caramel, malty. I thought this was ok. I could drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 5/23/2012. Pours crystal clear dark reddish brown color with a 2 finger dense khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big caramel, toffee, molasses, toast, brown bread, cherry, raisin, prune, fig, light chocolate, and toast/yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and dark fruit notes; with great strength. Taste of big caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, brown bread, raisin, cherry, plum, fig, light chocolate, and toast/yeast earthiness. Minimal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, brown bread, raisin, cherry, plum, fig, light chocolate, and toast/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt and dark fruit flavors; with a great malt/fruitiness balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a smooth and fairly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent eisbock style. All around great complexity and balance of dark/bready malt and dark fruit flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Poured from bottle into a snifter
 Appearance ¬ñ The beer pours a super deep mahogany color that is bordering on black. Upon pouring there is a small tan colored head that fades over about a two minute time frame to leave a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass and some foam islands on the surface of the brew.
 Smell ¬ñ The aroma is huge of a dark fruit smell with tons of dark cherry, plum, fig, and grape. Along with these dark fruit and sweet smells are some of sweet smells of molasses. A good showing of roasted malt and toasted grain as well as a very strong booziness being there as well producing a quite dark and robust aroma overall.
 Taste ¬ñ The taste begins with a thick and sweet dark fruit flavor of cherry, plum, and prune. The sweeter fruit, which create a heavy base flavor for the brew, are also joined by some tastes of caramel and molasses. There is a good showing of a roasted malt flavor upfront which ends up getting slightly stronger as the taste moves to the end. As the taste moves beyond the middle of the profile, a little bit of an herbal and earthy flavor joins the tongue, but these remain relatively light throughout. Some toasted grainy flavors come more toward the end of the taste and are joined by some flavors of cocoa and even more molasses. With a light rummy boozed flavor coming to the tongue at the very end, one is left with a super dark and sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel ¬ñ The body of the beer is very thick and chewy with a very light level of carbonation. For the style and the big sweet and dark flavors of the brew the feel is spot on, making for one enjoyable slow sipper.
 Overall ¬ñ This is a very nice Eisbock with tons of sweetness and a good roastedness. A rather tasty and big sweet brew.

Wow, tastes a lot like Troeganator which is a dopplebock and made me fall in love with craft beer. I know this is an eisbock, but they¬íre relatively similar. Dark fruit flavors abound, smooth alcohol flavor. I love it. Sweet, malty, dark.

12oz bottle shared, poured a medium brown color with off white head. Aroma is sweet malt, almost nutty and fruit but just sweet. Flavor is sweet malt hints of chocolate malt. Fantastic flavor start to finish.
Dark brown pour with a small tan head. Aroma of raisins, brown sugar, and sweet malts. Flavor is similar. Sweet and delicious. Slightly warming from the abv but not overwhelming. Solid.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, caramel and molasses. Flavor was sweet, malty and nicely rounded with dark fruit, caramel, raisins, brown sugar, molasses and light toffee. Medium-full body, low carbonation, sweet warming finish.

In short: strong caramel beer
Pours dark brown with almost not foam, malty aroma and caramel taste, very drinkable for its alcoholic content.
Pours black with carbonation. Has a strong prune and dark fruit aroma. Taste is very strong with dark fruits (mostly prune), raisins, caramel, malts, and some spices. A very complex and strong taste.

Sweet grainy malty aroma with a good deal of dark fruit. Pours very dark mahogany with an off white head that fades fairly quickly leaving faint residue on the glass. Sticky sweet. Malty. Fig, prune. Nicely boozy. Clean with a fairly thick mouthfeel. This is a really nice beer.
Oily rich. Spicy and fruity. Warming. Very Christmasy. I quite like Eisbook actually. I like the fact the alcohol isn¬ít hidden. I should drink more of this style.. in December.

Great eisbock, exactly as it should be: dark, strong, full-bodied without being heavy, rich, even complex. Notes to plums, raisins, marzipan, cake and liquor. Excellent with a dessert or a cigar; extraordinary by itself.

Tap @ Biermuseum Koln, large sample. Clear dark brown color with a reddish glow, short head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, molasses, caramel malt, hint of alcohol. Bit sweet, bit bitter. Nicely balanced and good complexity. Lovely classic german eisbock indeed.

Black bodied and small head. Thick brown sugar, bit if roast perhaps but mostly a concentrated liquorice sweetness. Taste is as expected from there on. Very sticky ending. For the abv it isn?t even too much, but generally speaking it?s sticky, sweet, alcohol and rich. It?s the style, but I?m not a real fan. (33cl bottle from Saveur Bi√®re)

My first eisbock! Pours dark with a thin large-bubbled lingering head. Appearance is oily like a red wine.
Aroma: booze, along with licorice with some banana and vanilla.
Taste: is that chinotto? Quinine? Booziness like a rum and coke. Vanilla and cherries. No hops noticeable.
Oily mouthfeel with lingering boozy aftertaste that¬ís almost chewy.
Slightly boozier than I prefer, but intriguing and quite tasty. Recommended.

Review according to BJCP 2008 guidelines (style 5D).
AROMA: strong malt aroma with some notes of dried plum and alcohol.
APPEARANCE: dark brown with average retention due to high alcohol content. ivory colored head.
TASTE: very rich sweet malt flavour with notes of dried grapes. smooth alcohol presence with a finish of malt and alcohol.
PALATE: full smooth body with a bit of alcohol warmth. medium-low carbonation.
OVERALL: a very strong, full and enjoyable Eisbock. Recommended.
Very nice. Tarnished copper pour with minimal head. Aroma is sweet malt and fruit. Very clean. Taste is sweet malt and very little bitter. I like.
Deep murky brown. Banana, prune and metallic taste. Some fizz. Short end with some sap. Not bad.
Quite nice a warmer with a high alcohol content but not that noticeable. Ok maltiness.

Bottle. Pours murky copper brown with airy light beige head. Clear aroma of malt, fruit, and booze. Sweet, malty and fruity flavour, with a distinct alcohol presence. Shot-lived aftertaste but still OK for a decent Eisbock.

1" off white frothy head that dissipates quickly, low lacing. Clear deep dark ruby liquid. Aroma of malt, alcohol at first sniffs and after good swirl. Strongly sweet malt taste and low bitter, a small metallic taste detected on first gulp. Silky moderate thick body and warmth. Carbonation had some bite on tongue. Moderate dry astringency and sticky finish. Great strong beer example of the style but a bit much on the sweet side for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottle onboard of Tallink Superstar, on Baltic Sea. This beer was only 2.90 EUR, the cheapest option available. Poured dark brown with a small head, looking solid. Aroma feels like smelling brown sugar candy - it has a strong malt base and a lot of sweetness. It has pretty high alcohol but it doesn¬ít come out in the aroma. Taste is actually quite smooth, dark fruits, that same caramelized brown sugar candy. Aftertaste has some plums, molasses and no rough edges. Nice and warming winter beer.
On hyv√§ tumma lager. Teemukista ihan mainiota t√§m√§yst√§. Hiilihapokas, sopivasti. Aika paljon my√∂s viinaa.

Pours a deep brown/amber with a short tan head and lacing. It has an aroma of dark fruit (plum, some apple) and malt with a similar flavor profile that is malt and plum up front with a semisweet, syrupy finish over a medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had it on tap at gustav's in Oregon. Fantastic, dark, powerful, flavorful, a new favorite of mine

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Smell of syrup, caramelized sugar. Dark copper colour with a twist of red, plentiful mid-brown head. Looks like a trappist. Aroma of cough mixture, cognac, sugar, syrup. Slightly burning alcohol sensation. Sweet with medium bitterness on the side. Medium carbon.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown/ruby; clear; tan head. A local beer to look at. Aroma is quite inviting as well. Bread and plums. Molasses, brown sugar, some vinous qualities; a trace of faded hops. Jam and berries. If this is what eisbocks have to offer, I¬ím going to have to track more of these down. Taste: sweet but not cloying. Some chocolate covered berries. Surprisingly little alcohol showing here. Layers of complex malt flavors, finishes somewhat dry. Full body, slick texture. More alcohol coming through as this warms -- eisbock is supposed to be consumed ice-cold, right? Becomes a little harsher along with that, but stays nice throughout.
R√∂tlichbraunes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig s√º√ü, fruchtig, alkoholisch. Geschmack sehr s√º√ü, malzig fruchtig, den Alkohol merkt man deutlich.

.33l bottle @ Vihre√§ Haltiatar 
Pours dark clear reddish, low head. Aroma is dark malts, syrup and brown sugar. Dark bread. Flavor is mostly same. Nice beer!
Botella 33cl en CerveZeres. Cerveza oscura de espuma ligera, mucho cuerpo y un sabor tostado y amargo. No decepciona en absoluto

Pours a deep dark brownish mahogany color with tan head. Lots of dark fruit character, plums, raisins, grape, sweet malts notes, and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is roasty initially followed by big warming alcohol sensation. More dark fruit character comes through after, not overly sweet. More warming sensation even after a couple sips. Pretty good boost juice.
12 oz bottle pours brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of caramel, raisin, and spice. Taste is sweet malts, dried fruit and toffee.

Harsh syrup. Though, if I was to homebrew then freeze off the water, I would expect something along these lines. Pretty much what you would expect from a concentrated bock. Solid bock, though not great, and I¬ím all for alcohol, but it doesn¬ít make this taste any better.

Aroma: dark ripe fruits, caramel malts, intense sweetness. Appearance: very dark brown/black, small white head. Taste: heavy sweet. Palate: ripe plum, raisins, sweets continue heavily, complex flavour, medium carbonation. Overall: very nice Eisbock, not as refined as the Aventinus though, but still very good. Bottle from Kris Wines, London.

Bottle 33 cl. Black brown color with brown whitish fast vanishing head. Notes of some chocolate, earthy, raisins, bread, alcohol, malty, red fruits. Alcohol abit too much present. Not too bad. The alcohol and taste gets smoother after a while.

The quest for 5 continues. Draft at gingerman. Pours deep reddish brown with nice head. Nose of dark fruits and sugar. Tastes quite boozy and of raisins, caramel, cherries, molasses, and red licorice. Bitter finish. Slightly odd aftertaste.

On tap at Ginger Man on NYC. My first eisbock and I am a fan. Malt and raisin are prominent in the nose. Sweet dark ripe fruit dominant the taste. Body is medium and carbo is soft. Nice beer of you are into these flavors.
It is defenately too sweet for me however the colour looks nice and i like the vanilla smell

Pours into snifter looking a lot like a Coke, including carbonation and quickly receding head. Nose is mostly malt with a touch of brown sugar. Tate is sweet - definitely get raisins and brown sugar, followed by the alcohol which I didn't find to be as well hidden as others. Only my second eisbock, and I liked the other more. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very malty, very nutty, very strong taste. High alcohol-% well hidden! Very tasteful.

Pours a deep ruby color into snifter. Faints smells of raisins and a complex malt profile. The robust flavor shines more with raisins, plums, licorice, and intense toffee. Very sweet and malty. No doubt a hint of smoke in the finish. Oily and slightly dry in the finish as well. Exceptional Winter warmer. Not as complex in the nose which is where I deducted some points.

Very nice. Aroma of raisin, dark plum and a twinge of smokiness. Low carbonation, normal for style. Pours dark brown without much head or lacing. Finishes with light sweetness and a light touch of bitterness from booze. Bottle.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits
Appearance - Deep ruby body, soft bubbles
Aroma - Dank hops, brown sugar, molasses, toffee
Taste - Red licorice, molasses, caramel, bitter hops

This was a very smooth brew with tons of bold flavor in an oily body. I could drink this all day, but not get too far given the abv - cheers!!!

delicious rich heavy n thick chocolate, toast, roasty, vanilla, brown, sweet and malty , not much head , great aroma of roast nuts and sweet hickory , sweet tasting and a smooth palate , overall a great drinker

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Very dark brown beer with reddish hues and no head. Aroma of rich malts and toffee. Taste is figs, dark fruits, pontefract cake and rich syrupy malts. Medium bodied, quite sticky and low carbonation. Decent, but a let down on what I was hoping for.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: On tap at RIBCO, pours a clear dark amber brown with an off white head, the aroma was super sweet with syrup and caramel and malt, too sweet for my liking in this style, the flavor was much of the same with dark fruits and tons of sweet caramel and malt, booze was evident in every sip, not my cup of tea.

Draft. WOW. Nose full of raisins and pure sweetness. Sticky sweet. This is amazing. No oxidation or sherry noted like past bottles. My lips are sticky after sipping this beer. No real alcohol noted. Will feel it later. A true malt bomb. Could have some more complexity, but otherwise awesome.

Review from notes 7/7/10
Poured from 33cl bottle purchased at Jim¬ís Homebrew in Spokane, WA ($4) into Sam Adam¬ís glass.

A: Dark ruby brown with thin lace at rim. Central dome of dissipating bubbles.

S: Strong and sweet grain, bread, toast, nut. These all combine and form a graham cracker scent. Nice.

T: Nice. Figs, cherry, deep roasted coffee. Hint of spice, resin. Toasty finish, like a good dessert.

M: Creamy medium body with low carbonation allows beer to flow strait back to throat with ease or to rest on tongue. 

D: Excellent craftsmanship. Enjoyable experience. Nice how the flavor and body changes with amount of time in mouth. Transitions from the initial sweetness to resonate into the more complex nuances of hops and grain.

Serving type: bottle

12-22-2010

33 cl bottle. Dark red-brown beer with a small brown head which disappears quite quickly. The aroma is roasty with hints of mahogany and syrup. The flavor is sweet with lots of caramel and syrup. Gets better in the glass and has lots of strength.

Very Dark Brown, Almost Black, Big Foamy Had That Lasts But Leaves Almost No Lacing. Sweet Malt, Slight Alcohol Aroma. Malt, Sweet, Dark Fruits, Boozy Finish. Medium Body. Although It Hides High ABV better than others, it still shines more than I like. Pretty Easy to Drink. Pretty Good Although It Is Not That Special. Worth A Try...
Aroma is of alcohol and malted barley and grain. Flavors of licorice, plums, and sour raspberries. No head and low csrbonation. Finish is of alcohol and even some banana.

Warming and vivacious, this beer begs to be entertained and enjoyed. Spicy and seductive; hints of black bread, pecans, and soy with which figs, brown sugar, sorghum molasses, German yeast, and dark chocolate came along for the ride. Keyword here: rich. Downright chewy and hefty.

Pourss a very dark mahogany with a foam that settles down as a ring along the edge of the glass. Nose has dark malts, rye, raisin and some caramel. Taste is malty sweet with a mild alcoholic bitterness in the finish. Carbonation is lively, lots of bubbles keep forming in the mouth. Palate is quite rich. Alcohol is well hidden but this will warm you up nicely.

Malty, vegetal, herbal, licorice, SOY SAUCE, a spike of iodine. Very reminiscent of chewy herbal licorice and soy sauce. A bit too sweet and stylized for me...but extremely interesting and worth trying.

very dark reddish mahogany colour, minimal beige head; aroma of caramel, dried fruits (mainly figs and raisin), maybe some alcohol, taste is dominated by malty sweetness with caramel again and dried fruits, in addition, herbal liqueur-like notes can also be felt

Bottled. Really dark ruby/brown color, thin creamy head. Loads of bready malt aromas, grains, raisins and fruity alcohol notes. Dark sugary notes and a hint of nuttiness. Surprisingly, it is not too sugary. It is sweet, of course, but too bad. Nice malty flavor with some alcohol warmth. Medium body, slick texture. Low carbonation. Nice sipper.

Bottle, 33cl - Hazy dark red brown beer with a small beige head. Aroma is malt. With notes of caramel, spices, alcohol and phenols. Flavor is malty with notes of dried fruit, raisins, spices, prunes and caramel. Wow, really great once it ages.

300 ml. draft in a dimple mug @ Biermuseum. Ruby dark brown with a creamy tanned head. Nose is sweet & rich in a lager way & feel with sweet dark fruits, chocolate, syrup, caramel. Taste is same rich feeling of syrup, dark fruits, brown sugar, chocolate, faint berries. Very rich & thick. Every bit as good as I hoped that it would be, excellent brew.
Bottle: Dark brown color, off-white head. Aroma of malt, roasted malt, molasse, sweets. Flavor is malty, sweet harmonic with toffee and molasse notes.

Pours very dark, end of the SRM scale. Not much of a head. Aroma is definitely malty-sweetness, caramel. On initial taste, very cold temp attributed to med-high spikey carbonation feel in the mouth. As I let it warm to room temp, the carb dropped and viscosity became thicker. Left very little lace. Hops are absent on aroma and taste. High alcohol in taste and afterwards, left a very warming effect. I don¬ít drink a lot of Eisbocks but this one will be worth another purchase in the future. One in a session is good enough based on the high ABV.

Not much of aroma, just faintly ... grainy.
Flavor has some maltiness, actually pleasant. Bready, little sweet.
A bit too carbonated.
0,33l bottle from the flagship Alko. Pours dark red with a low head. Aroma is malts, chocolate and alcohol. Flavor is malts, dark fruits, chocolate and alcohol. Not bad.

Dark and syrupy, sweet but strong. Dark brown/ruby with spare beige head. No taste of alcohol, but plenty of warmth. Dried fruit aroma with a tinge of molasses, taste is mostly sweet with some roast grains to round it out. Beautifully done.
bottle 33cl from alko @ home. pours clear very dark brown with a small head. sweet malty bread aroma, some cocoa bitterness, licorice. Malty, sweet flavor with a slight alcohol kick in the end.
Bottle 0.33l at home. Originally rated 02102011. Colour is dark brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Sweetness, caramel and malts.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with off white head. Lacing on sides of glass. Strong bready sweet aroma. Some caramel, toasted notes. Taste is sweet malty goodness. Caramel, toffee, biscuits and a hint of cherry. Barely any detectable bitterness. Medium to full bodied with a sweet sticky mouthfeel. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A dark brown beer with a medium and blond head. The nose is quite sweet and strongly malty, dark and dried fruits, some berries, also hint of dark bread. Taste is rich of malts, not very sweet, dark bread and some fruits. Almost full bodied, nice and lightnening carbonation. Quite nice, but slightly too simple.
On tap at Alewife in Baltimore. Pours a dark amber with minimal head. Aroma is sweet malt and some fruit. Flavor is sweet and fruity. Meet nice beer.

Bottle. Dark amber/black colour. Small head.
Aroma: Big on malt,dark bread, dried fruits, raisin, plum, hint of banana.
Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel.
Taste: Bread, sweetness, dark fruits, rum, alcohol.
Short, sweet finish with warming alcohol.

Flasche (33 cl). - Schwarzbraun mit r√∂tlichem Schimmer. In der Nase schwere S√º√üe, Rosinen, Lik√∂r. Auch im Antrunk sehr schwere R√∂stmalzs√º√üe, die aber durch holzige Herbe und kr√§ftige Hopfenbittere ausgeglichen wird. Noten von Bitterschokolade, Lakritz, Vollkornbrot, Rumtopf und Rohrzucker. - Ein konzentrierter Doppelbock, von St√§rke wie von Aromaf√ºlle her das unterg√§rige Gegenst√ºck zu den belgischen Trappistenbieren.
