UPDATED: NOV 21, 2013 Dark brown, almost black, little reddish against the light. Big soapy off-white head which dissolves quick leaving a ring on top of the beer and lacing on the glass. Aroma has dark loafy malts, peat, vanilla, chocolate sweetness, herbs, licorice and a feel of alchohol without being boozy. Taste is malty and sugary sweet with also some salty licorice. Finishes off with alcohol warming and tasting a bit boozy with not much bitterness at all. Mouthfeel is quite full, not oily but slick with surprisingly high carbonation. A nice beer to enjoy slowly. This is my first Eisbock, but I suppose I started with the best.
Brown body, offwhite head. Aroma has lots of malt, alcohol, dark fruits. Very sweet flavour and some alcohol warmth.
191113. Bottle at home. Pours clear dark brown with a d disappearing had. Aroma malts, hint of alcohol. Slightly sweet taste. Nice aftertaste. Not Bad.

330 ml bottle. Deep dark reddish brown colour, thin tan head. Sweetish aroma of malt, dark fruits and a whiff of alcohol. The flavour is sweet and malty, with dark fruits, notes of nuts, and a warm finish. Quite tasty.
Bottle. Deep amber color with a thin off-white head. Strong aroma of raisin, syrup, dark malt and some ginger. Balanced taste with medium bitterness and warming alcohol in finish.
Brown colour, small head. Aroma: lot of malts, fresh fruits, forest berries. Taste is sweet, roasted notes. Very good brew, harmonic.
Malty with some dark fruit notes. Dark brown with a tan head. Caramel, malt and alcohol, a bit like candied rum. Wonderful in every way with a long sweet, boozy finish.

Bottle. Dark brown, clear. Very dark bready, dry cake dark syrupy, nose. Some metallic, some earthy tones. Dried figs, xmas-y clove. Full thick body, somewhat oily texture. Dark bread on the palate, dry rye. Soft, slightly sweet. Flavourful, hides the heat extremely well, at least when cooled a little. I don¬ít find it super intensive, but more like a relatively normal winter lager with really full flavour and thick body.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours cola brown in color with a tan head. Sweet dark ripe fruityness in aroma. Slightly vinous notes, ripe plums and soup of raisins in taste. Like a liquid version of a cake made of these ingredients. A bit of roastedness in the background. Leaves one with a sweet overripe dark fruity and malty sweet finish. Not the best, tasty though.

Reddish brown colour, with minimal head on top. Aroma has berries, ripe fruits mainly resin and some stingy alcohol. Taste has sweet malt body, with berries plums and after taste is liqueur-like. Quite full body and light carbonation, way too boozy for my taste.

Deep black, one finger short beige head. Sweet aroma has berries and ripe fruits, bit herbs and alcohol. Full body, tingling, oily palate because of carbonation and roasted bitterness which stays to long finish, sweet. Ok.

Pours brown with a very little, almost minimal head. Aroma has sweetish malty and also some yeasty earthy notes, it is also very spicy and has ripe fruitiness. Taste is very sweet, almost cloyingly; flavours of ripe fruitiness, raisin, berries, spices. Medium to full bodied palate; sticky. Nice dessert beer, but richness of the taste is not quite up to the high standards set by Aventinus Eisbock, for example.

Bottle from Alko. Dark brown color, beige head. Bittersweet taste with nuts, dark fruits, hops, a bit of alcohol and cookie dough. Smooth body, the high ABV is very well hidden. Bitter finish with nuts, malts and a hint of alcohol. Very nice eisbock.

A: Dark Reddish, Brownish Hue, Passes Mild Light, Off White Head, Some Lacing

S: Sweet Bread, Cherries, Plums, Mild Boozy

T: Sweet Bread, Cherry, Plum, Mild Apple

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet, Mildly Boozy

Overall, a pretty solid eisbock with great balance of fruit flavors with a mild booziness to it but nothing drastic, solid.
Topclass eisbock. Very malty, with notes of brown sugar. Really nice beer for a cold winter night.
Aroma if ginger snaps, dates, and malt. Pours deep red brown with a nice big blanket. Taste is big and sweet with toffee, candied dates, and sugar cookies. Fantastic eisbock.
330ml bottle. A real gem this was, like a strong dark Belgian, except a lager. Thumbs way up on this one.

First thought.. Awesome aroma. Served between 55-60 degrees in a snifter. Rich aromas of honey, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, raisin and fig. Mouthfeel is soft and round, with a creamy carbonation. Flavors of dark honey, dark fruit, caramel and brown sugar. Balanced sweetness. Simply a great winter warmer to end the evening. Alcohol well hidden under flavors. Lingering finish of above mentioned flavors. Wonderful balance. Awesome value. Definitely going to have a few of these around for the holidays. I have nothing bad to say about this beer. Just try it.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

33cl bottle from Ambrosetti, Berlin. Pours deep mahogany with a tan head. Malty and slightly fruity aroma with dark, dried fruits, caramel and hints of banana, roasted malt and vanilla. Sweet and caramelly with notes of dried fruits. Some resemblance to fortified wine. Full body with slightly soft carbonation. Surprisingly smooth and well balanced. Warming alcohol, but well integrated. Surprisingly easy to drink and quite delicious.
Faint aroma of sweet malt. Beautiful ebony color with huge tan head...long lasting. Strong sweet caramel with a nice burn at the end. Roasted malt is a little overstated but o.k. Nice beer.

11.2fl oz. bottle. Pours a clear dark ruby/brown with a one and a half finger, off-white head that quickly fizzes away to a thin film. You could hear it bubbling as the head faded away.
Aroma is very noticeable. Big notes of bread, chocolate, raisin and other sweet dark fruits, vanilla, and alcohol.
Taste is malt forward but balanced well. Short, slightly chocolaty/alcohol aftertaste with some mild alcohol warmth. 
Medium-full body with a low-medium carbonation. Slightly syrupy in the mouth with a mildly frothy texture.
Overall very tasty. I could see this being a great winter sipper. Would buy again for sure if it was more available in Ontario. Not to compare beers but this smells similar to the Granville Island Lions Winter Ale but with a ton more flavour. Good show!

Poured into my Bare Hands eisbock snifter. Pours a deep ruby-brown with a fairly substantial off-white head. Complex nose involves dark cherries, hearty crusty toasted bread, red wine, some malt vinegar, brown sugar, caramel, a hint of soy. Quite sweet, fairly bitter, a touch tart. Heavier, rich, toward syrupy, soft, oily, with a long warm tart and drying bitter finish. A cool brew, fun to drink, plenty to contemplate, and though it doesn¬ít seem so strong, it is.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a large snifter. 

Appearance: In the glass it looks dark brown with reddish highlights. It is topped by a small tan head that quickly fades to a light ring of foam. Lacing is minimal and very slick.

Smell: The aroma is the star of the show and offers deep inviting layers of malty goodness. I get lots of sweet roasted malt, caramel and dark fruits like plum, figs and raisin with drop of molasses and rum like alcohol.

Taste/Palate: Its flavor matches the aroma to a tee but comes off a little lighter than I had expected yet still full bodied. It brings all the wonderful layers of maltiness with a mellow warming abv. It finishes sweet but not in a heavy or cloying way and the palate is smooth and full yet still very drinkable for such a big beer. 

Notes: This is a very enjoyable beer with nice complexity.

Tap at the Biermuseum Koln 26/8/13. Ruby red / brown pour with a cream halo head. Aroma is prune, raisin, rum and some alcohol. Full bodied light carb. Hides the alcohol well. Slight warmth. Very tasty.
September 2010. From bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Sweet roasted malt aromas with caramel and dark fruit. Spicy flavors with malt and caramel. Excellent beer.

33cl bottle. Pours a thick dark brown color topped with a pillowy off-white head that lasted. The aroma is initially sweet and malty, but has some nice fruit as well as subtle roasty notes. Flavor has some kicks of warming alcohol, with a huge backbone of sweet malts accompanied by some fruit flavors. Spices are mild, but help to balance a bit. Full bodied, with moderate carbonation.
Mahogany pour with tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, sweetness, figs. Taste is smooth, creamy, roasted malt, dark fruits. Tasty beer.

Bottle that¬ís been in my cellar since March 09 - Pours dark cola with some ruby highlights and a thin, soapy light tan head. Nose is molasses and dark fruit--lots of plum, prune and raisin. Some brown sugar sweetness, but really no booziness to speak of. Taste brings in a little dark, dry bready malt up front that transitions into caramel and brown sugar-covered dark fruit. A touch of clove appears, along with some honey. Notes of tobacco and more dry dark bread on the finish. Warming but not boozy. Wow. Thick and slick, with low, gentle carbonation. This is a little sweet for my tastes these days, but man is it an experience. This would have been damn near perfect for me when I started my beer journey.

2013 bottle to a tulip glass. Spectacular dark ruby brown color with good clarity and a small tan head. Aroma is an intense, rich toasted malt with prune underneath and a little chocolate. Taste is sweet with dark malt, prune, fig and some chocolate. Alcohol taste presents as a slightly spicy burn and finishes with a vinous quality. Some bitterness in the aftertaste but is balanced among the malt and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel that is a little warming.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pours cola brown with a finger of tan head. Aroma of caramel and dark fruits. Taste is sweet caramel with a slightly bitter woody finish.

30cl on tap at the bier museum, cologne.
Thick creamy off white head. Clear deep burgundy pour. Sweet and malty. The acohol was very well hidden

Poured out of the bottle in a deep dark brown /black colour with steady creamy head and smooth body. Nose of malt and whiskey. Taste of intense malt, high alcohol, cloves, raisins, plums, torf, bourbon and chocolate. Just very nice and delicious to drink, despite its high ABV, yet nothing too spectacular at all.

Grandios fand ich ihn nicht, doch ist er derma√üen konzentriert, er wei√ü schon zu gefalken. Malzig, dick, ordentlich im Alkohol und recht hoch konzentriert. Eine fl√ºssige Bierpraline mit einem schweren Gem√ºt. H√∂chstnoten mag icgph nicht vergeben, doch bei guter K√ºhlung kann man ihn gar einfach trinken. Nicht schlecht !

Colors dark copper or pepsi with a creamy head. Aromas banana bread ester, hint of metal, caramel, toffee and sweet candied malts. Flavors musty, aged wood, banana bread, toffee and caramel. Light alcohol noticed in flavor only. Light to medium bitter finish and medium sweet. Rated while watching the x-files on a Saturday night apartment in buffalo.

Dark cola brown with ample off white head. Smells of raisin, fig, caramel, vanilla. Alcohol is very present in the taste, but has a nice sweetness with the fig flavors, caramel, vanilla, a little spice, finishes with very little bitter and maybe some grape jelly like taste. My favorite eisbock. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

big, rich malty aroma. sweet, bready, caramel nose. a touch of alcohol. clear deep dark mahogany tinted cola color. moderate off-white head. thick, viscous body. thick, heavy malt flavor. sweet and malty. not much bitterness sneaking out from under the malt. a touch of alcohol in the finish. this is eisbock.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with one-finger beige head. Head persists quite a bit, leaving a lacy coat around the glass. Initial aroma is jam packed full of fruit; berries, prunes, raisins, you name it. After letting sit for a bit, things turn more towards caramel, though the raisins remain. Taste brings the booze and more sweetness. Caramel and raisins are the prominent flavors. Sugary, though not sticky amazingly enough. The beer is well-carbonated, which lightens the texture of this one considerably. Was not expecting that at all, which for what I want, is not a good thing. Finish is boozy raisins. Lingers substantially. While this may be the original eisbock, this doesn¬ít hold a candle to Aventinus Eisbock, which I should really try again some time.
Draft from notes. Sweet and dark. A little soft on the carbonation but very enjoyable. Like drinking dark honey mixed with fermented dark fruits and a lot of warming alcohol on the finish.
Bottle from bartlebeer. Thanks Frank! - Pours dark brown with red hue. Aroma and taste of caramel and dark dried fruits. Has a dry, slightly woody finish which completes a good bitter/sweet balance.
First Eisbock I¬íve had. Very nice stuff. Not too bitter and very drinkable despite its alcohol content.

Nice looking bottle. Chilled. Wasn¬ít expecting it to pour this dark. Have to force a head, which doesn¬ít endure. Smells of liquorice and apple, old ale. Taste is syrupy sweet molasses, some dark fruits, quite sharp. OK.
Whew! 9.5% alcohol, but a very pleasant taste. They claim to be the original Eisbock creators.

Auburn pour with big tan head.  Smells bready and honeyed.  Tastes saccharin sweet but also has a significant hit of hops and well developed other flavors.  Soy sauce, roasty, wheaty,woody notes dominate a beer that finishes simulataneously sticky on the palate and dry.
Bottle: Poured mahogany with a finger tall off white head. Aroma is sweet dark malts. Taste is smooth but sweet malts with a metallic edge of alcohol.

Beer of a dark ruby hue close to black, aromatic, complex and fruity notes. Very tasty which highlights its malty character, dominated by roasted, caramel and fruit, mainly dark fruit with hints of vanilla, a mild burning at the end of the drink.

Had this on tap at the Bavarian Grill in Plano. Black in color. Smelled strongly of dark chocolate. Delicious for sipping while having appetizers but not for drinking with meal. Probably more of a desert beer. Tasted the chocolate too. Also had a taste of vanilla and caramel. Bitterness was a bit much for me. Overall good but I probably won¬ít be drinking this again. If you like dark chocolatey rich beers this one is good.

Pours a deep dark mahogany brown with a shallow head. Nose is sweet fruit, mostly raisins and figs. Taste is sweet and fruity  with some hints of vanilla. Finishes in the same fruity notes , moderate lingering, with the alcohol well hidden. quaff score 8 /10

Pours a red brown with a tan head and aroma of dried fruits and raisans. Taste is sweet, of dried fruits, raisans, caramel, roasted malt, and chocolate notes with a warming finish. First Eisbock I¬íve ever had, very good

A - Pours a dark ruby brown with an active 1.5 finger beige head that sinks quickly

S - Roasted sugary malt, prunes, raisins, molasses, peppery alcohol, toasted grain.

T - Intense malt infused with dried cherries, prunes, raisins, apples, berries, with layers of rich caramel and toffee and toasted brown bread. Aftertaste is of nutty bread.

M - Light side of full bodied due to the moderate carbonation. Just right.

This is the good stuff. Rich intense but smooth malt profile. All the flavors melded into a well-rounded brew.

Serving type: bottle

03-15-2011

Aroma: bready, rich roasted caramel, sweet malt, 
Flavor: sweet rich malt and caramel at first; finishes with burnt sugar and light molasses.
Comment: full bodied, good carbonation. Best when chilled to cut the sweetness. Carbonation also helps with the mouthfeel.

Sweet grains in the nose, lots of caramel and berry flavors. A little sour.

The appearance is dark ruby red. Good head level; thick and hazy.

The flavor is sweet maltiness; does have a completely sweet finish. Borderline cloying. Leaves an aftertaste that is drier than, say, Spaten.

The palate is thick and slick. The alcohol is not hidden at all.

Like a cough syrup but kinda thin on tongue but it smacks a wallop had at bier museum in Germany.  Okay but nothing special.  Carmel coffee syrup

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smak och doft av malt, humle, kaffe och choklad. En aning f√∂r s√∂t och alkholen sl√•r igenom.

Bottled. Dark brown colour with a beige head that quickly diminishes. Aroma is toasty and spicy. Flavor os sweet, alcoholic, malty toasty, hints of chocolate and caramel. The final has a pleasant sweetess.

330 ml bottle from Neons. Pours a deep, rich nutty amber color with a minimal off-white head. Aroma of caramel and brown sugar, sweet sugary toasted notes, like marzipan, and toffee candy. Flavor of caramel and darker toasty malts, brown sugar, sweet roasted nuts, and a bit of an old earthy, woody note. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a sweet, smooth mouthfeel. About what I expected. Seemed a little old, too, but the bartender poured it and pitched the bottle before I could see.

I poured an 11.2oz bottle into a snifter. There was no decipherable freshness date.

Appearance: Pours out a dark brown shade, but appears to be opaque black in the glass with ruby red highlights. Forms a relatively large, eggshell, foamy head which retains and laces well.

Smell: Strong alcohol presence, but distinct fruit as well. Similar to a flavored liqueur.

Taste: The eisbock is a style that¬ís hard to come by, but if you¬íre lucky enough to find one you¬íre usually in for a treat. Kulmbacher Eisbock definitely was for me as it¬ís comparable to a traditional barleywine as far as flavor goes, but with a thinner, slightly crisp body because it¬ís a lager. Dark fruits like red apple, cherry, fig and plum as well as toffee are all quite prominent. The alcohol is as well, but it¬ís not distracting and makes the beer drink like the true sipper it should be. 

It¬ís a well balanced palette all around, too. Though definitely on the sweeter, maltier side, Kulmbacher Eisbock is not a sticky, syrupy mess. There is some residual flavor on the tongue, but it is not cloying or drying, but rather just "there." The taste is quite delicious, though not what I would consider among the best of the best. Still, you¬íre in for a treat if you drink this beer.

Drinkability: For a strong beer, Kulmbacher Eisbock is no challenge to drink at all. Though the 9.2% ABV potency is noticeable in the nose and in the taste, there¬ís no raw heat or burn in the drinking process. The mouthfeel is on the thicker side for sure, but soft and slightly crisp. Probably best enjoyed as a dessert or special occasion beverage, though.

Last beer in a random tasting evening on 2 Apr 2013: 33cl bottle, best before 26 Aug 2013, poured into a Palm Special tulip at home.

I love dark, rich, sweet brews and this fits the bill nicely.

The smell is all malty molasses: with a dark alcohol laden fruit cake dropped into the brew. The taste is also sweet malty fruit cake: raisins and Victoria plums soaked in a bitter-sweet balsamic mix with some caramel and burnt butterscotch all add to make this beer more than just a uber strong Bock.

All in all, a very nice beer, strong but balanced, if a little malty and sweet.
Bottle pour -  first of this style for me.  This is a really strong version of the bock that we all love.

Bottle. Thanks to Wombata. Chocolate, yeast, and a touch of smoke in the nose. Dark brown. Mild prune and chocolate / alc. warmth, candied fruit, chocolate-covered raisins / smooth, warming finish. Medium body. Tastes like doppelbock, with less body and sweetness. Pleasant, good mild flavors. Some alc. but not a lot of punch.
From tap. Dark brown pour with a hint of red visible around the edges. Aroma of malts and molasses. Taste is the same with added chocolate, fruit, and a hop bite. Good mouthfeel.

Pours cola brown with a beautiful thick tan head. Aroma is rich molasses blended with clove and a faint wif of alcohol. Taste is awesome syrupy malts up front with a bite from the alcohol fading to a rich, earthy, malt finish. The flavors are well balanced and nothing is overpowering - not even the sweetness. The aftertaste is almost milk chocolate. Wow.

Kulmbacher Eisbock has a very thick, beige head, thick lacing rings, and a clear, dark, ruby-brown appearance, with lots of rapid bubble streams. The aroma is of rich, dark-roasted barley malt, chocolate powder, cream, and a faint odor of coffee grounds. Taste is of very rich, sweet chocolate, chocolate powder, dark-roasted malt, dark fruit, brown bread crust, and there is a slight hop bitterness. The alcohol really shows itself here, especially as it warms down the throat. Mouthfeel is mostly medium and smooth, and Kulmbacher Eisbock finishes dry, sweet, and boozy. Overall, this is just fantastic, and I rate it world class! RJT

33 cl. bottle poured in to a snifter. Dark brown colour with a reddish hue, a thin, lightly tanned head. Sweet aroma with dark, dried fruits, rich caramel malts, marzipan, toffee, light hints of nuts. Taste is medium sweet. Full body, thick, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Long lasting sweet finish with lots of dark fruits. Excellent bock.

12oz bottle.  Walnut-black color, clear-ish, no head, no lacing.  Slight aroma, alcoholic, pleasant.  Strong taste, lots of dark fruits, caramelized sugars, not too sugary though.  Not as heavy as I thought it might be.  Really enjoyable beer.

Pours dark brown, small top, not lacing. Aroma of caramel, candy, dark berries. A bit syrupy. Taste is sweetish, mid hopping. Aro.a complex. Flavour the same. Mouthfeel very astringent, dry.  Nice brew but was sampling in rush so must repeat.

Reviewed on: 3-5-13

Appearance: Dark dark brown, near black.  Opaque.  1-1.5 fingers of soapy khaki-colored head.  Looks nice in the glass.

Aroma: Lots of malt notes (milk chocolate, biscuit, slight roast) mixed with dark fruits (raisins, figs).  Slight banana, almost Belgian smell.  A touch of booze. 

Taste: Milk/bittersweet chocolate, brown bread, biscuit, very slight roast.  Figs, dates, raisins, and dark berries through the middle and into the finish.  There¬ís some caramel and toffee present into the finish that works well with the rest of the flavors. Some spiciness (cinnamon) as it warms.

Mouthfeel: Syrupy, thick. The alcohol isn¬ít hidden at all.  Definitely a noticeable warming in the throat.

Overall: This is a delicious beer.  Because this was my first eisbock, I wasn¬ít 100% sure what to expect, so I can only compare it to other styles.  It reminded me of a dubbel with touches of Belgian-ish flavors mixing well with the rest of the palate.  

Score: 9/10

Dried dark fruit, port and treacle on the nose, lots of toffee and roast raisin notes on the palate, the vinous syrupy sweetness balanced by the burnt sugar and the alcohol. Lasting burnt-bitterness with an edge of grassy hops.

11.2 Bottle. Poured dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is strong of malts and booze mostly but you can also get notes of fruits and raisins... Sweet taste, quite rich you can feel the alcohol, but is nicely balanced with malts and fruits. Nice finish too. Eisbocks are not my favorite style of beer but I would have to admit that this is quite an enjoyable beer.

0.33l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. This is a dark brown one with a medium sized slightly bubbly light beige top. The nose has a nutty sweetness with green banana, slightly sticky caramel and a soft rubbery hint. Surprisingly mellow for an eisbock I have to say, but nice enough. A bit pungent-soapy flavor in the taste. Warming down the throat with a slightly licorice and soy-sauce flavor. Sticky and warming finish and aftertaste. Quite pleasant, but nothing extraordinary. Had hoped for a bit more. 26.12.2012

Very smooth, great aftertaste, just the right ABV. That roastys taste is just perfect! As with all beers, you need to have it at that perfect temp to fully enjoy it, so make sure chilled properly or you will taste a major difference.
Bread, nuts, and caramel in the aroma.  Flavor is rich and sweet, with raisins and fruit.  Finish has alcohol and a little coffee bitterness for balance.  Nice sipping beer on a cold day.

Bottle (330 ml). Clear dark copper with small quickly diminishing beige head and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel, malt, plum, raisins and tobacco. Aroma is moderate to heavy sweet with raisins, plum, caramel and slight spices. Sirupy. That¬ís a good eisbock, but not favorite style of beer. Lack of balance and too much sweetness.
Bottle. Clear dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, plum and berries. Flavour is intense fruit, syrupy and warming with a sweet jam palate. Alco is there but not dominant.

It poured about an inch of white foamy head that died within a minute. The body was extremely dark which caused no carbonation to be seen rising. The lacing was lightly speckled, but intricately stayed together for a good two minutes before it spider-webbed, very impressive. The lacing eventually died, but it took a good five minutes before it all died. The smell had mainly raisins, plums and cherries - mainly balanced between the three. Some sweet malts enter in at the end. The taste was extremely rich with some molasses and the raisins, plums and cherries come back but just enough to remind you they exist in this beer. The flavor was extremely well balanced. The palate was about a medium with a good fullness to it. It could be the ABV, not sure? Overall, this is a very nice eisbock that I would come back to.

12 oz bottle Whole Foods.  Dark brown/garnet pour, tan head disappears completely, no lacing.  Aroma is sweet, dark, vinous, brown sugar, caramel, raisin, alcohol.  Flavor is strong and shows alcohol clearly; malt, bread, brown sugar, light spiciness (cinnamon?), alcohol, and a rather warm exhale through the nose.  Medium-thin body, almost flat, very sticky.  Could stand to be a little thicker in the palate, but very nice in the style.

Draught at City Swiggers in UES.. Pour is dark brown.. disappearing tan head. Smells of tobacco and sweet malt.. definitely sweeter than expected.. some dark fruit perhaps. Taste is surprisingly smooth... medium/heavy body but with subtle malt and fruit. Really tasty.. medium to high alcohol taste.. little carbonation.. velvety texture. Impressive

Courtesy of Grima, huge thanx!!!
