Strong strong alcohol taste - overpowers the other flavors. The deep dark color, with a full head is a beautiful sight, and there are certainly complex flavors in this beer, most of them are unfortunately drowned out by the alcohol.
Bottle. Murky dark brown, thin beige head that dissipates. Nose is booze,sweet malts, soy sauce, tobacco. Taste is sweet malts, chocolate,booze. Smooth mouthfeel, fairly high carbonation.

Bottle best before 201009, sampled 040113. 
Small lingering brown foam. Deep dark red color. Toffey and dark chrystal maltiness in the aroma. Chocolate and medium chrystal maltiness in the taste. Huge body and fine sparkle for such an old and strong beer. A tuch of alcohole and fine for a new years beer.
bottle. pours light brown with small tan head. aroma of malt and sugary bread. taste is very boozy and lots of caramel

Bottle, shared with Bergen Beer Geek Tasting Crew on Christmas Tasting 2012. Another long-stored classic up for rating; looking forward to The Original Eisbock for sure! :-) Pours a deep mahogany brown body with a small white head. Aroma is caramel, banana, nuts, hints of raisins and brown sugar. Pleasant. Taste is deep caramelly malt tones, banana, muscovado, hints of chocolate and burnt sugar. Full body, medium carbonation. Mellow, balanced and pleasant, although I somehow was expecting a bit more of...something. Still, a well-deserved place in the top slots of the Eisbock ratings.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2013 Really well balanced, wide taste spectrum, soft, warm, high alcohol and malt flavor in superb balance, a small lack of edge.

24.12.12
Uts: dyp, m√∏rk bronse, lite skum og kullsyre.
Duft: s√∏t malt og korn, s√∏t og tung alkoholduft, noe humle.
Smak: mye korn og malt, fyldig og god, varig ettersmak, men litt skuffende.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich nutty malt smell and taste with cloves and nutmeg as well. Strong taste of alcohol and could be a good desert bee.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with an off white head. Aroma of sweet malts and dark fruits.  Taste is sweet malts, dark fruits, hints of dark cherries. Loads of caramel and subtle roasted notes. Just enough hops to balance the malty sweetness. Little carbonation. Creamy and full bodied. Alcohol warmth but not boozy.  Nice fruity sweet finish.

Bottle, courtesy of Meilby. Pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, alcohol, licorice and bread crusts. Flavor is sweet and malty with some sweet caramel, red apples, spices and yeast. medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 330ml @ Geokkjer
Pours clear dark reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, alcohol and licorice. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

True to type, not my preferred style but can see why people would rate highly. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From a 33 cl bottle shared at home.  At least 5 years old.  Dark cola brown with virtually no head. Aroma of raisins.  Dark cherries, brown sugar, and velvet smoothness. Lovely.

From notes: Poured clear nutty brown with a thick and creamy 3-finger light tan head.  Aroma is roasty and caramelly, with perhaps a note of stone fruit beneath.  Nice, full body, with a mild creaminess in the finish.  Nutty flavor with a very strong herbal/stone fruit note in the back that becomes more of a candied fruit note as it warms.
Smaak is koffie, rozijnen, donker gedroogd fruit en beetje peperig in afdronk. Aroma is zoet karamel met expresschoc. Kraag verdwijnt, fijn mondgevoel.

Pours a dark translucent purplish brown with decent tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is very malty with molasses, grape candy, toffee, and some dark fruits.  Taste is sweet, and alcohol is well hidden.  Full body with only slight carbonation.  Quite a treat!

Malty aroma has a strong overtone of caramel, rather sweet. Pours a barely translucent chestnut with a fairly thick tan head. Mouth-filling flavor has a malty core with notes of caramel and cloves, a hint of fruit, a fairly strong alcohol bite, rather sweet. Somewhat syrupy texture has a fair amount of fizz and leaves a sweet, edgy, malty finish. Prosit!

On tap at S√∂rmanufakt√∫ra (Budapest). Deep dark colour. Like a porter or a strong coffee. Big and strong head. In the flavour strong choclate, that is very pleasant, and roasted malt. Tast is dark-fruit with choclate and raosted malt. This beer has balance.
Bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a medium beige head that laces well. Aroma is caramel, toffee, dried fruits. Flavor is same, raisins and noticeable alcohol, medium sweet with a warming finish.
Pours a pitch black color with a small white head. Aroma is malt, raisins, bread and caramel. The taste is smooth sticky malt, toast, roasted malts, and a bit of alcohol. Awesome beer!

A deep ruby brown with a light tan head, smells of berries, grape and roast. Taste of spicy alcohol, bitter heavy roasted grains, heavy dark chocolate with a return of hints of berries and grapes from the aroma with a sweet toffee and vanilla coming through. Palate is slick and fully bodied and it finishes with a clean lager type finish. Super tasty and incredibly drinkable.

Poured in snifter.  Pours a very dark copper-brown color with a nice head that lingers a bit.  Nice fruity and malty aroma, lots of toffee, figs, dates, cherries, and rich caramel.  Taste is smooth but doesn¬ít seem as complex as the aroma.  The fruitiness doesn¬ít seem to come through in the taste very much but I still like it.  Very malty with toffee and caramel flavors.  Very little alcohol burn on the finish and very smooth.  Somewhat high carbonation and medium body.  Slightly sticky and chewy mouthfeel.  Not a great beer and very much enjoyed sipping this.

From bottle in Albuquerque, NM, USA. Pours an opaque black color with no head. Intense, rich malty aromas with hint of molassas. Big body with heavy mouthfeel. Big malty flavors with overall slightly sweet flavor balance with slight prune character. Complex, not overly alcoholic. Impressive.

First rating of an Eisbock.  11.2 ounce bottle purchased fourteen months ago at Best Damn Beer Shop ($3.49).  Pours a deep brown hue with nice reddish-purplish highlights and one finger of beige head.  Aroma of dark toffee, caramel, overripe dark fruit, dark artisan bread, and grape-flavored hard candy.  Flavor has lots of dark fruit (raisin, fig, sticky plum, artificial grape extract) as well as sweet toffee, dark grainy breakfast cereal, molasses, and hints of chocolate.  On the sweet side, but not cloying.  The high ABV is quite well concealed here.  Very nice!  (1064, 728)

330 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Murky brown pour that in the glass appears almost black with a frothy khaki head.  Aroma of lightly sweet malts and a bit of chocolate but other than that the aroma is quite faint.  The flavor is chocolate and light coffee.  There is an immediate warmth noticed from this one.  This beer is smooth and pleasant to drink (or rather, sip) but it lacks some complexity that I found in my other experience with this style.

Pours dark brown to black with a small head.  Aroma dark caramel malt, as well as in the taste.  Some nice dark fruits, plum, dates, figs as well in the taste.  Smooth and great carbination, great beer

Pours a dark red that looks like a porter with a light brown head and light lacing. Nose is dark fruit.  Medium plus in body with a smooth creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is rich with some alcohol showing, Very tasty.
Bottle.  Rich caramel brown, thin head after the pour.  Sweet malty aroma, thick and smooth.  High alcohol is warming.  A good beer that is different and for a warming effect.

Bottle at Bruce¬ís Housewarming Party Tasting, London. Pours dark red with a medium, brown and creamy head. Big, sweet bready nose with notes of caramel. Hugely sweet flavor, nicely rounded with bread, caramel, light toast, suggestions of cocoa and ripe fruits. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Faintly warming finish, big sweetness, toffee, rich bread. Nice. Quite drinkable.

Bottle thanks to weihenheizen for picking this up for me. Poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a really dark amber color with a nice khaki colored head of foam. The aroma has heavy notes of cinnamon, molasses, and raisins. Taste is pretty sweet but manages to cover the alcohol surprisingly well. Overall its a nice style, but it didn¬ít really sand out as something new or special. Thanks for picking this bottle up for me, David.

This beer pours with a thin head.  The malty flavors are caramel and chocolate rounded out with roasty qualities found in black malts.  Hops are not detectable, but the lack of high maltiness implies a well balanced hop profile.  The yeast flavors are no longer detectable through the alcohol.  The beer I tried actually had a copper or metallic flavor, so it may have been from an old or less cared-for batch.

It pours a fairly flat looking dark chocolate with almost no head and no lacing.  The aroma primarily consists of malt.  The taste is quite interesting.  I can¬ít really describe the uniqueness upfront.  Is it the alcohol that hit you instantly?  It¬ís strange because the beer finishes a little malty and clean.  It¬ís medium bodied and very smooth at 9.2%.  I had no idea what to expect from this style, as it was my last to review, and I was not disappointed.  This is a really nice beer!

330 mL bottle. Pours dark cherry with a big, foamy, tan head. The aroma is dates, molasses, pine, and brandy. The flavor is very sweet and a little spicy. The palate is heavy, sticky, and grainy. There is significant alcohol warming in the finish. This is a very nice, strong, and malty beer.
Heel donkerbruin van kleur, goede kraag die wegebt tot een randje op het bier. Geur van donkergebrande mout en caramel. Smaakt naar mout, koffie en wat fruit. Droge afdronk. Wel OK.
Sehr gutes bier vor allem im landkreis kulmbach und bayreuth sehr beliebt sch√∂ner herber geschmack

A clear dark brown pour with ruby highlights and a beautiful tan head which quickly disappears. The aroma is sweet malt, dark fruit, and alcohol. The taste is prunes, malt, and a slight alcohol burn at the finish. The mouthfeel is full and creamy. This would be great after a big meal - sit and slowly sip. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[Bottle from Beers of Europe] Mahogany in hue, with a cream head that swiftly vanishes altogether, Slightly fizzy.  Flavours of rum, brown sugar, raisins, malt loaf, coca cola & chocolate; the alcohol is very evident.  Slight dryness of old dusty hops in the finish just about saves it from being too sweet.  It¬ís decent enough, but lacks any wow factor.
Very malty. The aroma isnt very strong. Smells of chocolate and hops. The taste is fantastic. I could drink this brew all night.
Dark amber in color, clear with a thin head. Super rich thick malt flavor with a great alcohol flavor. Dried fruit flavors and dry this was a super tasty Eisbock.

Deep ruby mahogany, with a small white tan head that fades quickly away... limited retention limited lacing... very sweet lots of dark fruits in the aroma... quite chocolatey flavor, lots of raisin fruits dark fruits, medium full bodied...

Draft at craft ale house. Pours black with a finger of tan head. Aroma is very similar to a double Bock and had a lot of bready notes. Taste is on the sweet side and has some brown sugar and yeast flavor.

Bottle to oversized snifter.  Looks good; dark with low carbonation and razor-thin lacing.  Smells like raisins, and malt.  Tastes decent, but (while easy to drink) not as flavorful as I¬íd expect.  Mouthfeel is goos for the abv.  Solid, but not special IMO.

Bottle at Bruce¬ís Housewarming Tasting. It pours deep ruby, with a thin beige head. The nose is roasted malt, treacle, burnt malt, currant and Eccles cake. The taste is caramel, wood , cola, spice, Christmas cake, roasted malt, dark fruit, vinous aspect, touch of tar and alcohol warmth, with some dryness in the finish. Medium-full body and moderate carbonation. An enjoyable Eisbock.

Bottle @ Bruce¬ís Housewarming Tasting. The disco ball shiny labelling of this beer is pretty great. The beer pours deep brown with no head. The aroma¬ís of sweet raisins, vinous fruits. Banana nut raisin bread. Sugary. The taste is much the same, plenty of cherry and jammy fruits. Vinous. Medium body. Nice.

Nice dark amber and subtle red colour. Also a bit sparkeling as it has a fine carbonation. Nice light beige head that last. Mild malt and dark fruits int the aroma. Moderate sweet flavour. Oily texture. A fruitiness in the flavour that can remind you about a solid red wine. Some caramel and dark malt. Very fruity. Reminding of grapes. Exciting beer and very well hidden alcohol. An excellent choice for my beer #2000 at RB. Also the last beer style listed here that I had not tasted. It will definatley not be my last Eisbock. Lovely stuff![Bottle. Trade with Mr Grima. Thanxx a LOT for this gem]

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2012 Nice malty yeast nose. Plum notes, nice dark maltiness. Dark brown and clear in color. Thick mouthfeel, almost with grape flavor. There is a solid malty flavor with hints of prune that stays on the tongue. Nice aroma. BD- 9.18 (8-1-12) Joek- 9.6 incredible flavor
Sweet and malty, a bit boozy aroma, almost sharp on the nose. Dark brown colour. Very sweet and warming flavour. Very nice.

Pours opaque, tan head. Sweet aromas of dark malt and candied dark fruit, maybe a touch of cocoa. Fine carbonation that effectively cuts through the medium-plus body and sweet flavor. The flavor is fairly sweet, with more dried candied fruit. Actually a nice touch of German hop bitterness balancing things out towards the end, and a finish that is less sweet than I was expecting. Surprisingly well balanced and integrated, a paragon of the style.

12 oz. bottle. It pours a very dark copper red color with a nice khaki head. The aroma is pleasant and complex with notes of dark fruit, bread, (raisin bread?) brown sugar, dry toast and hints of cherry. It has a nicely balanced malt and yeast character. The flavor is very rich with loads of sweet dark fruits. Mostly fig and cherry with some raisins and molasses. There is some dry maltiness hiding in the background with some spicy lager-like yeast esters. The finish is delectably sweet fruity and rich. The body is full, but not cloying at all. This was a real treat. Loved it.
Bottle from Ale Yeah! in Decatur, GA. Dark brown, malty and full but not heavy. Strong alcohol flavor at the end.

Very strong beer, on all features.
Dark with not a big head.
Super strong taste of alcohol. Some dark fruits and a sweet malty aftertaste.
It is a very nice beer, but once again, eisbocks are not my favorite.

Very impressive, probably the least German-tasting German beer I¬íve ever had.  That is to say, it tastes like a strong ale, not a lager.  Pours brown with little to no head.  Smell is odd, somewhat roasty?  It¬ís overall smooth and a little sweet, with carmel and nutty flavors coming through.  Really unique, much different than what I expected, and enjoyable.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on June 16th.
Appearance: Pours a dark brown black with ligh head. 
Aroma: Aroma is caramel, doughy.
Taste: Caramel malt sweetness, hint of nut, faint bitterness.
Palate:Medium light, quick aftertaste. Covers alcohol well.
Summary: My first Eisbock rating! And it¬ís the #1 rated active Eisbock. This beer was really tasty, and I can¬ít believe it¬ís a lager and not an ale.

Ffrom the bottle poured a brown brew with a thick light brown head. Aromas of very strong sweetness and high alcohol. Full bodied, with very sweet flavor, and a hop sizzle at the end that goes all the way sown the throat.

Bottle. Very dark with frothy tan head and light lacing. Smells like dark  raisin bread that¬ís maybe a little stale and not spiced. Then perhaps a little boozy. Flavor is sweet then dry with a bit of bitter astringency. Low carbonation, nice dry/astringent finish, warming. I like it despite not loving the aroma.

Deep brown with a decent almond colored head that quickly disappeared.  Aroma is dark fruits, molasses, nuts. Full, oily body.  Flavor is full of dark fruit, raisin, sweet malt, molasses, light nuts.  Not quite the complexity that I was expecting but a very enjoyable sipper. I¬ím glad this June day is cold and rainy as I would not want to drink this on a normal hot summer day.

Bottle at home. Apparently I don¬ít have an Eisbock rating. Ratebeer can be a funny old place. This should solve that problem. Pours toffee brown, with a black walnut hue. Nose is stewed fruit, some lager-yeast characteristics, lots of spice.. Flavours of leathery prunes berries tannin, spice, and that distinct taste of two unicorns fucking... Pretty tasty.
Pours black thin head. Aroma is very strong with plums and raisin. Ful rich malt flavour with a very complex fruit flavour. Very drinkable.,with a perfect favour balance. Great brew.

Pours deep ruby-brown with a large tan head.
Aroma is caramel malt, nuts.
Taste is sweet, heavy malt, sugar, caramel,  dark fruit.
Alcohol asserts itself smoothly with a pleasant back-burn.
Very rich tasting, filling....Quite good.

33 cl bottle @ Maifest ¬í12, Tampere, BBE 14.12.12
Aroma has some sweet malt and apple lemonade. Also hints of wheat. Flavour has sweet malt, some stinging and warming alcohol and apple lemonade. Dry finish. Interesting and nice.

33 cl bottle @ Maifest, Tampere.
Pours murky brown color with medium off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, yeast, starch, mild ripe fruits and sugar. Flavour of sweet sugar, caramel malts, ripe fruits and starch. A bit disappointing.
4415

Dark brown with a very thin beige head that sticks around.  Heavy malt aroma of molasses.  The first sip is overly sweet with a complex heavy mouthfeel.  The initial sweetness seems to diminish after a few drinks.  Excellent balance of malt and hops to bring out the maltiness.  This beer is almost like a meal.  Filling finish.

Very dark in appearance, white small head.  Smells of strong malt and molasses, with maybe a hint of something metallic.    Tastes is thankfully not as sweet as the aroma.  Pretty good balanced taste, malty, but not overly.  Dark fruit on finish.  Good, mildly carbonated taste.   Pretty good.

There is a reason why this is the second to last style I needed to try. I tried to be as objective as possible, but the sweet malt bocks, doppelbocks, and eisbocks are just not my thing, I really dont know how anyone can have more than two of these. A deep brown to black pour with almost no head. SWEET caramel malts with a hint of roasted flavor and licorice. no hops whatsoever. I can tell that it is a well crafted beer, but not my thing at all.
Deep brown colour with small head. Aroma and flavour is dark fruits, roasted, quite sweet after taste.

This has a really sickeningly sweet smell to it that is really off-putting. It has a nice dark pour with minimal head. The taste is similar, though very muted, compared to its taste. Terrible first impression, but not too bad on the back end.

Small off-white head that¬ís diminishing fast. Dark brown, nearly black body. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, alcohol, dried fruits and dry hops. The taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Full body, creamy and sticky texture, average carbonation. Long lasting finish. Nice beer and good quality.

Refrigerated 11.2 oz. bottle set on the table for a bit and poured into a snifter.  Very dark brown with medium brown highlights with small beige head.  Little lacing, thick body, low carbonation, and molasses aroma.  Taste is molasses, some dark fruit (mostly dates), some alcohol, and some hop bitterness in the finish.  A little too much alcohol, I prefer Schneider Aventinus Eisbock.

Dark brown, tan head. Malty with some bitterness. Full bodied with a nice finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. Pours a deepbrown with a tiny tan head. Nose of caramel, molasses and notes of hops. Sweet flavor with caramel, syrup and alcohol. Full bodied, creamy texture and flat carbonationl. Some bitterness in the finish along with warming alcohol. Quite nice for a bock.

Dark mahogany, off white head which stays around for  awhile.  Yummy dark malt (sorry, that is what it is), with a fruitcake finish...some definite alcohol in the nose.  Currants and other dark fruit in the tongue, sweet alcohol finish.  An homage to the power of sweet, coddled malt.  Drink this after you are done eating.

33 cl bottle shared with gnoff on March 10, 2012

Pours black with a reddish hue, small tan head.  Scent of caramel, malt, molasses, figs.  Very sweet taste with raisins/figs, molasses, brown sugar.  Smooth with a sugary finish.

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours a very dark ruby red with a two finger tan head (I don¬ít understand the reviews that say it has no head, this is nice and frothy), clusters of frothy lace coat the glass. The aroma is strong caramel and toffee with a certain unidentifiable spice, sweet and very appealing. The taste is toffee, brandy, nutty, creamy, it leaves a warming feeling as it goes down my throat. Overall I was impressed, not sure If I was going to like this or not, I was afraid the sweetness would be too overbearing, but it is very drinkable and mildly dry in the mouth.
Smells very sweet.  Dark black.  No head.  Very drinkable, hard to believe it is nearly 10% alcohol.

330 ml bottle courtesy of and shared with Marsiblursi. Pours dark reddish brown with a caramel brownish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace. Smell is very sweet with caramel, toffee, pecan nuts, hazelnuts, figs in brandy, overripe peaches, dried apricots, bread, leather, honey, wood, tiny oxidation and alcohol. Taste is very sweet, malty and tiny tart with caramel, honey, cookie dough, nuts, very ripe fruits, bread and wood. Mouthfeel is sticky sweet and full bodied. Finish is sweet with hazelnuts, caramel, figs, dates and very ripe peaches.

Snifter from bottle. A: sweet malt, chocolate, cinnamon, slight alcohol, and brown sugar. App: very nice dark brown, small light   head that disperses quickly. T: alcohol up front, some sweetness from the malt in the middle, and slight alcoholly burn on the back. P: sensational, super bubbly, and an ever-lasting aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a faint ruby tint and thick off-white head; short retention and some lacing. Aroma is cherries, toasted and caramel malt, oak, brown sugar, and light booze. Flavor is smooth, lightly sweet malt with faint hops and fruit esters; dry, semi-sweet finish. Full body, medium carbonation, and medium warmth.
Deep mahogany reddish brown with a thin tan head. Smooth and a bit deep flavor malt with caramel, nut, cherry, and raisin. Strong and full, but not thick.

Pours a dark red with a decent sized head that dissipates quickly to ring. Aroma is dark fruits, malt sweetness, and some wood and earthiness. Taste is sweet caramel, figs, alcohol,  and some bread.  Carbonation is somewhat prickly on the palate.

Pours a deep ruby color with a small head that fades fairly quickly and has a bit of lacing. A rich aroma of dark fruits, with some malt sweetness and a hint of chocolate. Taste is similar to the aroma. Flavor of dark fruit with a mild sweetness. There is just a hint of bitterness and a dry finish.
 Medium body, smooth and creamy. Very clean with and excellent balance. No reach hint of the alcohol. Excellent drinker that goes down very easy. Good sipper on a cold eventing. Well worth a try.
Bottle - average size fomay head, deep very dark amber color, very sweet malty aroma and flavor, mild roast and alcohol flavor

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a beige head. Aroma is of raisins, caramel, sweet malt, toffee, toasted malt and nutty notes. Flavor follows the aroma lots of raisins, caramel and toffee, with the nutty notes, fruitcake, toasted and sweet malt. The body is medium to full with a sticky oily mouth feel. Overall a pretty good Eisbock, but I prefer Aventinus Weizen Eisbock.
Bottle.  Rootbeer brown pour.  Aroma is tangy with some sour cherries and fruitcake.  Taste is burnt sugar, cherries, and slight alcohol.  Medium to heavy body and light carbonation.

11.2oz beer pours a thin black with almost no head.  Aromas of alcohol chocolate malts and some roasted nuts.  Flavor is bitter with alot of alcohol warmth.  Body is medium and finish is a bit lasting

Bottle. Rating #1002. Dark brown, a little darker than a cola and it has a real nice creamy tan head. Lots of dark fruits in the aroma, sweet plums and the like. Flavor is similar, a little soy sauce to go with the fruits and alcohol, but with a mild and pleasant aftertaste. Good stuff. (2189)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Pitch black,  beige medium rocky head, sets quickly. Aromas are caramel, roasted malts, some nuts. Oliy slick texture, smooth medium carbonation. Taste sweet maltiness, vanilla , warm ABV, no hops or bitter in the taste. Some raw cacao beans drynees in the finish. Balanced, ABV well hidden, finish dry and somewhat sweet from malts. Nice eisbock , specially on cold winter nights.
Tap at Trion Tavern. Sweet molasses, malt aroma. Red tinted brown with a small beige head. Sweet dark fruit, dark roasted malt, anise flavor.
Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black with beige head. Caramel and some bitterness. Comparable to the aventinus without the hefe characteristics. Nice sweetness. Very good.
From bottle. Slightly muted aroma, caramel and toffee. Similar taste, some bready yeast. Abv well disguised. Sweet with a clean finish. Very well balanced. Tasty

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Tasted from 12oz bottle into nucleated pint glass. Poured an opaque dark brown color with moussy beige foam, lasting with nice lace. Strong aromas of raisin bread, loads of caramel, fruitcake, perfumey noble hops, and amazingly almost no alcohol or fermentation esters/phenols. Rich malty-sweet flavor, almost syrupy but not cloying because it was offset by just enough subdued hops tartness, toast, toffee, semi-sweet chocolate, hints of hardwood and more dried dark fruits: raisins again, prunes, cranberries, mulberries. Almost no trace of alcohol in the flavor either; a truly remarkable disappearing act at 9.2% ABV! Medium body, not as heavy as I expected. Low-medium carbonation. Well-rounded, smooth, almost sticky mouthfeel. Long-lasting tangy, candy-like aftertaste. Definitely a winter warmer to be sipped. Reminiscent of a Trappist Quad. Highly recommended on a cold night.

Pours a deep, deep brown, almost black.  Thin off white head that dissapates quickly.  Aromas of dank fruit, rum, molasses.  Taste is actually quite nice... almost akin to a porter but with a different yeast strain.  Heavy, heavy malts.  Alcohol is noticeable, but barely.  This beer is world class.
It poured a deep brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of malts and some molasses. The taste was of malt with more molasses and caramel. A very good Eisbock.

Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed while at my practice space listening to bandmates other band.  Appearance is a very dark, murky brown with a thick off white head.  Aroma is very malty, unique German lager yeast, dark fruit, nice and unique aroma.  Taste is nice and good, happy to have tried it, not my typical style though.

On tap at S√∂rspecialista, Budapest. Clear ruby color with minimal off-white head.  Sweet malty odor. Nice aroma with some smoke and much alcohol, but sugar doesn¬ít dominant. Clear, dry, bitter taste with some sweetness. Medium body with soft carbonation and creamy and oily texture. Smoky sweet alcohol finish. It¬ís an underhand beer with quiet taste but with high alcohol content.
spruce, cheese, banana, rotten eggs, smoke, amber, sparkling, tan foam, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, heavily sour, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish,

Deep brown almost black with red highlights and taupe head. Sweet crisp aroma with some dark fruit. Medium-full well rounded mouthfeel leads with dark fruit and cola. Biscuity malts throughout.  Alcohol warmth on the finish.
Bottle sample in a Winter Beer tasting in Tel Aviv. Pours coca-cola black. Grape, fruit, sugar aroma, sweet, wine-like taste. Smooth,not too carbonated, medium body, long, sweet finish. Quite nice.

Pours thick and near black with almost no head. Aroma of sour malt and oak. Taste is very sweet. No carbonation seemingly. Tastes a bit like flat soda with alcohol. Still the bock flavor is mild and a bit watered down. Even though its strong the alcohol doesn¬ít come through too much.
I will never understand Eisbocks.  Sweet, caramelly, kinda sticky and fruity, but not really in any way amazing, just ok, and not drinkable.
brown, hazy, minimal head, nuts, roasty, herbs, light sweetness, lightly bitter, oily feel, medium body,
brown, black, clear, tan foam, coffee, cereal, soy sauce, full body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness,

Bottle pours brown with tan head. Smell is big and malty with a little sugar. The taste is strong barley with a sugar finish and a bit of alc on the back end. Overall drinkable but not extra ordinarily smooth, good though. There is more in the nose but the taste is very close.
Dark brown beer with off-white head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits and roasted malts. Flavour is the same and a bit on the sweet side.
Deilig √∏l, takk til Svend p√• √òlkonsortiet i Aalborg!  Alkoholpreg, og mye malts√∏dme. Deilig ettersmak, "flytende fruktkake"...

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin off white foam. Foam retreats quickly to a thin film. Smells of caramel, brown sugar, and chocolate. Some roasted flavor with a definite alcohol warmth. Finish leaves a malty sweetness in the corners of the mouth with a clean bitterness. Unique.
Pitch dark and no head. Nose is full of. sugar with a little camel. Medium body and length. Taste of sugar, caramel. Powerfull but very simple in a good way

Bottle from 99. Clear, dark amber pour with a persistent beige head leaving heavy lace. Boozy, nutty nose. Heavy body and moderate carbonation. Toffee, dark fruit, licorice and dates. Tastes and feels concentrated, as you¬íd expect from an Eisbock, and makes me want a glass of water to follow it with. Finish is short, darkly sweet and has a bit of umami creeping in late. The alcohol is not as noticeable as one would expect from the nose or the ABV.

Consumed alongside EKU 28, because that beer is not sinister enough on its own. This bock pours used oil blackish with no head. It is evident that a fair amount of dark malts went into it. Aroma is fruity and spiced. Flavor is sweet caramel and toffee, fruit is less detectable. Bitter hops also make an appearance, although clearly it was a struggle. It is a heavy beer without being viscous; however it will leave some oiling in its wake. Very solid and still the staple for the style. An acquired taste in the same way scotch is.

Light,off white head and beautiful, deep ruby appearance. Nose has copious amounts of stewed fruit and notes of blackberry and leather. Flavor has a strong raisiny quality, with syrupy chocolate and dark honey flavors. Mouthfeel is heavy with a noted alcohol taste.

11.2 oz bottle
Aroma: raisin, plum, malty, dark fruits
Taste: very similar to the aroma
A very good Eisbock. I would never turn this beer down.

Rating #662, flaske fra Toft Vin Islands Brygge  

Den sidste i kvartetten af √∏l nydt f√∏r Svartsot-koncerten i Nakskov, i godt selskab med Troels, Brian og Frank. √òllen er brun uden skum, og det var s√•dan set hvad jeg havde forventet ud fra erfaringer med andre eisbock. Duften var dog ringere end forventet - alt var noget gammelt br√∏d. Smagen lidt bedre, men stadig pr√¶get af gammel br√∏d, malt og alkohol. Kun en medium bitter afslutning. Mundf√∏lelsen mellemtyk og bl√∏d. Ok. Drikkelig √∏l, men bestemt overvurderet og ikke tiln√¶rmelsesvis oppe p√• siden af hverken EKU28 eller Aventinus Weizen Eisbock.

330ml bottle. Pours a very deep dark red with a tall, pillowy head that has reasonable retention. Big molasses on the nose with a real brandy and stewed fruit feel. There¬ís some deep brown sugar there too. A bit of a medicinal edge too. Medium bodied with molasses and sewed fruit. Not as sweet as I expected and the alcohol is very well hidden.

cloudy, medium brown, tan-to-light brown head.  Aroma is caramelized banana and butterscotch.  Thick body with flavors of banana, caramel, light raisin, lager sulfur.  Very yummy, even dangerous.  Not quite as complex or as in-your-face flavors as Schneider Aventinus Eisbock per se, but good, like a drinkable doppelbock with some extra yeast kick.

Pours dark mahogany color with thick but fast dissappearing tan head, smell is herbs malts and soy sauce, pretty off putting. Taste isn¬ít that great either, kinda the same as the aroma, soy sauce, herbs, some slight sweetness. Didn¬ít really enjoy this.

330ml bottle poured almost black in color with a firm tan head which settled slowly to some thin lacing.  Aromas of dark roasted malts and some hints of coffee and hops.  Taste is roasted malty sweetness with some coffee and a moderate hop bitterness and alcohol in the finish.  A nicely balanced and relatively easy to drink beer that is very tasty.

Bottled 330ml. -from Ambrosetti, Berlin. Pale brown coloured, medium to big sized beige head, caramel and plums in the nose. Sweet malty, caramel and quite strong plums with rather sticky and sharp alcoholic finish. Huge disappointment , expected much better beer.... So is this a bad batch or just another overrated beer.

12oz bottle. Clear, dark red color. Minimal, light beige head, no lace. Rich, dark fruit taste, with some warmth. Hint of licorice. Light bitter taste evident here is kind of odd and medicinal. Light, subtle carbonation. Very light, hardly any there. Overall, it¬ís a pretty impressively tolerable high-ABV ale, and the price was right (got it as part of a $10 mix-your-own sixer).

Dark mahogany/caramel/toffee colored pour. Decent sized off-white, almost tan head. Doesn¬ít stay long, doesn¬ít leave much lacing. Big malty aroma with raisins. Big bready, malty flavor. A little bit dusty tasting and sweet. Slight alcohol warmth. Dry. Pretty decent.

This beer is bubbly when poured large tan bubbly head and bubbles run from the bottom of the glass and up the sides.After about 2 mins it¬ís over no bubbles and looks flat and has no head left.The aroma is weak but very unique malts first found and a lite herbal note.Full of flavor malts and alcohol most noticeable flavors stay with you.

Poured a clear dark brown color with a thin off-white head.  Slighlty sweet malty aroma with some dark fruit.  Some raisins and brown sugar.  Taste is very flavorful with lots of caramel and roasted flavors.  Lots of dark fruit as well.  Some grapes and raisins.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden, but there is a slight warming in the aftertaste.  Overall full-bodied and slightly creamy.  Great beer.

What an amazing eisbock!! This brew poured up a near black-colored body with a bubbly head with moderate retention and lacing effects. Aromas full of dark roasted coffee beans, roasted malts and dark fruits (figs perhaps). Flavors of sweet malts, dark fruits, alcohol, and coffee. Full-bodied, thick and creamy, very smooth on the palate and warming finish reminiscent of fresh baked bread.

A very dark brown beer with next to no head.  The aroma is strongly alcoholic with a sweet molasses and anise backing.  The flavor has a nice licorice and raisin taste, some earthiness, a little bitter, and a large dose of alcohol.  The flavor is pleasant but a bit overpowering.

bottle in a pint glass - pours clear ruby with beige head leaving some lacing behind.  Nose is plum or forest fruit.  Aroma is caramel malts, banana, and alcohol.  taste is quite sweet.  finish is long and dry due to high alcoholic content,  very pleased with the style and presentation.
Dark brown color  with small off-white head. Aroma of alcohol and brown sugar. Flavor is fruity with taste of raisins.

330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Has a real funky glittery label, like snowy ice. This, according to legend, is the original eisbock. It¬ís a must have, just for that legend. Also, Michael Jackson rated this as a top class beer. I felt that the beer couldn¬ít live up to its legend and reputation, but - boy oh boy - this beer is lovely! It¬ís all about the malt. And I love malt. I love, dark, flavoursome malt. Sweet, sticky, brown malt, with bread and fruit, and dark, dark, flavours, like swimming in treacle and molasses. Oh, this is soft, and delicious. But it¬ís not one-dimensional, it twists and turns, and, despite the loveliness, it has its challenges and secrets. There¬ís aromas of oil and petrol and decaying matter and bubbling richness, there¬ís alcohol nips, and there¬ís bitter spots, and there¬ís a solid tobacco stained adult quality about this. There¬ís much to enjoy, and much to admire. This is delightful, and never boring. And, phew, it hits you with that alcohol strength because it¬ís so soft and drinkable, you¬íve gone through a bottle in no time at all. Oh my, this is one of the best beers in the world. A fucking lager, for fucks sake!

Bottle. Very dark ruby red (nearly black) pour with a fairly large initial head that dissipated into almost no head. Rich aroma of fig and licorice. Medium mouthfeel, with a touch of carbonation. Taste is malt, dark fruit, a touch of roast, and bread. Good stuff. In addition, this was rating #1250, and one of the 2 remaining beer styles that I have not yet had. I think this was $2.79 well spent.

had this versus aventinus.  pours deep brown.\amber colour almost identical to aventinus.  A little more lively carbonation in this one.  Nose is more fruity than its counterpart (plums, fruit cake, slight breadiness) this carried over into the taste also.  Not quite as sweet and bready as the aventinus.  Decent mouthfeel, not as thick as aventinus.  Overall a quality brew, aventinus slightly better.
Jag har sv√•rt f√∂r s√∂ta bock√∂l i vanliga fall och den h√§r √§r ju flera resor v√§rre. B√∂r nog lagras. K√§nns spritig och s√∂tsliskig nu.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid dark brown with a ruby red tinge, and a small dissipating white head. Aroma of dark fruits bread, maple syrup, candied sugar. Flavour of dark fruits, light booze, syrup, bread, candied sugar. Full bodied, nicely sweetened, Beautiful.
Sampled in a small bottle. Aged for about 4 months. A really crisp well made brew. Very carbonated. Great brew.

Sch√∂ne dunkel-braune Farbe mit akzeptabler Schaumentwicklung. Malzig und s√º√ü im Geruch. Gleichzeitig r√∂stig und etwas alkoholisch. 
Geschmack weich und s√ºffig, s√º√ümalzig. Im Nachhall alkoholbetont und prickelnd-pfeffrig. 
Der Kulmbacher Eisbock ist ein Doppelbock von Format. Gutes Gesamtbild. 
Lediglich das Etikett erscheint mir zu "spacig". Das alte war wesentlich schlichter und gefiel mir besser.Test vom 19.4.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

330ml bottle from Bierkompass. Bottle was about a year old.

Appearance : Deep clear amber with small creamy off-white head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Rich raisins and plums. Light hops. Some caramel. Light mineral notes. Nice sweetness.

Taste : Raisins and plums with light hops. Finish is a bit hoppy with light bitterness. Slightly mineral. Rather dry. Not much alcohol.

Overall : Awesome caramel with great raisins. Nice hops too. Not too sweet which is surprising. A bit too mineral for my taste maybe. Very nice balance.
tons of molasses, a bit of soy sauce. smells exactly like a Whopper tastes! sweet, slight malty sourness, maybe salty. a bit of alcohol also. medium body, flat, sticky, viscous. awesome

WOWOWOW; first Eisbock and if I can remember where I got this (K/B Plano?) it won¬ít be my last.  

Dark brown pour with white lacing that stays on glass. perfect 5 on palate was first thing I noticed; taste was thick with powdery chocolate dark frutits and all else good in the world.   Alcohol in aroma and in taste but it works and works well;  more please

33 cL bottle from Beers of Europe poured into a Karmeliet Tripel glass.  Very dark brown with a well formed and generous head.  The aroma is sweet, alcoholly, and a smells of bock.  Its surprisingly smooth given the alcohol and the aroma, and very pleasant with a bit of a kick when it hits the back of the throat, but also some caramel notes.  Pleasant but almost a little sickly sweet.  I¬íd certainly have it again though.

Poured from a twelve ounce bottle to a stemless red wine glass, this classic bears a dense two-finger (though quickly condensing) mocha head above deep brown beer with good clarity. The aroma is milk chocolate, dark fruit, with a touch of alcohol. Flavors are dark chocolate, caramel and dark fruit on the nose, with chocolate pervading, followed by a balancing dryness with (not hot) alcohol and hint of hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is a notch above medium; it is not heavy, thick or oily. Delicious sipper that is pronounced by somehow svelte, quite balanced. Deserves rep as classic example for historically significant style.

I wish everytime I fucked up I could create something this awesome. Pours dark brown from bottle with a fat fist of khaki foam. Nice malted notes on the nose. Medium mouthfeel. Doesn¬ít leave a ton of lacing. It¬ís like pumpernickel in a glass. Finishes smooth. It hides it¬ís 9% well. Perfect after dinner drink or you could just make it your dinner.

Clear brown pour with a light tan head.  Toasted malt aroma with notes of honey.  Very sweet smelling with noticeable alcohol.  Sweet fruity flavor with notes of cherry and a bitter finish.  Very smooth and drinkable.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Medium tan head.  Aroma of plum, figs, brown sugar and alcohol.  Flavor is similar, with raisin and toasted marshmallow sweetnes followed by a moderate alcohol burn.  Mouthfeel is moderate and not as oily as many eisbocks.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2011 .(  Bottle)This  bottle resembles a disco ball  , a serious beer though . In my Duvel tulip ..if swriled alot a  good  nose in HD showcasing brown bread,soy sauce ..burnt malts ..tobaco,petrol fumes.  There¬ís chocolatey dark fruit covered  elements too . I wish I could drink the aroma ,  this beers  lacking to drink compared in contrast to the complex  stetnch . Rich and malt driven ovbiously on the palate  , plesant , but not expressive  . (Safe !!!) Why drink  9.2% eisbock for safety reasons ?.

Stark malziger Antrunk, durch die S√º√üe cremig und nicht sehr agressiv. Angenehm, kr√§ftig malzig, sehr semig. Sehr schokoladig, etwas brennend im Abgang. Ausgewogen. 	 
Test vom 13.10.2008, Gebinde: Fass 	Noten: 8,12,11,13,-,12 - 11,57

Deep reddish brown pour off white head ... lots of dark fruits and sweet malt in the aroma (plums, raisins) ..... taste is smooth and of caramel malts, dark fruits (plums, raisins) and a little bitter kick to it ..... abv is hidden well with a slight warming ... well balanced taste not too sweet not too malty just right ... great brew
Very dark with a deep, tan, good head.  Aroma is sweet - almost of molasses.  Taste is some syrup and brown sugar.  Finish is more sweetness.  Good - just not really my style.
Bottle from Superbest, R√∏dovre. Clear amber colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, fruit, caramel, malt and alcohol.

On tap - Lake Flying Saucer Spring Beer Fest 2011.
Clear amber with some beige head.  Alcohol is appearent in the aroma and flavor but isn¬ít overpowering.  Aromas of fruit and some vanilla - very thick and almost syrupy mouthfeel.  Flavors continues to creep out as the beer warms.  Great boozy fruit flavor with some chocolate and caramel.  Very tasty!

Poured quickly but the head disappeared in a minute. Chocolate color. Aroma is velvety nutty malt and some spice. Maybe some old fashioned candy. Slightly oily medium mouthfeel leaning toward heavy. Awesome job hiding the 9.5% alcohol rating. This is really a wonderful beer, glad I stumbled across it.

330 mL bottle.  (2009 vintage).  Dark, clear, cola brown with a small head.  Bread and berries in the aroma, along with the expected dark fruit and booze.  Nice flavour, with bruised apple, caramel, prunes, dates, and booze being my first impressions.  Body is solid without being heavy.  Medium-light carbonation.  A lovely sipper.

Picked this bottle up in Chicago when we were back for Christmas. Served in a wine glass.

Pours a moderate amber-copper color with a pretty good off-white head. A bit of spotty lacing on the way down and a nice, thin collar around the edges of the beer. The nose is pretty sweet with some dark fruits and a touch of oxidation. Not all that much alcohol. The taste is a bit of caramelized malt with some fruit and quite a bit of sweetness. Not much booze comes through in the feel, though that might be because it¬ís quite sweet, bordering on cloying. Not a bad beer but half of this bottle was more than enough for me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-24-2011

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a large snifter.

Appearance: In the glass it looks dark brown with reddish highlights. It is topped by a small tan head that quickly fades to a light ring of foam. Lacing is minimal and very slick.

Smell: The aroma is the star of the show and offers deep inviting layers of malty goodness. I get lots of sweet roasted malt, caramel and dark fruits like plum, figs and raisin with drop of molasses and rum like alcohol.

Taste/Palate: Its flavor matches the aroma to a tee but comes off a little lighter than I had expected yet still full bodied. It brings all the wonderful layers of maltiness with a mellow warming abv. It finishes sweet but not in a heavy or cloying way and the palate is smooth and full yet still very drinkable for such a big beer.

Notes: This is a very enjoyable beer with nice complexity and excellent drinkability.
Sweet and robust malt aroma. Clear amber color with a small white head. Light sweet beginning that builds in the finish and gets slightly bitter in the end.

Bottle. Dark brown,small and fully diminisshing light brown head. Moderate, malty and sweet aroma, caramel and some raisins. Body is medium to full, malty and sweet flavor, some caramel and raisins. Finish is average, malty and sweet, some alcohol. Sweet bock, some alcohol in the finish, nothing special.
12oz bottle, courtesy of drowland, pours with a light tan head. Sweet, boozy aroma, alcohol front and present. Interesting. This isn¬ít that bad for a drunk beer.
4/2/11. Bottle thanks to emacgee! Clearish dark red brown pour with a small brown head.  Extreme malty aroma with sweet caramel. Sweet malty flavor with a hint of smoke. Eh.

A: poured into a snifter. rich mahogany in color with a nice tan head. light lacing.

S: smells beautiful. great bouquet, warm apples with tons of spices. slight aroma of cloves.

T: rich malts with a hint of apples and bananas. the high alcohol is present but not overwhelming.

M: warms the mouth and makes the palate tingle with its complex flavors.

D: i may have found my Aventinus substitute. two of these and I am ready to party. Pick this up and you won¬ít be disappointed.

A dark amber pour with a frothy tan head.  It has a toasty caramel aroma with a hint of alcohol.  The medium to full body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste is mildly sweet with slightly roasted finish.
Bottle from 3 Sons, clear brown with fragrance of malts and caramel, sweet and not too much play from alcohol.  No bitter or iron notes.  Plenty of candy and dried fruit.  Nice head and lacing.

11.2oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours dark brown with a thick, lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of dark fruits, nuts, roasted malts, and some floral notes.  Flavor about the same with a strong alcohol and grape note on the finish.  Thicker than average, but nothing special.  A good introduction to this style of beer.

Pours deep chestnut brown with a quickly dissipating light khaki head. Aroma has a clear yeast component just like in a normal bock. Nice caramel and nutty maltiness, a slight alcohol hint, perhaps a hint of cafe latte and cardboard. Taste is pretty much the same, but it drinks really easily with only small note of the alcohol. Hints of sweets and nuts. Really nice, better than expected.

Pours dark brown with a quick off-white head. Nose is mostly brown sugar, with a touch of hops, alcohol, and roastiness. Flavor is both fruity and roasty, with a slightly sour undertone to the dark malt. Hops are fairly subdued. Definately more yeast and malty assertiveness than is typically present in German styles (it¬ís more akin to Belgian ales) and is a well-balanced and generally good beer.

2003 bottle, fresh bottle. Surprisingly similar despite difference in age ¬ó less carbonation and less bitterness in the older bottle. Plus the aged beer displayed more dark fruit and was more sherry-like. Deep amber, approaching brown, body. Short, frothy tan head, mostly diminishing. Sweet, fruity aroma of caramel, molasses, brown sugar and toasted grain. Notes of sherry and alcohol in the aged beer. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture with lively carbonation in the fresher bottle and mild carbonation in the 2003. The fruity aroma is appealing and the beer hits the front of the tongue with a variety of flavors ¬ó dark, overripe fruits, bread, molasses. The finish, however, is sticky and too sweet for my tastes, aged or not.

330 ml bottle in Germany, I admit that I am no fan of this brewery but this was not bad at all. Pours dark brown in color with a bubbling, huge tan head. Aroma is sweet, with elements of rapsberry fruit and alcohol. Flavors are pretty straight-up, malty and sweet, with some deep almost smokey complexity. Alcohol is warming, but not too intense. Great stuff, overall.
Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, heavy malty and dried fruit. Flavor is rather sweet. Soft and smooth with a sweet finish. Warming alcohol. Great eisbock. 141210

Bottle courtesy of guyinchicago!). Pours cola color with off-white head. Aroma of raisin, port, and some wood/cardboard.   Taste is sweet with little alcohol bite.  Full bodied and sticky texture.  Smooth, but somewhat boozy finish.  A nice winter beer!
very dark pour with red tones, no head. Aroma is prunes and some maltiness. Flavor is very pruny, alcohol, perhaps a bit o¬í chocolate. Medium body, a bit chewy. Good but not superb.
This is smoother than the aventinus eisbock, the alcohol doesnt burn as bad allowing the palate to be appreciated, malty complexity and many layers of malts take over the body, worth a try
On tap.  No head.  Alcohol and molasses and bread.  This will kick ones ass, but in a nice way.

"The Original German Eisbock"

Comes in a brown bottle with a flashy "Ice" label. Pours a nice tan 1 inch head that appears very bublly and thick, you cannot see thorugh the dense, dark color of this beer.

The smell is overwhelmingly of chocolate, with a juicy(yes) smelling toffee malt to finish. The smell is pretty scrumptious.

Taste is a lot more bitter than expected, and its gooood. Lots of dark roasted malts, coffee like bitterness, and a very faint bit of molasses/chocolate sweetness in the middle. This is a nice robust brew with only little traces of its 9.2% of alcohol which isn¬ít overpowering, but its there and increases as it warms. Its got a really nice and thick mouthfeel with a fair amount of carbonation. It leaves a good amount of stickiness in your mouth and on you lips though you cant taste the sugars as prevalent as you can smell and feel them although it does get slightly sweeter as it warms with the alcohol.

Overall this is a highly worthy brew and would fit well in a dessert setting.
Poured dark reddish brown, chocolate, dark fruit, nutty, little smoke, little alcohol.

Pours deep reddish brown, thin tan head.  Aroma has surprising notes of chocolate, burnt caramel, some raisins and other dark fruit, along with a touch of roast.  Taste is a bit less than the aroma, has notes of the caramel, dark fruit and other sugars, with a touch of some metal, finishing sweet, maybe a touch of booze.  Pretty good, like the style!

Pours very dark brown with tons of carbonation.  4" head into a tulip.
Strong aroma of soy sauce with some subtle smokiness and butterscotch
Chocolately flavor with mild sweetness and a moderate bitterness that hangs on to the back of your tongue.  Mod/high carbonation
Great beer, just has that thickness in malt and alcohol that hits you and makes you want every beer to be that good.
alcoholic aroma,golden, clear, tan foam, lightly bitter, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish.

Pours a hazy medium brown with a small beige head composed of small bubbles.  Smells of light carmel and malt.  This beer is relatively sweet but has enough other flavor to balance the sweetness nicely.  Molasses with no bitterness to speak of.  This beer is a little bit fuzzy in the mouth and is sweet enough to leave a bit of a bad taste in the mouth after drinking.  Not much of an alcohol taste for a high alcohol beer.  Overall, not bad but also not a beer I would choose to drink on a regular basis.

11.2 oz. bottle served in a Blvd. Tank 7 tulip. Poured a deep brown with two fingers of tan head. Deep malty aroma with some molasses. Big, rich full bodied mouthfeel. Lots of malt with more molasses and caramel. Some noble hops to balance things out. Warming, but not alcoholic. One of these is plenty. Top notch bock.

the expiry date is exceeded for 3 months!!!
The beer in glass is deep brown, almost black with a surprisingly large head, which, however, does not hold too long. The Eisbock smells intensely chocolaty and roasted malt, almost like a good Imperial Stout. Starts chocolatey nutty, subtle caramel and fruity, just absolute amazing! The aftertaste is also shown chocolatey-roasty, resonates very long and warm. Especially for the winter season a brilliant beer. The center part  is chocolaty, roasted malty with a strong body. Only a few little fruity nuances come through. Overall pleasant alcoholic-warming and just terrific!

(Sample Date: 4/18/2010   Source:Other)   BJCP study session. Very malty with some dark fruit and grape notes in aroma. Deep copper brown with small head and some legs. Caramel, toasty, with some dark fruit in the flavor. Little hop flavor but hefty bitterness balances out malts. Full mouth feel with some warming.

Poured into a flute.

4.0 A: Clear dark brown, nearly black. Frothy head with decent retention for the ABV. Some lacing.

5.0 S: Caramel, raisins, prunes. Really really wonderful. There¬ís a big sweetness to it to balance out the detectable alcohol.

4.5 T: This is just downright tasty. Lots of plum/prune flavor. Then some raisin and caramel. Complex set of dark malts. Delicious.

4.5 M: Medium heavy body. Chewy and creamy and oh so smooth for a 9.2% beer. Nearly perfect warming on finish.

5.0 D: Damn fine beer. Very drinkable. This could be a staple of anyone¬ís beer diet.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-12-2009 23:30:05
tap at RnH - heavy sweet, toffee , very boozey, tasty. very heady. smooth bodied.

Appearance:  black coffee with ruby notes against the light, tiny head that vanished to bubbles.  Aroma:  chocolate, raisins, rich dark toffee.  Taste:  sweet and rich, syrupy dark roasted caramel and malts, some coffee, then a little bitterness to balance; like a dessert port	lingering and slightly sweet, a little sour dryness at the end and then the alcohol warmth.  Notes:  Surprisingly thin in the mouth.  Very strong.  Definitely a sipper.  While interesting to try, I¬íd either have a doppelbock (to go a little lighter) or an imperial stout (to go a little richer).  I am new to the style, so maybe it just needs to grow on me.
Incredibly dark beer with complex sweet taste with just a pinch of alcohol, I can see why there¬ís been metal songs written about this stuff.
I can¬ít speak too much for this style as i think this is my first but this was a thick and alcoholic brew that i didn¬ít enjoy that much, but think i would like it on draft.
8th October 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Very dark brown beer. Good carbonation. Treacly and rich, no bitterness. Slighty dry finish. Pretty nice!

Bottle. Dark brown-copper colored pour with a thin ring of foam. Aroma is german, banana-cloves-wheat but with a bit of toast too that cuts into the sweet aromas. Taste is very spicy, lots of cloves, wheat and yeast. Full palate, some alcohol warmth.

12 oz. bottle.  Dark brown pour with light tan head and little carbonation.  Initial smoky aroma followed by rich sweetness.  Not too familiar with the style, but this one is full of flavor.  Coats your throat on the way down.  Very sweet finish considering the high alcohol content.  Little to no bitterness.  Excellent beer.

Bottle @ Home. Dark brown with a small light brown head. Caramel, nuts, brown sugar in nose. Taste is sugary caramel, bit of dark dried fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation, warm alchohol finish . Nice but abit to one dimensional and sweet. 271210

Aroma of chocolate, nougat and estery dark fruit- perhaps some dark cherry. Appearance is dark cola with tan head. Flavor matched the nose, with an emphasis on sweeter molasses and some brown sugar; the mouthfeel was chewy and there was almost no alcohol present. Palate was creamy and slightly bubbly. Nice, but I preferred the Aventinus Eisbock a little more.
UPDATED: JUN 15, 2014 Pours brown with a light brown head. Smell of yeast, malt, caramel, chocolate. Taste of dark fruits, dark malts, yeast, chocolate, some sourness at the end and some alcohol.

Pours extremely dark brown with little to no head and pretty much no lacing as well. Aroma is of dark malts, roasted/toastiness, plums, candied sugar. Flavor is pretty similar to the aroma with some coffee/toffee added in. Medium to full bodied with hints of roasted malts and moderate carbonation. Rather low alcohol presence considering the ABV.

Deep brown with brilliant red hues.  Dark fruit, deep malt aroma, gingerbread.  Smooth, smooth, smooth.  Swirling flavors of toasted malt, dark fruit, dark candy, gingerbread, pumpernickel.  Jello mouthfeel with extremely well hidden alcohol.  A king among bocks!

On Tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Clear brown/ruby, creamy tan head that clings to the glass nicely. Aroma is malty with caramel/molasses, woody, some grassy hops. Full bodied, malty, fruit comes out more on the palate, some raisins and dark fruit. Nice fruit/malt finish, very solid, very smooth. I could drink this all day.

A: The pour is a dark brown color and a bit of a yeasty haziness and a tan head.

S: A really great sweet, milk chocolate note to start this one off. I get some mild roast, lots of dark fruits such as plums, raisins, and dates, as well as a caramel and vanilla sweetness.

T: Starts off with sweet dark fruits, especially raisins and plums. The chocolate is once again potent, creamy, and sweet. A nice toffee and caramel flavor along with a bit of sweet vanilla. The roasted malt is there but not overwhelming at all.

M: The body is medium with a low to medium carbonation. Very smooth and creamy.

D: Probably a little better than the Aventinus Eisbock, and certainly less boozy and harsh. Dangerously easy to drink.

Pours clear, dark mahogany with a 2 finger, chunky beige head that has good retention. Aroma is sweet bread crust, dark caramel, brandy, raisins, faint spicy hops, earthy leaves, toasted cereal and a nice dose of dark fruit. Flavor is crust, sweet, crusty white bread, dark fruit, sweet, roasted nuts, earthy wet leaves, a bit of sweet bread spice and a healthy helping of dark caramel. Palate is medium bodied, sticky and lightly carbonated. Delicious eisbock.

11.2 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a deep, dark brown with ruby highlights and a foamy tan head that disappears quickly to a ring that lasts throughout. Minimal lacing. Nice aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits, caramel, and a pleasant hint of alcohol. Flavor is tilted towards sweet but does have a nice grassy hop character in the background to add some bitterness and balance. Lots of roasted malt, burnt caramel, raisins, even a touch of coffee. Nice warming finish but not overwhelming. Full bodied. Not cloying.

12oz bottle from I cant remember where. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head that soon fades to a fine ring. The aroma is soft with roasted grains, toffee, coffee and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is all toffee, caramel, dates and molasses. The palate is full and malty with soft carbonation. The finish is long with lingering sweet molasses. Overall: A very tasty Eisbock.

Pours deep brown black with ruby tones when light hits the glass. Thick heavy brown head leaving some lacing. Sweet aroma with roasted malts, alcohol, fruits etc. Velvet lean full bodied mouthfeel. Flavor is fruity sweet, caramel, hops, alcohol, chocolate. Really really good. Lean tart sweet palate. Finish is fruity and bitter tart
Pours a deep brown body with a fine white head. Awesome combination of vanilla, caramel, plum, toffee, etc. Really good.
Deep brown in the glass. Rich aroma of dried fruits and dark malt. Exceptionally smooth mouthfeel with slight residual sweetness. Excellent.

33cl bottle from bierkompass. BBE 26.10.2010. Poured cola color with a soapy thin head, disappeared quickly. Aroma is very malty with some sweet fruity notes and alcohol. Flavor very similar, malt, hops and alcohol. Quite sticky. Not really what I expected. Not bad, but too much alcohol in flavor for my taste.

Bottled. A reddish brown beer with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet and malty, notes of vanilla. Taste is also very malty and sweet, notes of dried fruits and vanilla.Noticeable alcohol. Milky texture and full body.

Bizony j√≥ volt

4 oz. @ SIB 2010

Notes
"First eisbock. Tastes very sim. to Asam with double the alc. Darker as well."

0,33 l bottle, S√∂rspecialista.hu.
Deep ruby-brown beer with a small pillowy tan head that melt down to a minimal lacing one. Aroma of licorice, toasted caramel and mild roasted grains, molasses and herbal hops. Thick body, oily and heavy texture, sweet caramel and burnt sugar, some roasted taste with a well balanced carbonation and herbal hop. Strong one!

Bottle pours brown-black with medium tan head.  Aroma malty, dark fruits and a bit sour.  Taste malts, caramel, dark fruits, molasses.  Palate failry thick, a bit sticky, moderately carbonated.  Finish with a bit of bitterness and roast that disappears immediately.  As opposed to other raters I thought the alcohol was pretty well hidden.

Overall I like this one.  Very nice flavor, really the entire package.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small off-white head. Malty aroma with notes of roastiness, alcohol and dried fruits. Flavour is sweetish roasted malt, caramel and dried fruits. Medium to full-bodied.

S√∂t√©t, b√≠borv√∂r√∂s sz√≠ne van ennek a s≈±r≈± s√∂rnek. A tetej√©n keletkez≈ë hab v√©kony, b√©zs sz√≠n≈± √©s gyorsan elolvad, ami el≈ëre figyelmeztet egy magasabb alkoholtartalomra.
