Pours a deep black with a pretty big brownish head.  Malty but very alcoholic head.  The taste is so overwhelmingly alcoholic at first and you have to be ready to try this beer or you may be overwhelmed as I was the first time.  If you carefully taste this beer, you will taste a dark malty, cola (I agree with a previous rater) flavor that is good for small drinks.  You have to approach this beer with some maturity or you will get knocked out by the first very alcoholic taste.

Versa un colore scuro tipo cola con una scarsa schiuma beige. Aroma dolce di grano tostato, frutta scura, caramello, e pane. Il sapore riflette quasi in toto l¬íaroma, con un finale caldo e alcolico ma non fastidiosamente invadente.
Pours a dark cola color with a small beige head. Sweet aroma of roasted grains, dark fruit, caramel, and bread. The flavor is similar, with a warm alcoholic finish.

12oz bottle pours dark brown with amber head and medium tan head. Aroma is very fruity; plums and raisins, caramel, and toffee. Taste has dark roasted malts, dark fruits, toffee, caramel, vanilla, honey, and slight chocolate. Very complex and well balanced flavors all around. I was really looking forward to this and was not let down in the least, awesome!

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2014 Slightly lucent dark mahogany, thin white head, full body, medium carbonation.

Aroma: very sweet, dark, molases, fruity esters, roast grain.

Taste: very sweet malt, dark fruit esters, some warm alcohol.


Lots of nice complex flavor, certainly a sipper rather than a sessional, due to sweetness and alcohol build-up on the palate.

330 ml bottle @ home. BBE 26.10.2010.
Pours a bit transparent brown colour with a small off-white head. Weak Eisbock-style on the nose with wheat, syrup, banana and honey notes. The taste is weak too with roasted malts, banana and brown sugar. Medium bodied, oily/watery mouthfeel and low carbonation. Well hidden alcohol. Average Eisbock, though this bottle is quite old (see BBE). Needs re-rating I guess.

Draught at Biermuseum. Almost black with a fine, tight head. Powerful vinous aroma with port, caramel, dried fruits. Big flavor of figs and raisins, caramel, wine, alcohol. Super sweet, super strong. Syrupy, but the booze cuts it Heavy and smooth, almost flat. Flavorful and dangerously drinkable, but not so original.
Bottle, dark orange/brown with medium beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel. Strong malt taste and quite sweet.  There is some alcohol after burn.

330 mL bottle.  Pours deep red brown with an off-white head.  Aroma has lots of caramel and raisin with a bit of banana.  Flavor leads with the raisin and some molasses, caramel, a bit of biscuit, and a light touch of hot booziness.  Fairly nice.

Bottle: Pour is oily and dark, with a modest tan head. Smells sweet. Toffee, Raisins, Caramel - Flavors are similar with more malt , sweet bread, and the like. I find this beer to be fantastic, frankly, and the alcohol to be modest in taste in spite of the ABV. Theres a mild bite and yet it drinks fairly smoothly. I will definately try this one out again

bottle.  Really excited about this one, my first eisbock.  Pours dark brown / black body with tan / gray head.  Aroma of plum, raisin, sugar, caramel, toffee, wine, cooked vegetables, slightly vinegary.  Maybe this is an older bottle, but with 9% abv the beer should have kept decently well.  This slightly winy, sour aspect is not as noticeable in the flavor, which features burnt marshmellow, raisin and fig, caramelized sweet onion, vanilla, toffee, plum, and molasses.  Pretty damn complex.  Mouth feel is quite nice too, smooth and silky, although there is a subtle alcohol presence.  Honestly this is one or the more unique beers I¬íve had in a long time.  This style is very interesting, and offers a high level of complexity.  Despite its complexity of flavor, it is not oily, syrupy, like many barley wines / imperial IPAs / imperial stouts.  Overall a very good beer, very enjoyable.

330ml bottle from K&L Redwood City.  Pours a dark but clear medium brown color, with a small but well-formed and lasting light tan head sitting on top.  The aroma is excellent - toasty dark bready malt, sweet toffee, sugar plums, prunes, and dates.  The flavor is excellent, with a nice level of sweetness from the caramel malt.  Honey and toffee notes along with dark toast.  Lots of dark fruit notes - date, plum, and prune standing out, along with even a little cherry and chocolate.  Medium-bodied for the style with a slight dryness despite the malty sweetness.  Not boozy at all.  This is a killer eisbock.  I love this style and this one did not disappoint.

330 ml bottle from Bier Stein. Poured a dark, clear brown with a thin cola head. Smells of cherries, plums, booze and toffee. Tastes very sweet, with notes of chocolate, cherries, plums and booze. Very warming beer, and quite the kick for a pretty low price.
Pours a rich amber brown color with tiny brown head.  Aroma is caramel, plum, fruity, toast, and some chocolate.  Flavor is caramel, plum, toast, fruity, some roast, and chocolate.
First Eisbock so not sure how to compare it, but nice aroma and sweet malty taste that improved a bit as it warmed. All in all pretty good, though perhaps a little sweet

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 At a tasting, thanks beer_and_beyond, pours brown with a small head, aroma of dried fruits, plums, nuts, white chocolate, brandy, plum liquor, flavor of plums. cocoa, nuts and alcohol warmth, medium to full bodied.
At a tasting, many thanks Tomer, pours shiny clear red to brown with a small head, aroma of bock beer with soy sauce, caramel, toffee, molasses, honey and malt, sticky mouthfeel with flavors of dried fruits, honey, wood, nuts and cherry liquor, zesty on the tongue, full body. Impressive and addictive

Great aroma of over-ripe fruits (apricot, prunes maybe?)  Very thin off-white head with good carbonation.  Very dark brown in color (almost like a Dr. Pepper or other dark cola).  Medium, creamy mouthfeel.  Nice palate.  Aftertaste is think with alcohol, which I don¬ít like.  But the initial taste in of ripe fruits that reminds me of a Belguim quad.  Good taste but the aftertaste almost ruins it.  To amend:  As the beer warms up, the aftertaste doesn¬ít bother me as much :)  This beer¬ís flavor improves as it warms.  I really enjoyed this beer.  Highly recommended.
This is delicious. The nose after you taste it is the best part. Kumquats, caramel. This is liquid fruitcake.

At a tasting, no head, crystal clear burgundy colour,  aroma of nuts, dried fruits, black peppercorn and flowery and aromatic coffee hints,  flavour of roasted coffee, and bitter chocolate with a suprisingly strong sourness mellowing the roasines, alcohol completly hidden. Amazingly mellow, i wish i had another bottle of this brew right now!
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 This is rather good.  Malty and some dried fruit soaked in booze flavor going on.  Serving: Bottle
Bottle sampled at SIB, pours dark brown. Aroma and flavour of candied fruits, roasted malt, caramel and alcohol. Excellent.

Bottle...  Poured dark, ruby with a beige head.  Aroma of deep fried bready grains and a berry-like alcohol warmth.  Fruity, plum, cherries, sugar, a metallic, leafy, earth tone with a slight malt sweetness.  A little nutty as well.  Really rich, like a fortified bock.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a decent biege head, some lacing.  Aroma of malt and caramel.  Tastes of sweet malt and fruit.  Some alchohol present.  Flavor more intense as it warms.  My first Eisbock.  Pretty good.

bottle.   not sure how old.   what does 1757315 mean?  haven¬ít taken taken cryptography since undergrad.  well shit, this pours a bright brown with nice ruby red highlights shining through.  small frothy darty beige head.    aroma of figs, booze,  ripened plums, red grapes,  and toffee.   nice sweet, smooth, port like body.   light watery dough note.  decent body, but feel a bit watery on the back of the tongue.  just looking at the bottle, one might think this is some goofball shit.  but in reality, this is the shit and all you player hating big booze, tangy plum fig hatin bitches can suck a phat one.  some more medicine in the nose as it warms, some more doughy chocolate in the taste.   nice balance.  well made.  good dessert beer.   if someone knows how to date this let me know.  I know of a nice thai place, but can¬ít afford any of those small plate places at the moment.

Dark, rich mahogany pour with an off-white head.  Aroma of bread, toffee, very sticky sweet.  Rich body with the sweet maltiness I generally associate with doppelbocks: doughy bread, caramelized sugar, raisin.  Little bit of a heat on the finish.  Quite enjoyable to drink despite the density of it.

Bottle,  pours an amber which appears completely brown until held to light. Foam quickly disappears and leaves a flat layer of thin bubbles afterward.  nose is somewhere between toasted and roasted dark malt. Full, rich aroma with a promise of some sweet, gummy flavors. Fairly sweet with caramel, brown sugar and molasses present. Some alcohol also present, making it somewhat like a dessert port or other dark dessert drink. Medium to thinnish body, carbonation is noticeable but not distracting.  Very drinkable beer, but not necessarily more then a couple at a time.

Poured from bottle. Strong nose of raisin, licorice, smoke, and a touch of alcohol. Color is a dark red-brown with a soft, small-grained head that lasts.  The flavor is intense, with sweet malt notes (there is a palpable sweetness to the beer) running neck and neck with alcohol heat -- mostly harmonious, though the boozy heat still kicks through occasionally. Incredibly smooth and rich on the palate. Definitely a must-try.

Bottle sample at homebrew meeting. Pours a dark brown, ruby at the edges. Nose is full of sweet bread, melanoidins. Light prune notes as well as a little cooked asparagus, but in a good way. On taste, it¬ís definitely on the sweetish side and burly. Tastes like what it is, a ramped up doppelbock. Still pretty alright.

Bottle, pours a clear maple syrup w/ a robust fizzy head, aroma is light candy malt and some esters, light bodied, flavor is heavy on the candy malt w/ some dried fruit near the finish, subtle alcohol, barely taste the 9% ABV, very quaffable brew

caramel, coffee, roasty, leather, butterscotch, soy sauce, black, cloudy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, oily feel, thick feel, soft carbonation,
My first Eisbock rating. Pours a clear deep purple with white head. Nose is dark fruits, raisins and bourbon. Taste is mostly raisins, some dark fruit and slight bourbon finish.

Bottle.

A - Dark black with some ruby brown hues on the edge. Small frothy and bubbly off-white head. Reduces fast with just tiny patches of lacing left.

S - Somewhere between toasted and roasted dark malt. Fairly sweet with caramel, brown sugar and molasses present on the nose. Some dark fruit (plum and date especially) and just a faint hint of overly ripe banana. Some alcohol also present, making it somewhat like a dessert port or other dark dessert drink. Full, rich aroma with a promise of some sweet, gummy flavors.

T - Similar to the nose. A lot of rich dark malt. A touch of bread flavors but loads of burnt caramel, brown sugar, molasses, and chocolate are much more dominant. Also a strong amount of dark fruit (strong plum, date, and raisin presence). All these make a sweet sticky, rich flavor. Some alcohol is present but it isn¬ít very strong and really just provides a nice warming touch that also balances the sweetness a bit. Mid sip there is a touch of earthy hops along with a nutty flavor and some dark chocolate and licorice.  The dark malt and fruit comes out again at the end and lingers on the tongue.

M - Full body with moderate carbonation. Very velvety, silky smooth with the flavors having a sticky/lingering aspect. A very full and rich beer.

D - Very drinkable beer. It is a touch too sweet and too high of an ABV to have another in a night, but I certainly would be tempted. I would definitely would have it another night though. Such a rich and smooth beer with a lot of flavor means this is quite a drinkable beer. Makes a wonderful dessert or night capper.

Notes: Best before 14/09/10. A very nice beer that is pretty sweet but not cloying and has enough flavors to balance it out. The alcohol is present and provides a nice warming, but it is very well masked. Very enjoyable beer that is a great way to finish a night. I highly recommend trying it.
Dark, redish brown with a small tan head. Nutty with caramel tones. Sweetness, malt and caramel. Medium to full body with a balanced finish.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a deep mahogany colored body with a big, two-finger width, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is sweet with lots of caramel, brown sugar, molasses, prunes and figs, and other dark fruits. Some cinnamon, toffee, and booze. Flavor is similar. Can feel the alcohol throughout, but stays well hidden and never gets boozy. Sweet with a prune-rum and enough of a hop balance to prevent this from cloying. Lots of brown sugar and molasses with other pitted fruits, licorice, and a light toasted toffee. Finishes dry with some cinnamon and light amount of other spices along with an earthy bitterness. Just a touch of alcohol warmth with a lengthy aftertaste following a full, somewhat syrupy body with just a trickle of carbonation. Overall, a cool beer. Fairly straightforward, but well balanced. The sweetness never gets out of hand thanks to the dry finish. Very nice.
Pours brown with ruby red hues and a cream-colored, 1 finder head.  Big nose of caramel and brown sugar.  Taste is alcohol forward caramel, brown sugar and some raisin, dry and tart. Pretty decent.

Draft at Teresa¬ís. Pours cloudy chesnut brown with a quickly fading, bubbly white head. Dissolves to nothing, leaving no lacing. Aroma is of toffee, cinnamon, caramel, raisins, figs, and sweet malts. Body is rather weak, besides the alcohol, and the palate is sickeningly sweet and carbonated. Tastes too much like a spiked root-beer for me. Not a fan of this style at all.

11.2 oz bottle into snifter. Aroma is malty--caramel and molasses are prominent, cinnamon also. Pours a deep reddish brown with a medium head and foamy lace. Flavor is sweet, then bitter, and finishes with an alcoholic bite that warms the entire upper body. Reminiscent of brandy. Medium carbonation and a somewhat oily texture. I didn¬ít think I¬íd like this, but it is very good. Impressive. Addendum:  I tired of this beer about 3/4 of the way through. It got to be too cloyingly sweet. I think this beer would work better in a 7 oz bottle.

Bottle. Pours deep red-brown with a thin head. Sweet malty aroma, a bit bready, with dried banana chips, plums, vanilla, and caramel. Sweet dried fruity and malty flavor, with dark fruits, caramel, light toasty notes, and light banana. Really good.

Aroma is full of dark fruits, yeasty esters, caramelized sugars and alcohol. Flavor is plums, raisins, figs, toffee, alcohol and chocolate. Flavor/aroma becomes more pronounced as the beer warms. Overall delicious.
A classic Eisbock. Smells of dried fruit and malt. Taste is big cherries, grapefruit and current, even some raison. Body is heavy. Alcohol definitely present.

Served in a snifter glass from a bottle that has been aged for at least 1 year. Dark brown, almost black, with a nice 1 inch head. Picking up rum-like alcohol aromas.  Lots going on with this beer. Some dark fruit notes like raisins and figs with roasted coffee, licorice and the alcohol flavors in the aroma. Don¬ít serve too cold, the flavors intensify as the beer warms.
Full bodied and syrupy mouthfeel.  This is a big beer, very drinkable but I couldn¬ít have more than one. Went well with my thin crust pizza, although I think it would even be better with some additional age.
Not all that great. Went flat. Slightly metallic. Mostly syrupy and brown sugar like flavors, roast malt, not much else. Not half as good as Aventinus. Glad I just got one and not the six-pack.

Deep dark pour in a tasting pint glass.  Little head, and what was there barely stayed.  Aroma is strong and in your face.  It smells strongly of alcohol and dried fruit.  This was not as malty as i expected.  This beer had good dried fruit characters, but was not supported by the malt backbone.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is breaddy malt, sweet caramel, fruity notes. Flavour is sweet caramel, alcohol, light hop, fruity notes.
Bottle from Grape Juice.  Brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, brown sugar, plums, malts, and a little spice.  Taste is sweet spice, more dark fruit, malts, and alcohol.
Bottle. Poured a soda brown with a creamy tan head that settles to a ring. Aromas of prunes and sweet malts. Flavor found dark fruits and chocolate. Medium to full body, sweet and creamy. Nice!

11.2 ounce bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown with a half inch tan head that didn¬ít stay around for very long.  However, there¬ís a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is very malty, the brew smells like caramel malt, dark fruit (raisins, cherries), and toffee.  It tastes like dark fruit, caramel malt, molasses, and a bit of peat. The 9.2% ABV isn¬ít very noticable at all.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, it¬ís a bit creamy and coating, with decent carbonation.  Drinkability is good too, it goes down easy and is enjoyable to drink.  I think this is a good Eisbock, I¬íd buy this again in the future.
Red-Brown. Tan, medium head. Aroma: Caramel malts. Flavor: Malts, caamel, plums, alcahol. Dry, alcahol finish.
At the bierkoning in Amsterdam, deep brown, thin head, lots of spices and fruits, a real taste sensation,  the best eisbock that I have tasted full of good complex flavors and very warming

330 ml bottle. Courtesy of mjs. Shared w/ mjs & FatPhil.
Reddish brown colour with tiny/no head. 
Caramel, cough drop, malt and sugary sweetness in aroma.
Sugary sweetness, malt, berries, candies and some alcohol warmth in flavour. 9.2% is not much noticeable.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2016 330ml bottle (Berlin) - shared by mjs - thanks! (6:4:7:4:14=3.5)
Deep red, no head. Sweet bocky aroma - smells sticky. Smooth soft
palate, some crisp carbonation is nice. Bananaey retronasals. Taste
also quite bananaey, and vey bocky - full of sweet malts. A touch
alcoholic, but nowhere near 9.2%. Compared to my previous eisbock this is very mellow, and not harsh at all. Great balance, but mostly malt based. The hops are a little papery, but not offensively so, in fact they¬íre quite fresh and almost buddy. Nice one.
Rerate: Tap (Alus Biblioteka, Vilnius) (7:4:6:4-:13=3.4-)
A bit heavy, actually has some heat to it. Still pretty decent for a malt head. Nice to do a format-tick rerate of, certainly.

(Bottle from Bier-Spezialit√§ten-Laden, Berlin) Poured reddish brown and clear without any head. Aroma contained malts, molasses, treacle and mild roastedness. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, treacle, chocolate, mildly grass and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter.

Cereal malt aroma with some wet cardboard in the mix.  Nice clear ruby brown color.  You can really taste the alcohol...  somewhere lost in the taste, some fruity malt comes through.  Overall it¬ís OK, but a really strong alcohol flavor
This beer was GREAT. Nose and palate of chili peppers, it was great for warming up to in the winter, but I¬íd love to have it with some light summer fare as well. So good!

Aroma of malt and alcohol, with yeasty notes, pours a dark amber-brown with ruby highlights.  Impressive palate strikes the tongue with roasty, toasty, malt (not porter, think doublebock) with a notes of alcohol with the accompaning warming.  This is my kind of beer, very malty with complexity.  Can¬ít wait to hit up more Eisbocks....

Bottle at Esbjerg Beerfestival. A copper to brown beer topped by a minimal off-white head. Slightly vinous nose with dried fruits and a light roasted scent. Vinous flavor with dried fruits, some roasted malts, a slight vegetal hint and a good dash of sweetness. Full-bodied and warming, finishing sweet and warming. More balanced and smooth than EKU28, making it a quite lovely beer for an hour by the fire. 091023

Pours a deep reddish brown with a good head and a bit of lace, something I don¬ít know that I have ever seen from this style of beer. The aroma is nutty and mildly roasty with some molasses, some apple, and some booze. The flavor is very nice with plenty of hazelnut and dark fruit. The alcohol is very concealed with some cherry notes in the back. Very tasty beer, the easiest drinking of any I¬íve had within this style.

This beer had a very nice aroma dominated by the tobacco therein.  It rolls on the palate for several seconds with a mixture of tobacco, vanilla and chocolate.  It is quite honestly the best beer I¬íve ever had.

Bottle sample at work.  My first Eisbock... I really enjoyed it!
  It almost seems as if there are two beers working together in this one brew.
  Aroma is a bit light, but inviting.  A malty experience with a bit of an alchohol... but not astringent, pleasent.
  Appearance is a rustic amber brown, clear with a minimal off white head.
  Wow, taste was something I haven¬ít really experienced before.  A sweet overtone stayed with me the entire time, but it didn¬ít seem to stem from the malt.
  Body is medium and a bit creamy, soft carbination leads to a medium long finish that remains sweet but... something. It keeps beconing for me to take another drink.  I¬ím intrigued.

33cl bottle. Pours with a frothy one finger tan head that soon settles to all but nothing. Beneath is a clear, deep ruby. A slight thickness on the glass. Huge deep malty notes: chocolate, prunes, fig, cakey a bit of raspberry in there and some alcohol in the back. Full and pruney, lots of bright sweetness, toffee quite juicy finishes with liquorice with a lingering bittersweet end. Medium to full on the palate, a bit of carb. bite.

Sampled at Binny¬ís of Glen Ellyn, IL. After Dinner Tasting. Poured to a small snifter a deep brown hue with some garnet tones showing through, off white/light tan foam to the head, and ribbons and spots of clingy lacing. The aroma was strong malt, alcohol, dark fruit and brown sugar sweetness. The flavor added to these, warming alcohol and a light hop bitterness, but seemed a little thinner than what was projected by the nose. A light stickiness was also part of the mouthfeel. Still very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a spotty beige head, appears clear ruby when held to the light.  Nose is really malty, not overly sugary, with lots of nice dark fruits, peat, a little smoke.  Very good.  Sweet and a bit peaty/smokey in the mouth.  Dark fruits like figs and dates shine.  A little too much residual hop bitterness, though that¬ís kind of nitpicky.  I guess I¬íd like it to be a little creamier and more thick.  This is maybe the first eisbock I¬íve had, and it¬ís bold, pretty strong, balanced, and impressive.

Pours a thick dark brown color with a soapy tan head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of caramel, nuts, and dark fruit.  Flavor of caramel, dark fruit and nuts.  Smooth mouth feel.  Great for a cold night.

haven¬ít sampled many eisbocks so this is still kind of new territory for me. deep dark brown color, tan head. aroma like malts and ripe fruit. flavor is sweet, powerful, malt, ripe fruits, and some wood. very satisfying on the palate, feels the way it should.

Bottle.  Not the fancy bottle shown.  It had a much different label.  The beer pours to a really deep dark mahogany body with a foamy thick tan head.  The aroma is bright.  Huge sweet malts and pine hops.  Almost like a liquid sugar and tobacco combination.  Deep oily tobacco.  The flavor is heavily malted with sweet molasses and barley.  Dusty nougat.  Grain dust.  Dark prunes.  The palate is medium bodied and clean and nicely carbonated.

11oz bottle. 1996 Vintage. Sticker on the bottle -> Vintage July 11, 1996 Number 38,656. Poured a medium to deeper mahogany color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of toasted nuts (lots of nuttiness), caramel and some dark fruits in the background. Tastes of nuts (not as much as the aromas), toffee, caramel, lighter dark fruits, and toasted malts. This has aged nicely and I¬ím enjoying it!

Pours from the bottle to a dark brown color with little head or lacing, but that¬ís all that went wrong. Nose is a very complex mix of licorice, coffee and malty toffee, but at various times, I also got bubblegum and cotton candy. Mouthfeel was very full and pleasantly biting, and the taste built on those complex scents in the nose. Although the 9.2% abv was well hidden in both the nose and taste, it made itselfd known by way of the long warming finish.

A ver enjoyable beer on a cold night.
Clear copper with a small off-white head. Weakish aroma of caramel, dried fruits, vineous alcohol and malt. Sweet caramel malty flavour with vineous and warming alcohol.
Draft @ Blind Tiger. Mahogany pour with a light tan head. Plumy aroma with some malt backing it up. Nice flavor, toffee, dark fruits, nuts, and even some maple notes, slight warming.

Bottle at the Fox River House in Appleton, Wisconsin. Pour was medium to deep golden brown with an aroma of toffee, sweet wheat, and light fruit. Yum, the flavors were well blended and on the sweeter side, which hid the alcohol quite well. Smooth, well attenuated brew that hit the spot. This is worth a try.

Bottle. Cellared for about a year.

Dark reddish brown with a small off-white head leaving small lacings.

The aroma is nice and round, but rather one-sided - malty with notes of dark fruits, wood and alcohol. 

The flavor is very sweet with prominent malty flavors, fudge and lots of sweet fruits. Notes of wood and alcohol. Ends mildly bitter and sweet with a warming feeling from the alcohol.

Medium body, smooth oily texture.

Decent. Seems like cellaring made this one sweeter. Would probably be even better with one more year to it.

Dark browm, rootbeer like liquid, medium head similiar to a cola that dissapated after 2-3 minutes.  Malty aroma.  Taste is rather one dimesional, sweet finish.  Not as good as The Urbock Dunkel Eisbock.

12oz brew from gourment beer of the month club, pours a solid cola color which is actually alot of fun, there are red flares streaking and solid dark brown shades which make this brew a pleasure to drink.  Head starts fast and ends the same, elimnated quickly.  Taste is pure goodness! With hints of rasins, black licorice and dark cholocate and some caramel, this is solid! The abv is snugged into the greatness of this brew which allows for total satisfaction.  I could sip these all day... well not exaclty, but you get my point.  The taste is just that good.  A brew Im glad Ive tried.  Quite a wonderful experience.

Dark, thick brown with an off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel and roasted malt. Flavor is the same, chewy sweet cinnamon-raisin bread. This tastes like a slightly German Abbey Quad. Much smoother than the Aventinus Eisbock.

Pours a shiny dark maroon with airy eggshell head. Malty aroma with green apple, laffy taffy, toffee, and strawberry. Flavor has notes of malt, caramel, and black cherry . It¬ís sweet and malty, yet the flavors seem a bit distant. There¬ís almost a delay in flavor where a huge bomb of sweet malt hits you a bit later than is usual. A delicate, velvet mouthfeel. I¬ím digging this. This is my first eisbock, and I imagine it won¬ít be my last.
Sampled at D√òE Beerfestival 2009, Esbjerg. Pours a clear brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt and caramel. The flavor is malt. The palate has some alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.

bottle poured a ruby brown in color with a cap of off white head. aroma has dark rich malt, plumb, raisin, yeast, and alcohol on the end. mouth feel is medium with a heavy coating and lower carbonation. flavor has dark fruit, raisin, fig, dark malt, caramel, molasses sweetness, and again some heat on the end. real rich stuff, winter sipper.
Pours reddish brown with a tan head.  Aroma is lots of caramel, with a little dark fruit and cocoa.  Flavor is full of caramel malt, with nice notes of bitter chocolate and roastiness.  Very good.

12oz bottle.  Pours dark copper with a moderate off white head, some spotty lacing left on the glass, thick legs.  Nose held cat food, black cherry fruit cake, finishes with some butterscotch and vanilla.....Light to medium carbonation.

Big and tasty.  Pretty hot.  Can even smell the alcohol in this bitch.  But it¬ís dark, fruity, and pretty damn awesome.  Got a bit of a hop hint in the background, but is mainly dominated by big malt and dark fruits, but is nicely balanced nonetheless.  Sexy.

Pours a deep brown mahogany with red highlights. 
Nose smells just like fruit cake, dried fruit and molases. 
Taste is moderately sweet, dry finish, peaches, caramel, slight bitterness, with low booze heat.
Pours a deep mahogany with a thin off white head. Aroma is Malty alcohol with some caramel and a hint of raisins.  Flavor is smooth, malty, bready with a warm almost vinous quality.  Tasty beer.

Bottle. Poured a dark amber color with a nice two finger white head. Aroma was bread, toffee, and sweet malts. Flavor was fruits, toffee, and a nice vanilla flavor. Finish is somewhat bitter. Alcohol can be felt as the beer warms. Medium body. A great beer.

Pours dark chestnut brown, with a one-and-a-half finger tan head, very fine lacing.  Rich woody aroma, with cherry and toast, leather, and some light grass notes.  Full, thick body, smooth, lightly tart and dry.  Chewy toffee flavor, toast, some cherry and citrus, grass and a little mineral undertone, warming, with a lasting lightly bitter finish.

330ml Bottle ¬ñ 99 Bottles ¬ñ Federal Way, WA  
Aroma: Sweet deep malt aroma with lots of alcohol.  
Appearance: Dark brown in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big alcohol and sweet malt flavor.  Lots of dried fruit flavor add to the brew.  
Palate:  Dry Sweet finish with a Great Mouthfeel.  
Overall: This was a great Eisbock and the flavors where above average.  This is strong and has a big bite drink it slow.

This is my first ever eisbock so I am not sure how this compares to the style standard, but it tasted good to me.

Pours dark brownish/red with red highlights. Not much of a head. The aroma is a mix of alcohol and caramel malt with a lot of malty sweetness. The predominant flavor is nuttyness as well as alcohol, dark fruit and malt. Not too much hop flavor. Tastes about like a concentrated bock, which judging from the way it is made, is probably what the brewers were going for. Medium mouthfeel and definitely a sipper.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2011 Rerated bottle thx to gnoff 2011-01-08 G√∂teborg
New rating 3,7- keeping old i.e. 3,8

2008-12-15, bottle, G√∂teborg, 2008 edition
Doft: rostat kaffe. F√§rg: l√§tt avslagen Pepsi Cola.
Bra skumkrona, f√∂rsvinner dock tyv√§rr relativt snabbt.
Smak: m√∂rk kaffe, choklad. Oljig.
Det var ett tag sedan man smaken en Eis, bitte!

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown with ruby highlights and a small light tan head. Aroma is very sweet, pretty much all malt, cloyingly sweet , a bit of a dark fruitiness, candy forward, some honey and caramel. Flavor starts with a basic malt sweetness, sugary with some toasted malt, a little bit bready. The alcohol starts to come midway and remains through the finish which is accompanied by a little bit of brown sugar and dried fruits. No hops or bitterness. Medium body and a fairly soft carbonation. I don¬ít know Eisbock¬ís too well, not sure I am a fan, this was okay I suppose

RnH: Extreme Winter:  my first Eisbock, not disappointed at all... After reading how the beer is created, I am even more interested... I feel the style is close cousins with a barley wine with lots of fermented dark fruits, high warming esters... at first I felt the beer was a bit on the thin side, however this adds to the drinkability.

Chestnut brown color with a semi-thick cream colored head.  The color has garnet hues and mahogany tones.  Very interesting appearance.  The head thins rather quickly but holds to the glass well.  Strong aroma of brown sugar and dried fruits: figs, dates, and brandied raisins.  Rich taste that isn¬ít as sweet as the nose would indicate.  Instead it¬ís a mouthful of toast and tart fruit.  Medium booziness fades into a surprisingly bitter hoppiness.  The high alcohol content is noticeable, for sure, but not overpowering.  Instead, the alcohol provides a nice backdrop for the roasty malts and hop bitterness.  Exceptionally well balanced and shockingly drinkable given the full flavor profile and high ABV.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Tried this on tap at Rattle¬ín¬íHum and at The Ginger Man.  Pretty sweet for the style, a little syrupy.  Not very fruity, but well hopped.  I tasted plenty of malt and brown sugar. Revisited in 2016 - we had some of this at a  Beer Judging class. Vanilla, toasted coconut, caramel, hazelnut, a bit syrupy.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2016 Bottle. Aroma of alcohol, malt, and grain. It poured a deep brown color with foam that vanished after about 3 minutes. The taste was top notch; the 9.2% alcohol is hidden exceptionally well and I tasted notes of caramel, bread, and cereal. Smooth and slippery on the way down. All in all, this is a great eisbock at a bargain price! Scoop up a bottle and enjoy. Cheers!

Maroon color, see-through, with a tiny bubble head that sticks to the edges.  
No lacing to speak of.
Aroma of maple syrup and nutmeg.
Sweet maltiness, somewhat on the syrupy side.
Medium body, average I suppose for the style.
Nice enough if you like the style, not really my taste.

Decided to buy this beer because of a rather healthy alcohol to cost ratio. Wasn¬ít the best idea, but I am glad I tried this monster of a beer. Anyway, pours with very little head... goes away very soon and leaves no lacing. Pours a rather impenetrable brown colour. Aroma of licorice and beef jerky... seriously. The taste of the beer is overpowering. Extremely sweet. Lots of licorice. Sends tingles through your body with even the smallest sip. Fruity, with the ever so slight amount of hop bitterness. A little bit too much for me. This is the kind of beer that should only be drank when you are ready for it and want exactly the taste it will give you, otherwise I wouldn¬ít really suggest this monster to most.

THOUGHTS: I love finding these rare eisbocks, There was nothing too special about this one, but it was very nice. One of the good lagers.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark mahogany with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. The aroma was heavy grain, cereal and caramel malts; light hops; toffee, light butterscotch and alcohol. The initial flavor was rather sweet; while the finish was sweet, light to moderately bitter and an average to long duration. There was caramel, grain, malt, malt and more malt, slight hops, toffee, molasses and alcohol. The medium to full body was fairly syrupy and a little oily with fizzy carbonation and a lightly alcoholic, slightly metallic and slightly dry finish.

The aroma Is earthy with rich malt undertones reminiscent of fresh beer being brewed in the kettle. The flavor is on the sweater side which lends itself nicely to the thicker mouth feel of the beer and I also found the beer that the beer has a nice alcohol finish.
 
In my opinion the Kulmbacher Eisbock is darker in color, lighter in flavor but still very Comparable to Samichlaus.

( 12oz bottle thanks to mar) pours clear medium brown, head that fades to thin ring, and great lacing. Nose of alcohol,tobacco, vanilla, rum, dried fruit, and chocolate. Taste is very flavorful, chocolate, creamy, dried fruit, alcohol, and rum soaked raisins. Nice thick creamy mouthfeel and delicious.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/8/09 


Aroma: Sweet nose consisting mostly of caramel, toffee, and dark fruits with some dough and earth

Appearance: Clearish brown color with a slight red hue with a dense, quickly dissipating tan head

Flavor: Taste is relatively sweet with a big malty flavor, similar to the nose, some alcohol in the end palate

Palate: Full bodied and rich, this beer has a nice mouthfeel and a mild alcohol burn 

Overall Impression: 
My first Eisbock rating!  This is a darn tasty beer.  I really liked this one quite a bit.  I have to admit I didn¬ít really know much about this style, but I like it.  A really nice beer for sure with a pretty cool (no pun intended) back-story.

Not sure who left this in my fridge but I sure tried it fast. A full bodied beer with lots of flavor, dark dried fruits, sweet carmel and malt, dusky grains and a nice warmness made for a nice evening drink. It not too expensive I will buy next time I see it.
bottle, dark brown color with nice foam, aroma has a lot of fruit and licorice, flavors of plum, chocolate, port wine, good beer

2009 Bottle - Pours clear and beautiful reddish amber with a small off white head..aroma is dk fruit and sweet toffee malt...flavour is similar, caramel, apple and dry grain...rich malt, but not too much going on besides that taste-wise....

Bottle.

Dark brown. large white head. Sweet aroma of raisins, dried fruit, alcohol.

The beer was  full bodied and strong with hints of alcohol. Tasted raisins, malt, dried fruit, some coffee and brown sugar. Sweet it was, but in a good way.

Aftertaste was long and warming. A good beer!

Strong bock flavor but flavor dissipates quickly after.  The beer tastes like a good bock where the bottom falls out quickly after.  It is interesting how this beer was first brewed and discovered but I still prefer a traditional double bock to this beer.  Neat story to tell though.  Wish it was a bit more of a "warming winter beer" with more substance.
Dark ruby brown with a medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, bourbon and an earhty undertone. Taste is somewhat sweet with alcohol, caramel and berry. Medium smooth body.

poured out clear brown with a nice tan beige head that was bubbly and fell pretty thick.  the body is deep, deep maroon with no carbonation movement at all that i could see.  the aromas are watery, ripe dark fruits, slight sugar, and a slight biscuit smell.  it is medium bodied with nice notes of alcohol, and a sweetness that was very nice.  i taste carmelized sugar, plums and grape.  i also get a bitter malt taste which is pretty strong.  there are hints of alcohol throughout the whole body is really potent.  it finishes a little dry with an aftertaste of plum and sugar which was kind of strong and lasted a really good while.  very interesting beer to drink.

Very dark brown and filtered. Nose chocolate, roasty, dough, alcohol, prunes.
Taste is medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, very alcoholic. Full body, sticky, lively, long finish.
Nice winter beer that sticks with you.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Fading tan head with a clear, brown, copper highlighted body.  Aromas of roasted grain and dark sugars.  Flavors of roasted grain, wheat, rye, molasses, vanilla, cedar.  Barrel aged?  Alcohol, complex, little dry finish.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Decent  Smells of molasses, raisins, and fermented fruit.  Tastes of bitter-sweet alcohol, concentrated fruit, cough syrup, sherry. Smooth and medium bodied. Pretty good stuff. Was looking for something a little more rich, but nice complexity.
Moderate malty aroma with heavy notes of spices. Large, frothy, off-white head. Good lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear, red brown body. Moderate bitter and very spicy flavor. Medium palate.

Pretty solid representation of the style.  Clear, dark mahogany color with a 1/4 inch caramel head that left a bit of lacing.  Aroma isn¬ít as aggressive as one might expect for the weight...lots of sugary malt, toffee, coffee, and cocoa.  Flavor possesses some nuttiness accompanied by honey, vanilla, and caramel.  Medium mouthfeel.  Good beer.

Good Eisbock.  A real malt atomic bomb.  I¬ím not sure that I¬íd ever want more than one in a sitting.  There¬ís not a ton to say about it.  It tastes like a bock extract, all candied dates, raisins, brown sugar and syrupy French toast.  It¬ís much more of a straight German malt sweetness than the Aventinus banana bread treacle, though both are pleasant in their own right.  I¬ím probably being generous on appearance.  The head is a joke but I¬íll give it the benefit of style comparison.  Good beer for a cold, hungry night.

Beer starts with an excellent german dark roasted grain aroma.  Beer poors deep mahogony with a slight white head.  Flavor is excellent with hints of plum and raisin.  Beer finish is suprising as I expected a sticky finish due to the alchol but this wasn¬ít the case.  Overall this beer was excellent and I look forward to having it again

Dark brown with a small light beige head. Aroma is a nice balance of dark fruit and green appleish esters. Malty and very inviting. Flavour is less exiting, almost a bit "watery" for the strenth and the rather full body with its light but lively carbonation. A solid brew that could use alittle more of everything.
Bottle. Goodness, this was a very tasty beer. Dark color. Nice date, fig, coffee, pleasant flavor. Warms one¬ís belly. Nice beer to enjoy after a day on the slopes. Highly recommended.

Bottle 33cl. Pours an dark brown brew with small quickly disappearing head. Clear filtered. Dark raisins and fruits, chocolate and toffee notes, sizzling. Massive alcoholic impression but well balanced overall. Nice Bock.

[2590-20091114] 11.2floz bottle. Strong date roast aroma. Slightly hazy, dark brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Sweet strong date roasty malt flavour is rich. Medium-full body. Very tasty, lots going on.
(w/ DuctTape, jerc)

Bottle. Pours a clear red-brown color with a foamy tan head. Aroma is raisins, caramel, dark fruits, alcohol, plums. Flavor is very malty, raisins, soy. Dry mouthfeel and well carbonated. Was hoping it would have a more syrupy mouth.

~12oz bottle poured into a dimpled mug.  KE pours dark ruby with a linen-colored small to moderate head.  The aroma is quite sweet with raisins, candi sugar, malt, cooked red cabbage and alcohol being noticible.  The body is just above medium in heaviness and comes across as oily.  The flavors follow the nose with some notable exceptions.  There is no cabbage taste and a mild hop bedrock carries this beer through the palate.  The hops really shine in the finish saving this beer from being overly sweet.  I wasn¬ít thrilled with the overall package at first but it quickly grew on me before I was even halfway through the beer.  If it isn¬ít to your liking at first I encourage you to stick with it.  The alcohol warms the belly nicely and the sweetness mellows as your body becomes accustomed to the brew.

A dark-reddish brown beer with a nice 1 finger head. The aroma is sweet as is the taste which was malty with a grainy taste, & caramel. Very smooth for 9.2% ABV & I was impressed with the alcohol¬ís hidden ability.

Aroma: weird, funky cooking, mushroom, dark malt, some hops, dates. 
Flavour: sweet, salty & profoundly malty. Almost soylike. Sweet & fullbodied. Very foody, malty & mushroomlike. Banana icecream. Dried fruit. 
Palate: not bad. Smooth, small bubbles. Not very sticky. Bold. 
Appearance: clear, raisin brown w/ yellowish foam.

Bottle from Bier-Spezialit√§ten-Laden, Berlin. Pours dark brown with a big, beige head. Potent caramel aroma. Tastes of sweet caramel and licorice, yet remains very drinkable. Full-bodied as can be. The Angela Merkel of the beer world: solid, moderately complex, surprisingly strong, yet restrained. Overall easy to digest.
Full bodied. Rich brown color. Caramel and molasses flavors without the burnt flavors of some stoudts. syrupy texture, soft carbonation.
Bottle from beers of europe. Pour burnt ruby with a white head. Low carbonation. Aromas of toffee, caramel, bitter chocolate. Flavours of malts, caramel, licorice. Bitter sweet finish.

(Bottle) Reddish brown colour with firm, creamy, beige head. Malty nose with notes of dried fruit, chocolate, toffee, liquorice and hints of alcohol (a bit like cherries in brandy). Malty taste with dried fruit, coffee, dark rye bread, chocolate, liquorice and a finish with a touch of spicy hops, toasty malt and warming alcohol. Full body, fairly sweet (but not as sweet as I expected). Smooth and rounded mouthfeel with an almost overwhelming malt character. Excellent balance. Lovely beer.

Serving: Draft.
Appearance: Very deep brown with garnet highlights and a small tan head.  The head disappears fairly quickly.
Aroma: Caramel, dark dried stone fruit, plum, and some brown sugar.  Very nice.
Flavor: Mirrors the nose with notes of caramel, prune, plum, dried cherries, brown sugar, spice, and a decent bitterness.  Sweet with warming alcohol.
Palate: Low carbonation with a rich mouthfeel and medium-long, sweet finish.
Overall: This is a great beer for those cold winter nights.  Well done!

Poured in a snifter. Beautiful dark amber color with a small head that disappears rather quickly. No lacing. Smells of big malts, some caramel, and brown sugar. Taste was huge in malt, brown sugar, raisins, and maybe some darker cherries. Really a good brew that gets a lot better as it warms up. Great for this time of year when it¬ís getting cold outside and you¬íre looking to warm up with a beer that has a lot of depth. One of my new favorites.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a nice looking deep dark brown with red hues and tan head. Aroma is of pure clean strong malt, prune and nice chocolate. Flavor is the same with nicely balanced bitter and nice warming alcohol spice. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable beer....good shit! Yum!

pours dark brown/copper, thick mocha head.
Aroma is malty, some hops and friots, light herbal scent and yeast.
Taste, malty, with plenty of caramel and chocolate.
Boozy mouthfeel, some fruits; prune and grains, hint sof spices in the finish, thick caramel syrupy palate.

11.2oz bottle. First eisbock I¬íve had. Black and opaqe with a pretty tan head - very nice looking, and the darkest lager I¬íve seen. The color contrast of the fairly light head and the black beer is very appealing. Aroma of caramel, candy sugar, figs, lots of plum, and almost a little wood. Beautiful rich caramel flavor, heavy and lots of depth. Chocolate, raisins, molasses, even a little cherry can be found. This beer has a lot of weight to it - the body¬ís heavy, very smooth and pleasant on the tongue. A bit of warming alcohol shows through, reminding me that this is a big beer. A big success, as well - eisbock is a rare treat, and I¬íll certainly be searching for more of them.

Bottle thanks to nqualls.  Admission up front, this isn¬ít really my favorite style.  Dark dark brown, creamy light tan head.  Big prune aroma, caramelized sugar, caramel, cocoa.  Taste is more fruity, prunes, plums, caramel, sugar, very sweet, light alcohol warmth.
Bottle. Brown colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel and dark fruits. Sweet fruity flavor with notes of alcohol. Lasting finish. Creamy palate.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a paperthin light copper head that diminishes quickly to nothing and a lot of carbonation. The aroma is sweet caramel malt with dark fruit. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet fruity malt flavor with raisin and cherries. Hides the alcohol very well making it easy to drink. A very impressive Eisbock from Kulmbacher.

Cool looking bottle. Pours dark brown body with a ruby tint when held to a light. Small biege, short lived head. Dark fruity, caramel, malty aroma. Good balance of sweet fruits and malty flavor with an overall alcohol burn. Medium-full bodied. Alcohol is somewhat detectable. Tasty beer.

Bottle. Great beer. Dark brown with  medium brown head quickly diminishing. Aroma sweet malty, bread, sugar, dried fruits, dates, figs. Taste sweet malty, some alcohol burn, bread, dried fruits and a little bitterness. This is a beer after my head, so nice.
33cl bottle. Hazy nut brown body with small head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and notes of alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 Pours dark cola with a thin tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, sweet malt, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is more of the same, syrupy sweet, maple syrup, and a little medicinal alcohol.  Very nice.
05.03.2004, 0,33l Bottle. The colour is black. Rich beer with a nice malty aroma. Very nice bitterness combined with the strong alcohol level. This beer tastes a lot and I really likes it!
Pours brown with an off white head. The aroma is a lite banana one. Flavor is sweet and malty. Finishes on molasses notes.

Bottled (BB 12/2009). 
Dark nut brown color, small beige head. Very bready, ryeish aroma with caramelly hints. Flavor has ryebread, toasted malts,  raisins, plums .. overall semi-sweet. Suprisingly also some cardboard. Some similarities to Celebrator. Not mindblowing eisbock, but overall enjoyable.

12 oz bottle from Oak Tree. Poured a deep mahogany brown with deep scarlet edges and a large foamy light beige head. Sticky sweet aroma of buttered raisin toast, prunes, plum, chocolate, brown sugar, toffee. Full dry body that is much drier then I was expecting. The flavor is nicely balanced between the sweet aroma and dry body. Notes of raisin, brown bread, plum, prune, wood, sugary toffee. Really nice and very well done, highly enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep reddish brown color with a large, but fleeting beige head.  The aroma is sweet malty, caramel/toffee, ripe fruits, slightly woody, and slightly vinous.  The flavor was more sweet malts, caramel, ripe fruits, woody, light chocolate,  with some earthy bitterness in the finish.  This is medium bodied and silky smooth.  Where is the alcohol?  This is very drinkable at 9.2%.

Source:12 oz bottle from a sixer purchased at Frugal MacDoogal¬ís in Nashville.Glass:Fuller¬ís snifter. 
Appearance:Deep mahogany pour with a one finger beige head that lingered. 
Aroma:Sweet malts, caramel, chocolate, red wine, alcohol and oak.  A hint of sour cherries.
Flavor:Sweet malt, red wine, toffee, chocolate and cherries.  Flavor was not as pronounced as the aroma. 
Palate:Medium body with mild carbonation.
Overall:This lived up to the hype.  Thought the aroma was awesome, the flavor was very good, not great.  Glad I have more.

(bottle). Dark brown color. Medium tan head. Aroma of molasses and alcohol. Sweet malt flavor with molasses and light wood, grapes, and alcohol. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.
We are in a beer tasting club, several of us get together in honolulu and rate 8 beers every week.  We have our own scales as well as the scale used on this website to record our fun weeks!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2010 Hell yeah bottle thanks to beerman6686 and a darklord day trade pours black and clear with a reddish hue around the edges and a tan whippy  head the color reminds me a lot of a swarz , the aromas are of malts, caramel,licorice,and dark fruits taste is roasted caramel malts,vanilla and picking up wood like oak and a little chocolate and licorice this might be the best lager I have ever had smooth and sweet and the alcohol is well hidden a masterpiece truely amazing brew

This poured easy and tasted even better. Aroma was sweet like molasses and flavor was smooth and nutty. Low carbonation and easy to drink. Maybe the alchol content is higher but I couldn¬ít tell by the taste. A treat!
Tasted at the San Diego International Beer Festival.  Dark copper with a creamy tan head.  Sweet malty aroma and taste with a sugary finish.

Bottled 33cl. Courtesy of joss. It pours a beautiful deep ruby brown beer with a creamy beige head which leaves a beautiful lacework. A huge amount of walnuts in the nose with hints of wood, caramel, marzipan and candy appearing. Reminiscence of some ageing. Quite a lot of walnuts in the taste. Low carbonation. Full bodied. Sweet. Great long sweet finish with a lingering sensation of walnut and sesame. Thanks a lot joss!

How did I get such a highly rated beer for so cheap? Vintage of course. $2 for a 12 oz bottle.  A darker thicker beer. Has a sweeter wheat aroma, quite enticing. Strong and thick on the buds from  the beginning. Thick and oily alky impressions. Truly dizzying after a while and in yer face. Alky flavors almost like high gravity cheap american beers but stronger and thicker. Perhaps a bit more palatable than those cheapo HGs. Difficult to handle for this lager wooss any horn. I guess  they can¬ít sell this in some states, woohoo. hheheheh
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This was my first Eisbock and all I can say is what took me so long to try this style. Poured from a bottle into a snifter. A nice dark brown color which looked similar to maple syrup. All types of stuff seemed to be going on in the aroma and sort of reminded me of port wine. Taste is really smooth and the alcohol never comes to the forefront. Picked up dried fruits, spicy hops and some sweet malt. It just really mixed well together.

bottle thanks to my brother.    dark brown with a nice cream head.  nose is raspberries, sweet malts and some roastiness.  very smooth on the palate with a berry flavor that has a hint of caramel in it.   very smooth and very drinkable.

Pours a dark amber brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma strong of roasted malt, alcohol, and dried fruit.  Flavor matches, but alcohol overwhelms the senses in this one.  Bitterness shines through eventually and the aftertaste is more pleasant than the initial taste.  Drinkable, but nothing I need very often.

12 oz. served in a pint glass.  Excellent, syrupy sour cherry aroma, and crystal clear dark amber or red in color.  No head to speak of, though it did pour well.  Great caramelly and roasted flavor.  Can definitely taste the alcohol.

Dark ruby pour. Strong aroma. Smells of fermented fruit and aged grapes. Definitely a red wine type of flavor with a slightly dry finish. Alcohol is not tasted at all. My first eisbock and a superb sample!

Very dark brown with amber highlights. No head.

 Fruity. Warm alcohol. Not really sweet. Not bitter.

Fizzy, medium body.

 Not really a style for me. Too flat, too alcohol balanced.

 Purchased at New Beer Distributors, New York

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2012 33 cl. bottle. Pour a thick but short lived head, over a clear dark amber (SRM 20) body..... nose of raisin, plum, ginger, cinnamon, no hops, minimal alcohol....tastes of molasses, spices, with rich malty sweetness throughout, and  a mild bitter dry finish.....mouth feel is thick and chewy. Meets the style to a "T". I won¬ít change the initial rating, but the description!! Nose is heavy with dried fruits, plum, raisin, cherry, also brown sugar, light molasses.....taste is heavy roasted malts with cherry dominating the plum, raisin, leading to light molasses, then a bit of spice bitterness...mouth feel thick, chewy, sticky, carbonation low.

Bottle. Aroma of caramel, bread, dried fruit and alcohol. Deep dark brown with a very small tan head that completely vanishes. Sweet malty flavor of bread and sugar, just a very slight bitterness. Creamy smooth mouth feel with a mild carbonation, medium to full bodied. Exceptional beer that goes down almost to smooth, alcohol very well hidden.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 On tap at stumbling monk. Dark hue with nice sweet aroma and a great balanced sweet taste with dark fruity sweetness.

re-rate bottle. same review, upped taste for upholding balance

This poured a dark red/briown color with an off white head. Aroma was lots of dark fruits, some maltiness and alcohol as well. Flavor was dark fruits, some caramel, malty, a bit roasted and some alcohol warmth as well.

Sample @ Bock&Rock.Caramel and malt aroma with hints of fruit.Poured a dark red with a decent beige head.Tasted like it smelled malty sweetness and a good alcohol warming in the mouth.Good brew,would like to have a full bottle.

330ml bottle 
9.2% ABV 
I tried this beer on April 27, 2009 at the "Beer Bistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a semi-translucent reddish brown with a thin tan head.  The aroma was sweet malt, some yeast, and plums.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was sweet malt, molasses, and some plums.
In my opinion this is the best eisbock that I have tasted full of good complex flavors and very warming

bottle thanks to RCL.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is very malty with raisins and caramel.  Taste is same, but better.  Vinous fruit, dates and caramel.  Mouthfeel is medium with slight alcohol.  Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 11.2 oz bottle served in a snifter. Dark cola in color. Carbonation of a flat soda. Large, frothy beige head. Little lacing. Sweet aroma of caramel, diluted brandy, and toasted raisin muffins. Medium body. Quite a bit of carbonation on the palate also. Alcohol is present as brandy satured prunes. Fun silver label. Tasted again with identical descriptors and ratings.

Kulbacher Eisbock is a clear copper beer with a leathery beige film of a head.  It has a sweet, tart aroma.  It is medium-full bodied and syrupy.  It¬ís very sweet, tast and malty.  The flavor is very clean and strong.  This is nice.  I¬íve never had an eisbock.  It¬ís kind of like a barleywine.

Big malt aroma jumps out even before pouring, bread, raisin, fig, toast.  Pour dark brown, but clear, moderate tan head.  Flavor is toasted maltiness, bread and dried fruits, some apple cider.  Finishes more bitter than sweet.  Medium body, distinctly warming on the palate.

From a 12 fl. oz. bottle no. 1757315.  This pours a vey brown with hints of ruby red when held to the light.  The head is a modest beige that stays around for most of the the tasting.  The aroma is of sweet malts and alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel.  The taste is like a strong ale with a noticeable alcohol note but smooth on the throat when it goes down.  Hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle.  Sampled at the 2009 Peoria International Beer Festival.  Dark red-brown with an off-white head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving no lacing.  Aroma is super rich and malty.  Assertive flavor is roasty, chocolatey and sweet.
[330 ml bottle] Dark ruby red volor with lots of nice foam, that disappear quick. Aroma of caramell and herbs. Taste of fruits, caramell, herbs and a bit honey in the end.

Deep mahogany pour with a ruby highlight ans a small off-white head that fades quickly to a thin ring.  Very rich dark fruit aroma with hints of molasses, cherry, brandy, and some vinous quality.  The flavor is burnt caramel, dates, tobacco, brandy, a little cocoa, and some more vinous hints on the finish.  There¬ís also a little bit of a lingering irony/vegetal note after you swallow.  Oily, medium-full body.  This a real winter warmer or desert beer but it is slightly cloying.

(bottle) pours a dark ruby colour with a faint tan head. aroma oozing chocolate cake and marzipan, with some notes of roasted malt, coffee and soy-sauce. flavour is exactly the same, the marzipan being quite prominent. heavy body with moderate carbonation and a semi-dry roasted finish.
Pours dark brown with little head. Aroma is rich and malty, with caramel and raisiny notes. Flavor is malty, warming, and little else.
Rich thick and heavy. Not a very pleaing sweetness. Very sticky. Syrupy and malty, one dimentional.
tasting at the bluebird.  vintage bottle from 7/11/96.  had an aggressive taste to it.  an in your face smell and surprisingly smooth follow through.

Clear dark brown, thick fine brown head. aroma is a little spritty, caramel, dark toffee. aroma not that strong, and seems to be to be rather one dimenstional.
flavor: dark toffee, dark sugar, caramel. slight roasted grains. too toffee like for my taste. flavor is quite full and well balanced.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of toasted, dark chocolate and mild coffee, light flowers and dough for the yeast, with notes of raisin, brown sugar, vanilla, sapodilla and melon. Head is huge, creamy with some larger bubbles, very light brown, with fair lacing yet great legs and is fully lasting. Color is clear dark brown. Flavor is heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic. Palate is medium to full, syrupy, has a lively carbonation and finishes moderately alcoholic and chewy. A sweet fruity beer without being cloying, but the mouthfeel puts this Eisbock over the top.
Bottle.  Poured a dark reddish brown thin eggshell head.  Aroma is malty with fruit.  The flavor is very sweet malt, raisin, almost belgian-like.  Body if pretty full with warming alcohol.  Good.
Pours a dark brown with a thin dark tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, caramel malt.  Taste is very clean and crisp for a dark beer.  Taste is roasted malt and dark fruit.  Good stuff.

11.2oz. pours darkk brown with small head. aroma is dried prunes and fig and a little cocoa. mouthful is full and burst with the dried fruit roasted malt and big crisp finish. very yummy and well balanced eisbock.

12oz bottle thanks to MrChopin. Pours clear dark reddish bronw with huge tan head. Aroma is toasted malt, caramel, brown sugar and some bread. Flavor is rich with caramel, brown sugar, toasted malt, toffee and some wood. Really well balanced and hides alcohool weel. Mouthfeel is medium but perfect for style. Really good brew.

Aroma:malty sorts of aromas. no hop aroma.  mostly carmel, some bread or pie crust, a  little toasty

Appearance: pretty dark, not as dark as a stout but darker than a brown. some redness or amber when held up to a light. big head first that dissipated quickly. 

Flavor: really malty. no real perceivable hop flavor. mostly like toasted bread or pie crust, a little roastiness, less carmel

Palate: smooth, medium body, no real perceivable sweetness, slight bitterness in the finish

Overall Impression: Its just like I hoped it would be. Very flavorful, very malty, but not sweet or syrupy. I had hoped for more carmel and less roastiness though.
UPDATED: DEC 15, 2010 Draft.  Pours a dark brown with medium head. Aroma is malty and strong. Taste is caramel, bread, noticeable alcohol. Very good though.
Bottle: Dark bron/red colour, with a nice head. Aroma of lots of malts, citric,, medium to ful body. nice medium caramelly finish. this was a werry nice Eisbock,best so far

Poured a clear reddish brown with a medium sized off white head. Aroma is noticeably strong of alcohol and syrup. Taste is alright, but not to my liking, a little overpowering initally. Rich roasted malts and toffee flavours.
Dark, fruity.  Kinda sweet.  There¬ís a slight roast flavor in the finish that is a nice touch. Very smooth.  Very good beer.
Dark brown-red pour with a large tan head. Sweet aroma of caramel and dark fruits. Flavor is malty, mostly caramel with some alcohol at the finish. Medium-heavy body.

Nearly-black dark brown pour with medium head has a dark fruit and caramel aroma.  Palate is fairly heavy, although lighter than anticipated and with heavy carbonation. Flavors are very nice in this eisbock:  a strong malty molasses flavor dominates, with raisin, caramel, chocolate, and faint oak. This is very enjoyable and solid, although I prefer the weight and depth of the Aventinus Eisbock slightly more.

First Eisbock I have tried.  Pours a dark brown with a small tan, quickly diminishing head.  Unique taste, almost caramel with a bit of chocolate.  I wasn¬ít expecting much as I got a single of this for 2.99 but it was a damn good beer.
Brown in color with a medium sized head. Aroma is of alcohol, oak, caramel, and chocolate. Taste is of caramel, chocolate, oak and whiskey.

330 ml bottle. Very dark colour, almost black, with ruby red
  hues. Strong chocolatey caramel aroma. Sharp hops initially, but
  that is soon replaced by lots of chocolate flavours. Mellow soft
  texture. Much like ovamaltine. Hints of raisins and wood, but it is
  the chocolate and the caramel that dominates. Thick body, but not at
  all cloying. A rich malty beer, which is surprisingly
  drinkable. Best before 22.10.04.
Dark amber color with a consistent creamy head. Bold sweet flavor, but not overpowering. A fairly heavy brew, sip & enjoy, a flavorable experience.
Bottle. Dark brown-red body. A small thin begie head. Aroma is very sweet, burnt sugar, malty and cola. Also some spices. Flavor is warming, "aleish", sweet malty and spices.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a slightly tan head.  Nice fruity/malty aroma.  Sweet taste of caramel, fruit, and slightly roasted malts.  Nice finish.

Pours thick dark brown with a tan head Sweet aroma which is like a symphony of dried dark fruit, plums, banana and chocolate with a hint of roasted malt. Sweet aroma of spices, raisin, cloves and caramel. Finishing with a warming touch of alcohol.

Bottle.Pours a beautiful reddish brown with small head. Rich aroma of sweet malt, caramel, toffee and dark fruit. Flavour has sweet malt, toffee and dark fruits. Warm and smooth finish with a light bitterness. I really enjoyed this.
12oz bottle aged one year.  Dark brown pour with a big tan head.  Malty sweet and nutty notes in the aroma.  Sweet flavor with vanilla, nuts and some roastiness.  Pretty good.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a light tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits.  Flavor is of caramel and dark fruits.  Clean finish with very little warming alcohol.

Nose of dried fruits, roast, chocolate and slight smoke.  The mouthfeel is faintly slick but thick, a slight warming but well blended for a beer of this strength.  Dark chocolate, cherries, raisins, figs, molasses, cloves, bannana, toffee, caramel.  It is all in there.  Finish is warm but rather dry.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Deep red colour, small beige head, creamy. Some lacing. Aroma is malty, sweet. warming, jam, honeylike. Flavour is sweet, honeylike,a bit metallic reminiscent of samichlaus. There is caramel and it has a vinous quality. Mouthfeel is smooth woth small bubbles, medium body. There is a faint bitterness in the finish. This beer was very good, but it is so sweet that it got a bit overwhelming at the end.

Serving type: bottle

Big, figgy, sherry/plum bock aroma with bitter chocolate and light vinegar- quite good. Very dark, clear, rootbeer brown beer, tall head in a pint glass, cool holographic crystal effect on the label.  Strong, but nice and smooth.  Reminds me of Moretti La Rossa.  Fairly sweet, prune-y flavor, reasonably boozy. A chalky, chocolate finish over a viscous beer -- making for a pudding-like mouthfeel.  Really a good beer, but one or two is plenty. Liquor Loft.
Bottle. Dark fruits, cherry, candied sugar and caramel prevail. Would buy again.

Apperance: Dark brown with nice, beige, head that disappears rather quickly. Some lacing.

Aroma: Dark fruit, Caramel, Malts, Brown sugar, Dark bread.

Flavor: Malts, Sherry, Bread, Alcohol, Ripe fruit, Grain.

Palate: Low carbonation. Very sweet and warming with a hint of hops and alcohol at the end.

A decent eisbock but this one just didn¬ít cut it for me. Too sweet and boozy. Quite nice to sip at, slowly, tho. Worth a try!

On tap. Poured ruby brown body with a thin mocha colored head. Strong fruity sweet nose. Strong flavor of licorice, grapes, candied sugar, nutty malt. I didn¬ít find the alcohol overpowering or the carbonation detrimental to the flavor. Reminded me of a celebrator.

Nice deep brown coloured body with a strong ruby tint and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of strong concord grapes, nuts, coffee and a lot of sweet sugars. Full-bodied; Strong alcoholic flavour with grapes up front, fading to a lot of malt and ending with a bunch of nuts. Aftertaste shows a bit of sugars, a lot of nutty maltiness and a significant amount of alcohol in the palate. Overall, a good icebock with good complexity. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Oliver¬ís Beverage in Albany, New York on 22-December-2008, sampled on 09-January-2009 at home in Washington.

Dark pour into snifter, but some light seeps through.  Sort of a weak, tan head that dissipates quickly.  Some bubbles float around aimlessly on the top.  Sweet, smokey nose similar to a scotch ale or Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock. Much more smoke, and a bit of dark, dried fruits.  Flavor is sweet, with bits of fruit and chocolate. Heavy flavor with a bit of caramel, toffee and coffee. Palate is thick, with a crisp carbonation. Finish is bittersweet. The ABV is not noticeable in the flavor, but you can feel it half way through the glass. While you could not drink more than one of these in a sitting, one bottle of this is awesome.
Smoky nose.  Black and a sticky white head.  More smoke and charred character in the sip, floral bouquet mid plate.  Sweet finish with more smoke.

First for me from this brewery.

A: Dark as night, tan head, quick fade. Lace is decent though.

S: Prunes, toffee. Sweet malts.

T: Ripe bananna, fig/raisin. Toffee, candy, malt. A little bitter hops at the end. Nice.

M: Lush, smooth, coats your mouth with sweet goodness. Low carbonation, perfect for the style.

D: Almost gave it a 5. Had to hold back because of the high ABV. Easy to sip, knocks you on your can pretty quick. The ABV is well hidden on this one.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Very dark brown, tan head. Sweet malty aroma.
Too sweet tasting, the alcohol is well hidden. Due to the decription of the style I expected somthing a lot rougher...

On tap at Biermuseum, Koln.  Very dark brown colour.  Good dry malt, OK yes its 24 degrees, but it is excellent.  Really thick in the mouth.  Really good toffee, natural carbonation, quite soft, some liquorice, nicely and subtley warming.

Happy 50th Present from my daughter!  Pours a dark brown with a tan head that holds .  Malty aromathat is kind of sweet.  Nice dark brown sugar flavor with some nuttiness to it, nice maltiness.  great mouthfeel.  Nice bittering on the back side.  A great way to enter the next 50 years of life!

This is quite a remarkable beer. It pours a deep, dark brown with a rich tan head that disappears quickly. This reminds me a lot of the Spaten Optimator, a dopplebock, but this beer has more spice, nuts, and complexity. The aroma is rich and sweet. Alcohol is barely noticeable in the aroma and more noticeable in the flavor. The palate is full and heavy. The flavor has brown sugar, nuts, and alcohol, and is quite sharp and bright overall. The flavor doesn‚Äôt linger long either. This is no doubt a great winter beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark, slightly translucent burnt brown sugar brown.  A small fizzy tan head that disappears quickly.  Very sweet sugary aroma with some bananas foster.  Definite alcohol notes.  The flavor is a deep caramelized sugar with some fruit.  Lots of alcohol and roasted smoky notes.  The body is very rich and creamy.  Pretty good.
Bottle from Bruisin Ales.  This hit me over the head with soy and teriyaki.  Salty molasses.  Three words for this beer: malty and salty.  Three more: not my bag.
Bottle pours a ruby brown body with a tan head.  Big dark fruit aromatic character of plum, alcohol, raisin, caramel, and toffee.
Pours dark red with excellent longlasting light beige head. Aroma of toffee bread and caramell. Taste is sweet with a nice lingering long lasting bitterness. A nice christmas brew.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 Bottle. Dark brown colour with a disappearing beige head. Malty aroma with notes of sweetness, figs, caramel and grain. Sweet and malty taste, dark fruits, licorice, alcohol, peat, and lightly roastiness. Not a bad brew, but not that great either.
Bottle. Dark ruby/black. Decent head. Aroma of burnt sugar and dark fruits. Somewhat metallic taste, rather sugary, some licorice with subtle alcohol-sting-bitterness in the finish. Good one.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with a big off-whit head. The aroma has a fantastic and sweet wort-like, grainy German maltiness with tones of caramel, sweet juicy dark bread, almond paste, maple syrup, light roast, caramelized nuts and dark fruits like prunes and sugar sweaty figs. The woody alcohol notes are notable - yet surprisingly soft. Some grassy and mild herbal hops are also present. Cocoa milk. The flavour is massive malty with an alcohol sting to back it up. Tones of caramel, oatmeal cookies, sweet wort, grass and herbs. The flavour is maple sweet but the alcohol dries out the beer on the finish. Light to medium sweet. The mouthfeel is fat, syrupy and chewable with a nice smallish carbonation. The aftertaste is of dark fruits, wort, brown sugar and a light hoppy touch.  Medium to full bodied.

Dark brown purplish pour with garnet highlights and thin light tan head.  Nose of raisin and anise, some plum, and huge amounts of sweet dark malt, but absent is alcohol.  Flavors are earthy, rum soaked fruit, black cherry, peat, leather.  There is a pleasant warming sensation but not much alcohol flavor.  Body is medium chewy with high carbonation.  Very tasty and very alcoholic, a winning combo in my book...

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Pours with a large, creamy, light brown head that stays for a while. Good lacing. Deep brown body. Aroma of dark fruits, cherries, sweet, brandy, and berries. Taste is sweet with caramel, marshmallows, fruit and berries. Syrupy mouthfeel, light bubbles, well hidden alcohol.

Bottle. Pours a thick red/brown color. Looks really nice in the glass! Aroma is fruity with som chocolat in there. Lots of sweet notes aswell. Taste is malty with lots of dark fruit,caramel and some dark bread. Hides the alcohol really well. Mouthfeel is creamy and thick. Good!

UPDATED: APR 15, 2009 My first Eisbock... it¬ís goona be interesting!

Pours a dark brown color with nice foamy beige head which dissapears. Not that much lacing.

Aroma is maybe not that powerful as some beers, like imperial stouts and barley wines, can be, but still very nice. Malty with lots of liquorice and dried fruits. I also feel something I would describe like some strong wine, maybe port? Nice.

Flavour is rather malty but not that sweet. Notes of liquorice, caramel, lots of dried fruits and dark bread. Pretty similar to the smell. Very well hidden alcohol, though it is slightly warming. Almost excellent taste actually. I really enjoy this.

Very complex - I am sure there is other flavours and aromas I can not detect here.

Mouthfeel is very filling. It feels rather fullbodied with low carbonation, a bit creamy and almost sticky.

Drinkability is rather high for the high ABV. Goes down a bit to easy maybe? Great beer!

Bottle. Pours clear brown with big but short lasting white head. The aroma reminds me of balsamico. There¬¥s also some chocolate to it. Sweet taste. Balsamico... but also soy. Chocolate. This was my first eisbock, but not the last one. Interesting!

In short: A syrupy typical Eisbock. Sweet sipper. Good for the style but not my style. How: Bottle 11.2oz, vintage 1 year old. The look: Very dark ruby body topped by a small tan head In long: Big molasses and tobacco nose. Taste is sweet, molasses, dates and figs, graham cookies, spicy notes, brown sugar, hard candies. This really is a sweet dessert sipper with no balance attempt. Overall pleasant crispness but the body is a bit syrupy. 9.2% is apparent with a little bite in the finish. A reference for the Eisbock style but Eisbock is just not my style. Don¬ít recycle the bottles, give them to your acid-dropping stoner cousin for hours of psychedelic entertainment.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a very nice, dark brown with frothy tan head.  No lacing.  Aroma is strong...maily dried fruit and malt.  Flavor is similar, almost like a fine port, sweet, malty with a pronounced alcohol bite.  Palate is med-heavy with an odd foamy mouthfeel.  Overall a very good beer.

I guess bocks will never be my favorite style, one way or another. Dark clear brown with a medium brown head. Sweet syrup nose mixed with alchohol and some vanilla. Sharp alchohol bitterness along with the sweet malts. Its the harsh bitterness that sets me off, but definetly a powerfull brew.
12oz bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany with a small head.  Aromas of caramel malt, alcohol, and raisins.  Flavors....Im f*cked up.  Its good, ginger? chocolate? and caramel.  Daddy like.

Draught at TND:  Aroma of yeast, malts, dark fruits, raisin, slight chocolate, and nuts.  Poured brown/extremely deep orange in color with a small tan head.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes of malts, burning, yeast, candi sugar, dark ripe fruits, nuts, slight caramel, slight chocolate, and slight alcohol.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty, nutty finish.

330 mL bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with little carbonation and a small, Coca-Cola-like head that disappears almost completely. Nose is straight up Strawberry Twizzlers. There is some toast, roasted malt, caramel and, toffee as well. Taste is very much like a Celebrator and Barleywine combined. Lots of raisins, mild bitter hops, and red grapes. Excellent. The 9.2 abv is nicely covered with very little alcohol warming. Neutral palate in the end. Overall superb.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2008 Bottle. Ruby brown, low golden brown layer. 
Toffee nose with a light herbal and wooden edge. Wooden start, caramel, chocolate, light nuts, tobacco, oranges, a hint berries. Fullbodied, slick mouthfeel. 
I tried a older bottle before and was surprised how badly it had aged.
Black with smaller head.  Ginger coffee chocolate, vanilla malt caramel tangy sweetness.  Decent amount of balance and character, a good tasty brew, a little quenching too.  Nice, a good brew to try.

Shared this one w/ oldrtybastrd. Picked up at Maruhn Getr√§nke in Darmstadt. Pours a dark reddish brown. Sweet caramel/roasty aroma, smells like blackstrap molasses. Roast malt/chocolate flavor with a touch of fruit and great alcohol bite in the finish..

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getr√§nke in Darmstadt.  Pours a dark reddish brown.  Sweet caramel/roasty aroma, smells like blackstrap molasses.  Roast malt/chocolate flavor with a touch of fruit and great alcohol bite in the finish..

33cl bottle. Cool label design: poured dark brown with a medium sized light brown head. Very rich aroma of caramel, figs, raisins, prunes, etc. Taste is very malty with all the dark fruits above. Starts off sweet and finishes nicely bitter albeit mild. Undoubtedly Kulmbacher¬ís best beer.

Smells like prunes and caramel.  Looks roasty brown with upper 2/3‚Äôs of glass too dark to see through.  A well disguised wallop.  A deep but roasty and dry flavor. Almost taste like a fuller bodied nut-brown.  Not a favorite but decent. Just recently had something similar I liked better.

Bottle shared by footbalm, thanks man. Pours a cloudy toffee color with a medium tan head. The aroma is very sweet; almost like a Barley Wine; sweet candies and tons of rich malts. The flavor was quite interesting; loads of rich and intense malt, a ton of dusty dryness leaving your palate really quickly. Not too hot, just a bit of alcohol warmth. A bit of yeast and caramel also. Pretty damn good and interesting.
